{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2011}} The '''Dollar Sweets dispute''' in 1985 was a small [[industrial dispute]] with major legal ramifications in [[industrial relations]] where an employer resorted to a [[common law]] verdict and damages in a case in the [[Supreme Court of Victoria]] to resolve a dispute after industrial courts proved ineffective. It was the first time a [[trade union]] was forced to pay common law damages to an employer for losses suffered through [[Picketing (protest)|picketing]] in [[Australia]]. The dispute was also significant for boosting the career of the barrister representing the company, [[Peter Costello]], leading him to stand for federal Parliament and become Treasurer in the Howard Government.
==Background== Dollar Sweets was a confectionery company in the Melbourne suburb of [[Malvern, Victoria|Malvern]] employing 27 people on a 38-hour week basis. The award for the industry specified a 40-hour week. The Hawke Government and the [[ACTU]] had entered into a [[Prices and Incomes Accord|wages accord]] which provided employer superannuation, reduced taxation and other social gains in return for unions agreeing to not pursue excessive wage claims. At the same time, centralised wage fixing was introduced in September 1983 where indexed wage rises were automatically granted to those workers whose unions undertook to abide by the Arbitration Commission's principles.
Several small unions, including the [[Federated Confectioners Association of Australia]], refused to join the accord.
The company owner, Fred Stauder, proposed an agreement with his employees in November 1983, that if they agreed to abide by the principles of the Arbitration Commission, the company would pay them the prescribed increases. All 27 employees agreed to the proposal.<ref>Peter Costello ''[http://www.hrnicholls.com.au/archives/vol5/vol5-5.php In Search of the Magic Pudding: The Dollar Sweets Story] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719125131/http://www.hrnicholls.com.au/archives/vol5/vol5-5.php |date=19 July 2008 }}'' Published by the [[H.R. Nicholls Society]], Accessed 6 August 2008</ref>
==The dispute== In July 1985, the Federated Confectioners Association started a campaign with employers for a 36-hour week. Although this breached Arbitration Commission wage-fixing principles, the union had never agreed to accept those principles. When the union demanded negotiations with Stauder on a 36-hour week, Stauder told the union he could not afford to reduce hours and offered to show his accounts to the union. A reduction in hours would have also broken the 1983 agreement Stauder had reached with his employees.
Stauder offered his 27 employees that if they wished to continue to receive over-award pay for a (below-award) 38-hour week, they could do so if they signed a no-strike agreement; but, if they wanted to work a 36-hour week, they would have to find it elsewhere. Twelve employees accepted Stauder's offer, whereas the other 15 refused to sign the no-strike agreement and were subsequently sacked by the company, with the company employing another 15 workers in their place on existing conditions.<ref name="Peterson">{{cite web |author=Peterson, Eric |url=http://www.anu.edu.au/polsci/marx/interventions/law.htm |title=The legal antecedents of the Workplace Relations Act- From the Plague to Reith |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071223091515/http://www.anu.edu.au/polsci/marx/interventions/law.htm |archive-date=23 December 2007 |dead-url=yes}}</ref>
On 22 July 1985, a picket line was established by the sacked workers outside the Dollar Sweets factory. The picket line remained for 143 days, with the company refusing to reinstate the workers.
By October 1985, the company was still refusing to reinstate the sacked workers but through the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission had provided "an offer to assist in finding alternate employment within the industry and also to supply references to those people." Commissioner Bain recommended "that those who have been picketing should accept the employer's offer and cease their picketing forthwith."<ref>{{cite AustLII|AIRC|403|1985|litigants=Dollar Sweets Pty Ltd and The Federated Confectioners Association of Australia |courtname=[[Australian Industrial Relations Commission]] |date=22 October 1985}}.</ref>
A number of bomb and arson threats were made against Dollar Sweets and one strike-breaking driver was assaulted and his truck vandalised.<ref>{{cite book| title=The End of Certainty: Power, Politics, and Business in Australia| first=Paul| last=Kelly|date=December 1994| publisher=Allen & Unwin| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EKXBgmYeO2QC&pg=PA258&lpg=PA258&dq=%22dollar+sweets%22&source=web&ots=kTLtdiqPEK&sig=02uiXgzRUAyzTRjgfdVybLsZMGk#PPA258,M1| isbn=978-1-86373-757-9}}</ref> At one point, phone and telex lines were cut to the factory with telecom workers refusing to cross the picket line to repair the services.<ref name="SMH 26 Jul 06"/>
Dollar Sweets received strong support and assistance from [[Richard Mulcahy (Australian politician)|Richard Mulcahy]], chief executive officer of the [[Confectionery Manufacturers of Australia]]. By December 1985, it was decided to seek an injunction under common law against the union in the [[Supreme Court of Victoria]], with solicitor [[Michael Kroger]] engaging [[Alan Goldberg (judge)|Alan Goldberg]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|QC}} to lead junior barrister and future federal Treasurer [[Peter Costello]] to represent the company. The case was financed by the [[Victorian Chamber of Commerce]].<ref name="SMH 26 Jul 06"/>
The company alleged union interference with contractual relations, intimidation, nuisance, and a conspiracy to injure the plaintiff and sought an injunction and punitive damages. Victorian Supreme Court Justice Peter Murphy gave judgement, issued restraining orders on 12 December with the picket ending the next day. In his judgement, Murphy described the picketing as "stupid and nihilistic." He ruled that this was not a "lawful form of picketing, but a... nuisance involving obstruction, harassment, and besetting". It was beside the point that there were specialist courts for industrial disputes. "This court is not without power ... and should intervene". He issued an interlocutory injunction against the picket,<ref>{{cite AustLII|VicRp|38|1986|litigants=Dollar Sweets Pty Ltd v Federated Confectioners Association of Australia |parallelcite=[1986] [[Victorian Reports|VR]] 383 |date=12 December 1985 |courtname=[[Supreme Court of Victoria|Supreme Court]] (Vic)}}.</ref> The common law damages claim was settled in April 1988, when the union paid the sum of $175,000 to Dollar Sweets as compensation for the losses it suffered as a result of the picket.<ref name="Peterson"/><ref name="SMH 26 Jul 06">{{cite News |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/the-sweets-of-a-famous-victory/2006/07/25/1153816182414.html |title=The sweets of a famous victory |newspaper=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=26 July 2006 |access-date=6 August 2008}}</ref>
==Aftermath==
Fred Stauder sold Dollar Sweets Holding Limited in 1999, which is now called [[Snack Foods Limited]].
Peter Costello described the case as "''It came to be bracketed with the [[Mudginberri dispute|Mudginberri Abattoir case]] as a great victory against militant unionism''".<ref>{{cite News|author=Peter Costello |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/freds-place-in-political-history/2006/07/25/1153816182417.html?page=fullpage |title=Fred's place in political history |newspaper=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=26 July 2006 |access-date=6 August 2008}}.</ref>
[[Doug Cameron (politician)|Doug Cameron]], the secretary of the [[Australian Manufacturing Workers Union]], with which the Federated Confectioners Association amalgamated, saw the dispute as a turning point. "''It was when the social contract between workers, business and the government started to collapse,''" and "''It became a cause celebre for the big end of town and lawyers started to realise they could make money ripping off the pay and conditions of workers.''"<ref name="SMH 26 Jul 06"/>

The '''Dublin Statement on Water and Sustainable Development''', also known as the '''Dublin Principles''', was a meeting of experts on water related problems that took place on 31 January 1992 at the International Conference on Water and the Environment (ICWE), Dublin, Ireland, organised on 26–31 January 1992.
The Dublin Statement on Water and Sustainable Development recognises the increasing [[water scarcity|scarcity of water]] as a result of the different conflicting uses and overuses of water.
== The Dublin Principles ==
The declaration sets out recommendations for action at local, national and international levels to reduce the scarcity, through the following four guiding principles:<ref>http://www.wmo.ch/pages/prog/hwrp/documents/english/icwedece.html</ref><ref>http://docs.watsan.net/Scanned_PDF_Files/Class_Code_7_Conference/71-ICWE92-9739.pdf</ref>
#[[Fresh water]] is a [[finite resource|finite and vulnerable resource]], essential to sustain life, development and the environment #[[Water development]] and [[water management|management]] should be based on a participatory approach, involving users, planners and policy-makers at all levels #[[Women]] play a central part in the provision, management and safeguarding of water #Water has an [[economic value]] in all its competing uses and should be recognized as an [[economic good]]
== Water as a human right or economic good? ==
The emphasis of the Dublin Statement on ''the economic value'' of water rather than water as ''a [[universal right]]'' is highly contested by [[NGO]]s and human rights activists (although the full text of principle 4 does state ''it is vital to recognize first the basic right of all human beings to have access to clean water and [[sanitation]] at an affordable price'')
In November 2002, however, the UN [[Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights]] adopted ''General Comment No. 15'', which was formulated by experts as a comment on articles 11 and 12 of the [[International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldwatercouncil.org/index.php?id%3D1764 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717002357/http://www.worldwatercouncil.org/index.php?id=1764 |archivedate=2011-07-17 |df= }}</ref> In this comment, water is recognised not only as a limited natural resource and a public good but also as a [[human right]]. This step - adopting General Comment No. 15 - was seen as a decisive step towards the recognition of water as universal right.
On 30 September 2010, the 15th Session of the UN Human Rights Council passed Resolution A/HRC/15/L.14,<ref>http://ap.ohchr.org/documents/dpage_e.aspx?si=A/HRC/15/L.14</ref> reaffirming an earlier General Assembly resolution (64/292 of 28 July 2010) which ''recognized the right to safe and clean [[drinking water]] and sanitation as a human right that is essential for the full enjoyment of life and all human rights''. Resolution A/HRC/15/L.14 clarifies that ''the human right to safe drinking water and sanitation is derived from the [[right to an adequate standard of living]] and inextricably related to the right to the highest attainable standard of [[physical health|physical]] and [[mental health]], as well as the right to life and [[human dignity]]''.

Retrieved 20 August 2016. The customs union is a principal component of the [[European Economic Community]], established in 1958, and now succeeded by the [[European Union]]. No customs duties are levied on goods travelling within the customs union and – unlike a [[free trade area]] – members of the customs union impose a [[common external tariff]] on all goods entering the union.{{Cite journal|last=Erskine|first=Daniel H|date=2006|title=The United States-EC Dispute Over Customs Matters: Trade Facilitation, Customs Unions, and the Meaning of WTO Obligations|url=https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=987367|journal=Florida Journal of International Law|language=en|volume=18|pages=432-485|via=}} A precondition of the customs union is that the [[European Commission]] negotiates for and on behalf of the Union as a whole in international trade deals such as the [[World Trade Organization]], rather than each member state negotiating individually. == Non-EU participants == Monaco and the British dependencies of Akrotiri and Dhekelia, Guernsey, the Isle of Man and Jersey are integral parts of the EU's customs territory. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Notes |- | {{nowrap|{{flagdeco|Andorra}} [[Andorra–European Union relations|Andorra]]}} | Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Economic Community and the Principality of Andorra – Joint Declarations{{citeweb|url=http://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/customs/customs_duties/rules_origin/customs_unions/article_412_en.htm |title=Andorra : Customs Unions and preferential arrangements |publisher=[[European Commission]] |accessdate=12 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121026034312/http://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/customs/customs_duties/rules_origin/customs_unions/article_412_en.htm |archivedate=26 October 2012 }} | 1 January 1991 | Excludes agricultural products |- | {{nowrap|{{flagdeco|San Marino}} [[San Marino–European Union relations|San Marino]]}} | Agreement on Cooperation and Customs Union between the European Economic Community and the Republic of San Marino{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2002:084:0043:0052:EN:PDF|title=Agreement on Cooperation and Customs Union between the European Economic Community and the Republic of San Marino|publisher=}} | 16 December 1991 | |- | {{flagdeco|Turkey}} [[Accession of Turkey to the European Union|Turkey]] | Decision No 1/95 of the EC-Turkey Association Council of 22 December 1995 on implementing the final phase of the [[European Union–Turkey Customs Union]]{{cite web|url=http://www.avrupa.info.tr/fileadmin/Content/Downloads/PDF/Custom_Union_des_ENG.pdf|title=Decision No 1/95 of the EC-Turkey Association Council of 22 December 1995 on implementing the final phase of the Customs Union|publisher=}} | 31 December 1995 | Excludes agricultural products |- |} == EU territories with an opt-out == While all EU member states are part of the customs union, not all of their respective territories participate. Territories of member states which have remained outside of the EU ([[overseas countries and territories of the European Union]]) generally do not participate in the customs union. However, there are seven territories that are within the EU which do not participate in the customs union:{{why|date=December 2018}} *[[Büsingen am Hochrhein]] (a German exclave within Switzerland, part of the Switzerland–Liechtenstein customs area)Article 6 of [http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/ALL/?uri=celex%3A32006L0112 Council Directive 2006/112/EC], 28 November 2006 *[[Campione d'Italia]] and the adjacent Italian waters of [[Lake Lugano]] (an Italian exclave within Switzerland, part of the Switzerland–Liechtenstein customs area) *[[Livigno]] *[[Ceuta]] *[[Melilla]] *[[Gibraltar]]Article 28 of the Act concerning the conditions of Accession and the Adjustments to the Treaties, 22 January 1972 *[[Heligoland]] *[[Madeira]] *[[Azores]] == Union Customs Code == {{Main|Union Customs Code}} The [[Union Customs Code]] (UCC), intended to modernise customs procedures, entered into force on 1 May 2016.{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/customs/customs_code/union_customs_code/ucc/index_en.htm|title=Union Customs Code – Taxation and customs union – European Commission|website=Taxation and customs union}} Implementation will take place over a period of time and full implementation is anticipated by 31 December 2020 at the latest.[https://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/business/union-customs-code/ucc-introduction_en UCC: an Introduction], accessed 29 January 2017 The European Commission has stated that the aims of the UCC are simplicity, service and speed. == Common external tariffs == The EU Customs Union sets the tariff rates for imports to the EU from other countries. These rates are detailed and depend on the specific type of product imported, and can also vary by the time of year.[https://circabc.europa.eu/faces/jsp/extension/wai/navigation/container.jsp Taric and Quota Data & Information] {{snd}} [[European Commission]] Communication and Information Resource Centre for Administrations, Businesses and Citizens. The full [[WTO]] [[Most Favoured Nation]] tariff rates apply only to those countries that do not have a [[European Union free trade agreements|Free Trade Agreement with the EU]], or are not on a WTO recognised exemption scheme such as [[Everything but Arms]] (an EU support arrangement for [[Least Developed Countries]]). == See also == *[[European Customs Information Portal]] *[[European integration]] *[[European Single Market]] *[[European Free Trade Association]] *[[European Economic Area]] (EU and EFTA except Switzerland) *[[European Union–Turkey Customs Union]] *[[Free trade areas in Europe]] *[[Non-tariff barriers to trade]] == External links == * [http://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/dds2/taric/taric_consultation.jsp TARIC database enquiry system], gives current tariff rates applicable by exporting country and season {{snd}} [[European Commission]]: Communication and Information Resource Centre for Administrations, Businesses and Citizens. ** [https://circabc.europa.eu/faces/jsp/extension/wai/navigation/container.jsp TARIC and Quota Data & Information]: user guides for the TARIC database above {{snd}} European Commission: Communication and Information Resource Centre for Administrations, Businesses and Citizens. * [https://www.ft.com/content/b4458652-f42d-11e6-8758-6876151821a6 Turkey border gridlock hints at pain to come for Brexit Britain] [[The Financial Times]], February 16, 2017 == References == {{reflist|30em}} {{Foreign relations of the European Union}} [[Category:Customs unions]] [[Category:Customs treaties]] [[Category:European Union law]] [[Category:Treaties entered into by the European Union|Customs]] [[Category:Treaties of Andorra]] [[Category:Treaties of Monaco]] [[Category:Treaties of San Marino]]

{{Infobox organization |name = Federal Bar Council |image = Federal Bar Council Logo.jpeg |size = 350px |formation = 1928 |leader_title = |leader_name = |location = New York, [[New York, NY|New York]], USA |website = {{URL|http://www.federalbarcouncil.org}} }}
'''The Federal Bar Council''' is a not-for-profit specialty Bar association whose membership consists of [[lawyer]]s and judges who practice primarily in federal courts within the [[Second Circuit]]. The Second Circuit covers the following districts: District of Connecticut, Eastern District of New York, Northern District of New York, Southern District of New York, Western District of New York and District of Vermont. The Federal Bar Council's offices are in White Plains, New York.
The organization was created as a separate organization by act of the [[New York State Legislature]], effective April 1932, under the name "the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut." It adopted its current, shorter name in 1968.
==Historical Timeline== *1928 - The organization began as a chapter of a national association of attorneys employed by the federal government. *1932 - The Council was created as a separate organization - the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut - by act of the New York State Legislature then signed into law by Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt on April 1, 1932. *1968 - The organization changed its name to the "Federal Bar Council." *2014 - Following an investigation concerning her treatment of staff members, Federal Bar Council Executive Director Jeanette Redmond is forced to resign. According to reports, Redmond had restricted her enployees' ability to use the restroom. All timeline items are cited from the Federal Bar Council History Webpage.<ref> {{cite web|title=Federal Bar Council History Page|url=http://www.federalbarcouncil.org/our_history.php|publisher=Federal Bar Council}}</ref>

{{Infobox organization | name = Forum for International Conciliation and Arbitration | founded_date = 1996 | homepage = [http://www.ficacic.com/ www.ficacic.com] }}
The '''Forum for International Conciliation and Arbitration (FICA)''' is a non-governmental organisation providing arbitration, dispute-resolution and dispute-avoidance services, founded by [[Ben Beaumont]].
The first operation was initiated by ITC which recommended FICA to work with the Law Association of Zambia to create a new Arbitration Act, enacted in 2002, and train potential Arbitrators during 1996/1997 with funding provided by Chemonics and USAID.
Ben Beaumont was co-opted into the Expert Group of Working Group VI Secured Transactions assisting with the Draft Legislative Guide to the Model Law of Secured Transactions 2005-07.
In 2002 FICA was invited with Observer status to attend [[UNCITRAL]] and is accredited to the [[WTO]] in 1999 and [[International Trade Centre]] (ITC) in 1998.
==External links== *[http://www.ficacic.com Forum for International Conciliation and Arbitration]

{{globalize/US|date=January 2017}} '''Hedonology''' (Hedonics), is the study of the impact an injury or incident had on a persons lifestyle.
== History == The Hedonology Institute was developed by [[Jeffrey Francis Magrowski]], Ph.D., CRC, CRE. A trademark for Hedonology was registered in 1990 and abandoned in 1999 while Magrowski attended college and his studies in Vocational Rehabilitation.
The development and use of Hedonics admissibility of scientific evidence for use in the legal system is set by the standard of [[Hedonic damages]] to evaluate non-economic damages using the American Juris Jurisprudence method (1988), based on the [[Frye Standard]] and supported by the [[Daubert Test]]. The determination of present and future pain and suffering is taken into account. Generally, the fact that statistics can be used, but must get the same result was proven in the use of Hedonics.
The Hedonics model and analysis was first accepted in 1991 in United States Claims Court: Joshua Wasson V. Secretary of the Dept. of Health and Human Services, No. 90-208V. The second case accepting Hedonics in the legal system was in Gary D. Wyatt, Sr. V. The United States of America (Veteran's Administration) 4:94CV1567-DJS September 23, 1996.
An Economist, [[Stan V. Smith, Ph.D. (economist) |Stan V. Smith]], developed a theory of economic damages (as opposed to non-pecuniary, or non-economic damages) for Hedonic Damages based on the value of a human life by statistical analysis, which has not met the Frye or Daubert Test under admissibility in a court of law in several states.
== References == {{reflist}}http://www.nafe.net/JFE/j04_3_am.pdf *Journal of Forensic Economics, 4(3) 1991, pp. 355–367 http://cases.justia.com/us-court-of-appeals/F2/988/131/142052/ *Joshua Wasson V. Secretary of the Dept. of Health and Human Services, No. 90-208V, United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit. - 988 F.2d 131
==External links== *[http://nafe.net/default.aspx "National Association of Forensic Economists, website"]

{{short description|American political controversy surrounding Hillary Rodham Clinton's conduct while Secretary of State}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Hillary Clinton series}} During her [[Hillary Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State|her tenure as United States Secretary of State]], [[Hillary Clinton]] drew controversy by using her family's private [[email server]] for official communications rather than using official [[United States Department of State|State Department]] email accounts maintained on secure federal servers. An [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] examination of Clinton's server found over 100 emails containing classified information, including 65 emails deemed "Secret" and 22 deemed "Top Secret", none with classification markings. An additional 2,093 emails not marked classified were retroactively classified by the State Department.
Some experts, officials, and members of [[United States Congress|Congress]] contended that Clinton's use of a private [[Message transfer agent|messaging system]] and a private server violated State Department protocols and procedures, as well as federal laws and regulations governing [[recordkeeping]]. Clinton responded that her use complied with federal laws and State Department regulations, and that former secretaries of state had also maintained personal email accounts. News reports indicated that the emails discussed "innocuous" matters already available in the public domain. For example, the [[Drone strikes in Pakistan|CIA drone program]] has been widely discussed in the public domain since the early 2000s; however, the very existence of the program is technically classified, so even sharing a newspaper article that mentions it would constitute a security breach as far as the CIA is concerned.<ref>"Secrecy defines Obama’s drone war," ''Washington Post'', December 19, 2011: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/secrecy-defines-obamas-drone-war/2011/10/28/gIQAPKNR5O_story.html</ref><ref>"DoD Warns Employees of Classified Info in Public Domain," Federation of American Scientists, June 11, 2013: https://fas.org/blogs/secrecy/2013/06/dod-classified/</ref>
The controversy was a major point of discussion during the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]], in which Clinton was the Democratic nominee. In May, the [[Office of the Inspector General of the Department of State|State Department's Office of the Inspector General]] released a report about the State Department's email practices, including Clinton's. In July, FBI director [[James Comey]] announced that the FBI investigation had concluded that Clinton had been "extremely careless" but recommended that no charges be filed. Clinton's opponent, presidential candidate [[Donald Trump]], used the nickname "Crooked Hillary" to criticize Clinton primarily for the email controversy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2018/01/05/trumps-nicknames-for-rivals-from-rocket-man-to-pocahontas.html|title=Trump's nicknames for rivals, from 'Rocket Man' to 'Pocahontas'|first=Kaitlyn|last=Schallhorn|date=April 17, 2018|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=April 21, 2018}}</ref> Trump supporters adopted the chant "lock her up" to imply Clinton had committed a crime.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/11/22/a-brief-history-of-the-lock-her-up-chant-as-it-looks-like-trump-might-not-even-try/|title=A brief history of the 'Lock her up!' chant by Trump supporters against Clinton|last=Stevenson|first=Peter|date=November 22, 2016|publisher=[[Washington Post]]}}</ref>
On October 28, 2016, days before the election, Comey notified Congress that the FBI had started looking into newly discovered emails. On November 6, Comey notified Congress that the FBI had not changed its original conclusion.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/2016/11/06/fbi-not-recommending-charges-over-new-clinton-emails/93395808/|work=USA Today|title=FBI declares it is finally done investigating Hillary Clinton's email|authors=Schouten, Fredreka, Kevin Johnson & Heidi Przybyla|date=November 6, 2016}}</ref> Comey's timing was contentious, with critics saying that he had violated Department of Justice guidelines and precedent and prejudiced the public against Clinton.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2016/11/james-comey-fbi-clinton-230851|title=Will Comey survive the Clinton email flap?|work=Politico|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref> The controversy received more media coverage than any other topic during the presidential campaign.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.cjr.org/analysis/fake-news-media-election-trump.php|title=Don't blame the election on fake news. Blame it on the media.|work=Columbia Journalism Review|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://shorensteincenter.org/news-coverage-2016-national-conventions/|title=News Coverage of the 2016 National Conventions: Negative News, Lacking Context|date=2016-09-21|work=Shorenstein Center|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://cyber.harvard.edu/publications/2017/08/mediacloud|title=Partisanship, Propaganda, and Disinformation: Online Media and the 2016 U.S. Presidential Election {{!}} Berkman Klein Center|website=cyber.harvard.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-12-07}}</ref> Clinton and other observers argue that the reopening of the investigation contributed to her loss in the election. In April 2018, Comey said his announcement had been influenced by the fact that he thought it extremely likely that Clinton would become the next President.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/04/13/james-comey-clinton-investigation-poll-numbers-522958|title=Fact-check: Comey didn't say he reopened Clinton investigation because of poll numbers|work=Politico|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref> On June 14, 2018, the Department of Justice's Office of the Inspector General released [[Inspector General report on FBI and DOJ actions in the 2016 election|its report]] on the FBI's and DOJ's handling of Clinton's investigation.<ref name="highlights">{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/live-news/inspector-general-report-clinton-email-investigation-2018-06-14-live-updates/|title=Highlights of DOJ inspector general report on handling of Clinton email probe|date=June 14, 2018|work=CBS News|access-date=2018-06-15|language=en}}</ref>
{{TOC limit|4}}
==Background== ===Clinton's use of BlackBerrys=== [[File:U.S. Air Force Col. Peggy Poore, commander, 65th Air Base Wing, greets Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton during a stop at Lajes Field, Azores, Portugal, June 3, 2009 090603-F-MK264-040.jpg|thumb|Clinton holding a Blackberry phone in 2009]] Prior to her appointment as Secretary of State in 2009, Clinton and her circle of friends and colleagues communicated via [[BlackBerry]] phones.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/how-clintons-email-scandal-took-root/2016/03/27/ee301168-e162-11e5-846c-10191d1fc4ec_story.html|title=How Clinton's email scandal took root|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref> State Department security personnel suggested this would pose a security risk during her tenure.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/26/us/politics/state-department-hillary-clinton-emails.html|title=Hillary Clinton Is Criticized for Private Emails in State Dept. Review|date=May 26, 2016|work=The New York Times|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref> The email account used on Clinton's BlackBerry was then hosted on a private server in the basement of her home in [[Chappaqua, New York]], but that information was not disclosed to State Department security personnel or senior State Department personnel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/may/31/hillary-clinton/fact-checking-hillary-clintons-claim-her-email-pra|title=Not 'allowed': Clinton's email talk misses the mark|publisher=politifact.com|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref>
Setting up a secure desktop computer in her office was suggested, but Clinton was unfamiliar with their use<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/27/us/politics/hillary-clinton-state-department-email-inquiry.html|title=Hillary Clinton Wasn't Adept at Using a Desktop for Email, Inquiry Is Told|date=May 27, 2016|work=The New York Times|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref> and opted for the convenience of her BlackBerry,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-31819843|title=Hillary Clinton: Private email set up for 'convenience'|publisher=BBC|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref> not the State Department, government protocol of a secured desktop computer. Efforts to find a secure solution were abandoned by Clinton,<ref name="lawnewz.com">{{cite web|url=http://lawnewz.com/high-profile/we-now-know-more-about-why-clinton-set-up-private-server-and-its-sketchyy/|title=NSA Refused Clinton a Secure Phone, She Set Up Private Server Instead|publisher=lawnewz.com|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref> and she was warned by State Department security personnel about the vulnerability of an unsecured BlackBerry to hacking.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/3/3/govt-cybersecurity-source-clintons-office-warned-private-email-use.html|title=Revealed: Clinton's office was warned over private email use|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref> She affirmed her knowledge of the danger, and was reportedly told that the [[Bureau of Diplomatic Security]] had obtained intelligence about her vulnerability while she was on a trip to Asia, but continued to use her BlackBerry outside her office.<ref name="WP032716">{{cite news|author1=Robert O'Harrow Jr.|title=How Clinton's email scandal took root|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/how-clintons-email-scandal-took-root/2016/03/27/ee301168-e162-11e5-846c-10191d1fc4ec_story.html|accessdate=March 28, 2016|work=The Washington Post|date=March 27, 2016|quote="The issue here is one of personal comfort", one of the participants in that meeting, Donald Reid, the department's senior coordinator for security infrastructure, wrote afterward in an email that described Clinton's inner circle of advisers as "dedicated [BlackBerry] addicts". ... "Her attention was drawn to the sentence that indicates (Diplomatic Security) have intelligence concerning this vulnerability during her recent trip to Asia. ... "}}</ref>
===Domain names and email server=== [[File:Clintonemail.com Outlook Web App.png|thumb|A screenshot of the Outlook Web App login page that is displayed when navigating to [https://mail.clintonemail.com/owa Clinton's email service]]] At the time of Senate confirmation hearings on Hillary Clinton's nomination as Secretary of State, the [[domain name]]s clintonemail.com, wjcoffice.com, and presidentclinton.com were [[Domain registration|registered]] to Eric Hoteham,<ref name="ABCNews.Hoteham">{{cite web|title=Hillary Clinton Email Mystery Man: What We Know About Eric Hoteham|author=Meghan Keneally|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/hillary-clinton-email-mystery-man-eric-hoteham/story?id=29413827|date=March 5, 2015|publisher=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=March 19, 2015}} (The name Eric Hoteham is similar to that of Eric Hothem, a former Clinton aide.)</ref> with the home of Clinton and her husband in Chappaqua, New York, as the contact address.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://washington.cbslocal.com/2015/03/04/clinton-private-server-listed-under-mysterious-untraceable-name|title=Who Is Eric Hoteham? Clinton Private Server Listed Under Mysterious, Untraceable Name|publisher=Washington.cbslocal.com|date=March 4, 2015|accessdate=April 1, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Sick|first=Gary|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/03/hillary-clinton-email-5-questions-115876.html|title=5 questions: The Clinton email|publisher=Politico.com|date=March 9, 2015|accessdate=April 1, 2015}}</ref> The domains were pointed to a private email server that Clinton (who never had a state.gov email account) used to send and receive email, and which was purchased and installed in the Clintons' home for [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2008|her 2008 presidential campaign]].<ref name=NYT8815>{{cite news|author1=Scott Shane |author2=Michael S. Schmidt|title=Hillary Clinton Emails Take Long Path to Controversy|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/09/us/hillary-clinton-emails-take-long-path-to-controversy.html|accessdate=August 8, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=August 8, 2015}}</ref>
The email server was located in the Clintons' home in Chappaqua, New York, from January 2009 until 2013, when it was sent to a [[data center]] in New Jersey before being handed over to Platte River Networks, a Denver-based [[information technology]] firm that Clinton hired to manage her email system.<ref name=AP0813 /><ref>Natasha Bertrand, [http://www.businessinsider.com/platte-river-hillary-clinton-private-server-2015-8 "VP of Cybersecurity Firm Hired by Hillary Clinton: 'We would never have taken it on' if we knew of the ensuing chaos"], ''Business Insider'', August 19, 2015.</ref><ref name=WP81215>{{cite news|author1=Tom Hamburger |author2=Karen Tumulty|title=Hillary Clinton's e-mail server turned over to FBI|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/clintons-e-mail-server-turned-over-to-fbi/2015/08/12/aba5feea-4160-11e5-8ab4-c73967a143d3_story.html|accessdate=August 14, 2015|work=The Washington Post|date=August 12, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Clintonserver>{{cite news|last1=Labott|first1=Elise|title=Hillary Clinton to turn over private email server to Justice Department|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/11/politics/hillary-clinton-email-server-justice-department/index.html|accessdate=August 12, 2015|publisher=CNN|date=August 11, 2015}}</ref><ref name=server>{{cite news|last1=Dilanian|first1=Ken|title=Clinton relents, gives up possession of private email server|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/40f1d5d9d6cc411a83e8466253e6ef3e/us-official-fbi-has-hillary-clinton-emails-home-server|agency=Associated Press|date=August 11, 2015}}</ref>
The server itself runs a [[Microsoft Exchange Server|Microsoft Exchange 2010]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2015/03/clintons-email-hosted-on-exchange-2010-server-now-not-in-chappaqua|title=Update: Clinton’s e-mail is on a hosted Exchange 2010 server, not in Chappaqua|access-date=July 6, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://mail.clintonemail.com/owa|title=Outlook Web App|website=mail.clintonemail.com|access-date=July 6, 2016}}</ref> server with access to emails over the internet being delivered by [[Outlook Web App]]. The web page is secured with a [[TLS/SSL|TLS certificate]] to allow information to be transmitted securely when using the website. However, for the first two months of its use - January 2009 through March 29, 2009 - the web page was reportedly not secured with a TLS certificate, meaning that information transmitted using the service was unencrypted and may have been liable to interception.<ref name="WP032716"/>
===Initial awareness=== As early as 2009, officials with the [[National Archives and Records Administration]] (NARA) expressed concerns over possible violations of normal federal government record-keeping procedures at the State Department under then-Secretary Clinton.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gerstein|first=Josh|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/03/state-department-email-rule-hillary-clinton-115804.html?hp=t4_r|title=Clinton private email violated 'clear-cut' State Dept. rules|publisher=Politico.com|date=March 6, 2015|accessdate=April 1, 2015}}</ref>
In December 2012, near the end of Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State, a nonprofit group called [[Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington]], or CREW, filed a [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|FOIA]] request seeking records about her email. CREW received a response in May 2013: "no records responsive to your request were located."<ref name="washingtonpost.com">O'Harrow Jr., Robert. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/how-clintons-email-scandal-took-root/2016/03/27/ee301168-e162-11e5-846c-10191d1fc4ec_story.html "How Clinton's email scandal took root"], ''[[The Washington Post]]'''', March 27, 2016.</ref> Emails sent to Clinton's private clintonemail.com address were first discovered in March 2013, when a hacker named "[[Guccifer]]" widely distributed emails sent to Clinton from [[Sidney Blumenthal]], which Guccifer obtained by illegally accessing Blumenthal's email account.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|title=Hacker Begins Distributing Confidential Memos Sent To Hillary Clinton On Libya, Benghazi Attack|url=http://www.thesmokinggun.com/buster/sidney-blumenthal/hacker-distributes-memos-784091|website=The Smoking Gun|accessdate=September 30, 2015|date = March 18, 2013}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{cite web|title=Hacked Emails Show Hillary Clinton Was Receiving Advice at a Private Email Account From Banned, Obama-Hating Former Staffer |url=http://gawker.com/5991563/hacked-emails-show-hillary-clinton-was-receiving-advice-at-a-private-email-account-from-banned-obama-hating-former-staffer |accessdate=September 30, 2015 |first=John |last=Cook |website=Gawker |date=March 20, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001023951/http://gawker.com/5991563/hacked-emails-show-hillary-clinton-was-receiving-advice-at-a-private-email-account-from-banned-obama-hating-former-staffer |archivedate=October 1, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=":2">{{cite web|title='Guccifer' hacks Hillary Clinton's e-emails via aide's account|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2013/03/19/guccifer-hacker-hillary-clinton-sidney-blumenthal-george-hw-bush/2001429/|accessdate=September 30, 2015|website=USA Today|date=March 22, 2013|last=Acohido|first=Byron}}</ref> The emails dealt with the [[2012 Benghazi attack]] and other issues in [[Libya]] and revealed the existence of her clintonemail.com address.<ref name=":0"/><ref name=":1"/><ref name=":2"/>
Blumenthal did not have a security clearance when he received material from Clinton that has since been characterized as classified by the State Department.<ref>Gerstein, Josh. [http://www.politico.com/story/2015/10/hillary-clinton-sidney-blumenthal-emails-benghazi-hearings-215083 "Clinton's emails from Blumenthal spark tension"], [[Politico]] (October 22, 2015): "At least one [email] has been deemed classified by State, including information Clinton sent to Blumenthal, who had no security clearance."</ref><ref>Morrison, Micah. [https://nypost.com/2015/10/31/hillary-clintons-rogue-agenda-why-sid-blumenthal-matters/ "Hillary Clinton's rogue agenda: Why Sid Blumenthal matters"], ''[[New York Post]]'', October 31, 2015; "The November 2009 e-mail was sent by Wilson to Blumenthal, who passed it on to Clinton. Most of Clinton's reply to Blumenthal is redacted as classified."</ref>
In the summer of 2014, lawyers from the State Department noticed a number of emails from Clinton's personal account, while reviewing documents requested by the House Select Committee on Benghazi. A request by the State Department for additional emails led to negotiations with her lawyers and advisors. In October, the State Department sent letters to Clinton and all previous Secretaries of State back to [[Madeleine Albright]] requesting emails and documents related to their work while in office. On December 5, 2014, Clinton lawyers delivered 12 file boxes filled with printed paper containing more than 30,000 emails. Clinton withheld almost 32,000 emails deemed to be of a personal nature.<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/> Datto, Inc., which provided [[data backup]] service for Clinton's email, agreed to give the FBI the hardware that stored the backups.<ref name=WP10715>{{cite news|author1=Tom Hamburger |author2=Rosalind S. Helderman|title=FBI probe of Clinton e-mail expands to second data company|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/fbi-probe-of-clinton-e-mail-expands-to-second-data-company/2015/10/06/3d94ba46-6c48-11e5-b31c-d80d62b53e28_story.html|accessdate=October 7, 2015|work=The Washington Post|date=October 7, 2015}}</ref>
As of May 2016, no answer had been provided to the public as to whether 31,000 emails deleted by Hillary Clinton as personal have been or could be recovered.<ref>Emery, Eugene. [http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/apr/03/hillary-clinton/hillary-clinton-i-have-now-put-out-all-my-emails/ "Hillary Clinton spins on ‘Meet the Press,’ says she put out all her emails"], ''[[Politifact]]'' (April 3, 2016).</ref>
A March 2, 2015 ''[[New York Times]]'' article broke the story that the Benghazi panel had discovered that Clinton exclusively used her own private email server rather than a government-issued one throughout her time as Secretary of State, and that her aides took no action to preserve emails sent or received from her personal accounts as required by law.<ref name="MontanaroFactCheck" /><ref name="nytimes.com">Michael S. Schmidt, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/03/us/politics/hillary-clintons-use-of-private-email-at-state-department-raises-flags.html Hillary Clinton Used Personal Email Account at State Dept., Possibly Breaking Rules], ''The New York Times'', March 2, 2015.</ref><ref>Jack Gillum - "H [https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/ap-finds-hillary-clinton-used-private-server-official-email/ illary Clinton used private server for official email"], Associated Press, March 4, 2015. Retrieved November 14, 2016.</ref> At that point, Clinton announced that she had asked the State Department to release her emails.<ref name=NYT0315>{{cite news|author1=Schmidt, Michael S.|title=Hillary Clinton Asks State Department to Vet Emails for Release|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/06/us/politics/hillary-clinton-asks-state-dept-to-review-emails-for-public-release.html?ref=politics&_r=1|accessdate=November 5, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=March 5, 2015}}</ref> Some in the media labeled the controversy "emailgate."<ref>{{cite web|first=Anthony |last=Zurcher |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-31806907 |title=Hillary Clinton's 'emailgate' diced and sliced |publisher=BBC News |date=March 11, 2015 |archivedate=March 12, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150312173705/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-31806907 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Kurt |last=Eichenwald |url=http://www.newsweek.com/hillary-clinton-emailgate-312784 |title=Why Hillary Clinton's 'Emailgate' Is a Fake Scandal |work=Newsweek |date=March 3, 2015 |archive-date=March 10, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150310235140/http://www.newsweek.com/hillary-clinton-emailgate-312784 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Margaret |last=Hartmann |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2015/08/hillary-clinton-legal-emailgate.html |title=Could Hillary Clinton Face Criminal Charges Over Emailgate? |work=New York |date=August 21, 2015 |archive-date=November 3, 2016 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20161103202304/http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2015/08/hillary-clinton-legal-emailgate.html |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Use of private server for government business== According to Clinton's spokesperson Nick Merrill, a number of government officials have used private email accounts for official business, including secretaries of state before Clinton.<ref name="Los Angeles Times">{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/politics/politicsnow/la-pn-hillary-clinton-emails-20150303-story.html|title=Hillary Clinton's use of private email not unusual, but still raises questions|work=Los Angeles Times|date=March 3, 2015|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref>
State Department spokesperson [[Marie Harf]] said that: "For some historical context, Secretary [[John Kerry|Kerry]] is the first secretary of state to rely primarily on a state.gov email account."<ref name="MontanaroFactCheck">Domenico Montanaro, [https://www.npr.org/sections/itsallpolitics/2015/04/02/396823014/fact-check-hillary-clinton-those-emails-and-the-law Fact Check: Hillary Clinton, Those Emails and the Law], NPR (April 2, 2015).</ref> John Wonderlich, a transparency advocate with the [[Sunlight Foundation]], observed while many government officials used private email accounts, their use of private email servers was much rarer.<ref name=":3">{{cite web|title = Howard Dean: 'Tremendous' number of public officials have done what Hillary Clinton did with email|url = http://www.politifact.com/punditfact/statements/2015/aug/18/howard-dean/howard-dean-tremendous-number-public-officials-hav/|website = @politifact|access-date = February 9, 2016}}</ref>
Dan Metcalfe, a former head of the Justice Department's Office of Information and Privacy, said this gave her even tighter control over her emails by not involving a third party such as Google and helped prevent their disclosure by Congressional subpoena. He added: "She managed successfully to insulate her official emails, categorically, from the FOIA, both during her tenure at State and long after her departure from it—perhaps forever," making it "a blatant circumvention of the [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|FOIA]] by someone who unquestionably knows better."<ref name="MontanaroFactCheck" /><ref>{{cite web|title = Hillary's Email Defense Is Laughable|url = http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2015/03/hillary-clinton-email-scandal-defense-laughable-foia-116116|website = Politico.com|access-date = February 9, 2016}}</ref>
According to Harf, use by government officials of personal email for government business is permissible under the [[Federal Records Act]], so long as relevant official communications, including all work-related emails, are preserved by the agency. The Act (which was [[Presidential and Federal Records Act Amendments of 2014|amended in late 2014]] after Clinton left office to require that personal emails be transferred to government servers within 20 days) requires agencies to retain all official communications, including all work-related emails, and stipulates that government employees cannot destroy or remove relevant records.<ref name="MontanaroFactCheck"/> NARA regulations dictate how records should be created and maintained, require that they must be maintained "by the agency" and "readily found," and that the records must "make possible a proper scrutiny by the Congress."<ref name="MontanaroFactCheck"/> Section 1924 of [[Title 18 of the United States Code]] addresses the deletion and retention of classified documents, under which "knowingly" removing or housing classified information at an "unauthorized location" is subject to a fine, or up to a year in prison.<ref name="MontanaroFactCheck"/>
Experts such as Metcalfe agree that these practices are allowed by federal law assuming that the material is not supposed to be classified,<ref name="Los Angeles Times"/><ref>{{cite web|author1=Bob Cusack |author2=Molly K. Hooper|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/237012-the-backer-who-could-hurt-hillary|title=The Hillary backer who will pose problems for her 2016 bid|newspaper=The Hill|date=March 26, 2015}}</ref> or at least these practices are allowed in case of emergencies,<ref name="nytimes.com"/> but they discourage these practices, believing that official email accounts should be used.<ref name="MontanaroFactCheck"/>
Jason R. Baron, the former head of [[litigation]] at NARA, described the practice as "highly unusual" but not a violation of the law. In a separate interview, he said, "It is very difficult to conceive of a scenario—short of nuclear winter—where an agency would be justified in allowing its cabinet-level head officer to solely use a private email communications channel for the conduct of government business."<ref name="nytimes.com"/><ref>Merica, Dan.[https://twitter.com/danmericaCNN/status/572842630855430145 Report via CNN Tweet (March 3, 2015), "Jason Baron, former head of litigation at the NARA, says Clinton didn't 'violate' the law. 'The Federal Records Act is amorphous enough.'"]</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Seitz-Wald|first=Alex|url=http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/hillary-clinton-email-problem-not-going-away|title=Hillary Clinton's email problem is not going away|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|date=March 4, 2015|accessdate=May 24, 2015}}</ref> Baron told the Senate Judiciary Committee in May 2015 that "any employee's decision to conduct all email correspondence through a private email network, using a non-''.gov'' address, is inconsistent with long-established policies and practices under the Federal Records Act and NARA regulations governing all federal agencies."<ref>{{cite news|author=Eugene Kiely|url=http://www.factcheck.org/2015/09/more-spin-on-clinton-emails|title=More Spin on Clinton Emails|publisher=FactCheck.org|date=September 8, 2015}}</ref>
=== May 2016 report from State Department's inspector general === In May 2016, [[Office of the Inspector General of the Department of State|the Department's Office]] of the [[Inspector General of the Department of State|Inspector General]] [[Steve Linick]] released an 83-page report about the State Department's email practices.<ref name="IGReportPractices" /><ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/apps/g/page/politics/state-department-report-on-clintons-email-practices/2039/?tid=a_inl Office of the Secretary: Evaluation of Email Records Management and Cybersecurity Requirements], Office of the Inspector General of the U.S. Department of State and Broadcasting Board of Governors (May 2016) (republished by ''The Washington Post'').</ref><ref>Morello, Carol and Yang, Jia. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2016/05/25/here-are-the-most-critical-parts-of-the-state-dept-inspector-general-report-on-clintons-email-use/?tid=a_inl Here are the most critical parts of the State Department inspector general report on Clinton’s email use], ''The Washington Post'', May 25, 2016.</ref> The Inspector General was unable to find evidence that Clinton had ever sought approval from the State Department staff for her use of a private email server, determining that if Clinton had sought approval, Department staff would have declined her setup because of the "security risks in doing so."<ref name="IGReportPractices"/> Aside from security risks, the report stated that "she did not comply with the Department's policies that were implemented in accordance with the Federal Records Act."<ref>Dilanian, Ken. [http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/clinton-broke-federal-rules-email-server-audit-finds-n580131 "Clinton Broke Federal Rules With Email Server, Audit Finds"], [[NBC News]], May 25, 2016.</ref> Each of these findings contradicted what Clinton and her aides had been saying up to that point.<ref>Lerer, Lisa; Lucey, Catherine. "[https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/ap-fact-check-some-clinton-email-misstatements/ AP Fact Check: Some Clinton email misstatements]". Associated Press. Public Broadcasting System. May 31, 2016.</ref><ref>Carroll, Lauren. [http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/may/31/hillary-clinton/fact-checking-hillary-clintons-claim-her-email-pra "Fact-checking Hillary Clinton's claim that her email practices were 'allowed'"], Polifact, May 31, 2016.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2016/05/ig-report-on-clintons-emails/|title=IG Report on Clinton's Emails| publisher=factcheck.org|author=Kieley, Eugene|date=27 May 2016|accessdate=21 November 2018}}</ref> The report also stated that Clinton and her senior aides declined to speak with the investigators, while the previous four Secretaries of State did so.<ref name="IGReportPractices"/>
The report also reviewed the practices of several previous Secretaries of State and concluded that the Department's record keeping practices were subpar for many years.<ref name="IGReportPractices"/> The Inspector General criticized Clinton's use of private email for Department business, concluding that it was "not an appropriate method" of document preservation and did not follow Department policies that aim to comply with federal record laws. The report also criticized Colin Powell, who used a personal email account for business, saying that this violated some of the same Department policies.<ref name="IGReportPractices"/> State Department spokesman Mark Toner said the report emphasized the need for federal agencies to adapt "decades-old record-keeping practices to the email-dominated modern era" and said that the Department's record-retention practices had been improved under the current Secretary of State [[John F. Kerry]], Clinton's successor.<ref name="IGReportPractices"/> The report also notes that the rules for preserving work-related emails were updated in 2009.<ref>Browne, Ryan and Evan Perez. [http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/25/politics/state-department-report-faults-clinton-over-email-use/ “State Department report slams Clinton email use”], [[CNN]], May 25, 2016: "while the report acknowledges personal email use by previous secretaries, it also notes that the rules for preserving work emails sent from a personal email account were updated in 2009, the year Clinton took office".</ref>
Inspector General Linick wrote that he "found no evidence that staff in the Office of the Legal Adviser reviewed or approved Secretary Clinton's personal system," and also found that multiple State employees who raised concerns regarding Clinton's server were told that the Office of the Legal Adviser had approved it, and were further told to "never speak of the Secretary's personal email system again."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/5/25/11771850/hillary-clinton-emails-inspector-general-report|title=What the new inspector general report on Hillary Clinton's emails actually says|author=Andrew Prokop|date=May 25, 2016|work=Vox}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/26/opinions/clinton-email-server-ig-report-opinion-cox/|title=Hillary Clinton's shrinking email defense|author=Douglas Cox|date=May 26, 2016|publisher=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2016/05/state-department-hillary-clinton-violated-record-keeping-rules|title=State Department Inspector General Finds Hillary Clinton Violated Recordkeeping Rules|work=Mother Jones}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/26/us/politics/state-department-hillary-clinton-emails.html|title=Hillary Clinton Is Criticized for Private Emails in State Dept. Review|date=May 26, 2016|work=The New York Times}}</ref>
Clinton campaign spokesman [[Brian Fallon (press secretary)|Brian Fallon]] issued a statement saying: "The report shows that problems with the State Department's electronic record-keeping systems were long-standing" and that Clinton "took steps that went much further than others to appropriately preserve and release her records."<ref name="IGReportPractices" /> However, the Associated Press said, "The audit did note that former Secretary of State Colin Powell had also exclusively used a private email account. ... But the failings of Clinton were singled out in the audit as being more serious than her predecessor."<ref name="APMay26Report">{{cite web|authors=Michael Biesecker & Bradley Klapper|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/e9cf125b8af1417a8cdd0b3526a1ce9e/apnewsbreak-state-dept-audit-faults-clinton-emails|title=Clinton email use broke federal rules: inspector's report|agency=Associated Press|date=May 26, 2016}}</ref> The report stated that "By Secretary Clinton's tenure, the department's guidance was considerably more detailed and more sophisticated, Secretary Clinton's cybersecurity practices accordingly must be evaluated in light of these more comprehensive directives."<ref name="APMay26Report" />
== Server security and hacking attempts ==
===Encryption and security=== In 2008, before Hillary Clinton became Secretary of State, [[Justin Cooper (aide)|Justin Cooper]], a longtime aide to Clinton's husband, former President [[Bill Clinton]], managed the system. Cooper had no security clearance nor expertise in computer security.<ref name=WP0804>Carol D. Leonnig, Rosalind S. Helderman & Tom Hamburger, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/fbi-looks-into-security-of-clintons-private-e-mail-setup/2015/08/04/2bdd85ec-3aae-11e5-8e98-115a3cf7d7ae_story.html FBI Looking into the Security of Hillary Clinton's Private e-mail Setup], ''The Washington Post'', August 4, 2015.</ref> Later, Bryan Pagliano, the former IT director for Clinton's 2008 presidential campaign, was hired to maintain their private email server while Clinton was Secretary of State.<ref name=WP0901>Helderman, Rosalind S. & Carol D. Leonnig, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/clintons-personally-paid-state-department-staffer-to-maintain-server/2015/09/04/b13ab23e-530c-11e5-9812-92d5948a40f8_story.html "Clintons personally paid State Department staffer to maintain server"], ''The Washington Post'', September 5, 2015.</ref><ref name=Joseph0901>Joseph, Cameron.[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/hillary-clinton-won-apologize-private-email-server-article-1.2348855 Hillary Clinton 'takes responsibility' for email controversy, but won't apologize for using private server], ''Daily News'' (New York), September 5, 2015.</ref> Pagliano had invoked the [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth Amendment]] during congressional questioning about Clinton's server. In early 2016, he was granted immunity by the Department of Justice in exchange for cooperation with prosecutors.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Perez|first1=Evan|title=DOJ grants immunity to ex-Clinton staffer who set up email server|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/02/politics/hillary-clinton-email-server-justice-department/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=March 2, 2016|date=March 2, 2016}}</ref> A Clinton spokesman said her campaign was "pleased" Pagliano was now cooperating with prosecutors.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/in-clinton-email-investigation-justice-department-grants-immunity-to-former-state-department-staffer/2016/03/02/e421e39e-e0a0-11e5-9c36-e1902f6b6571_story.html|title=Justice Dept. grants immunity to staffer who set up Clinton email server|last=Goldman|first=Adam|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=March 2, 2016|accessdate=March 3, 2016}}</ref> As of May 2016, the State Department remained unable to locate most of Pagliano's work-related emails from the period when he was employed by that department under Secretary Clinton.<ref>Fishel, Justin. [http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/emails-found-hillary-clintons-senior-staffer-state-department/story?id=38989504 "Emails From Hillary Clinton’s IT Director at State Department Appear to Be Missing"], ''[[ABC News]]'', May 9, 2016.</ref>
Security experts such as [[Chris Soghoian]] believe that emails to and from Clinton may have been at risk of [[Hacker (computer security)|hacking]] and [[Computer and network surveillance|foreign surveillance]].<ref name="Greenberg"/> [[Marc Maiffret]], a cybersecurity expert, said that the server had "amateur hour" vulnerabilities.<ref name=AP1013/> For the first two months after Clinton was appointed Secretary of State and began accessing mail on the server through her BlackBerry, transmissions to and from the server were apparently not encrypted. On March 29, 2009, a [[Public key certificate|digital certificate]] was obtained which would have permitted encryption.<ref name="WP032716"/>
Former [[Director of the Defense Intelligence Agency]] [[Michael T. Flynn]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://video.foxnews.com/v/4157397774001/michael-flynn-weighs-in-on-hillary-clinton-email-controversy/?#sp=show-clips/primetime|title=Michael Flynn weighs in on Hillary Clinton email controversy|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=April 6, 2015}}</ref> former [[United States Secretary of Defense]] [[Robert Gates]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/266674-former-defense-secretary-says-clinton-server-may-have-been-compromised|title=Ex-Pentagon chief: Iran, China or Russia may have gotten to Clinton server|work=TheHill}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://theweek.com/speedreads/600728/did-russia-read-hillary-clintons-emails-robert-gates-says-odds-are-pretty-high|title=Did Russia read Hillary Clinton's emails? Robert Gates says the odds are 'pretty high'|publisher=theweek.com}}</ref> and former deputy director of the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] [[Michael Morell]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/05/michael-morrell-foreign-governments-have-hillarys-email-118007|title=Hillary Clinton emails: Former CIA head says foreign governments have access|newspaper=Politico}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.commentarymagazine.com/politics-ideas/hillary-clinton-email-scandal-victim|title=Hillary's Tell-Tale Server|author=Noah Rothman|magazine=Commentary Magazine}}</ref> have said that it is likely that foreign governments were able to access the information on Clinton's server. [[Michael Hayden (general)|Michael Hayden]], former [[Director of the National Security Agency]], Principal Deputy [[Director of National Intelligence]], and [[Director of the Central Intelligence Agency]] said "I would lose all respect for a whole bunch of foreign intelligence agencies if they weren't sitting back, paging through the emails."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2016/02/21/ex-nsa-chief-backs-apple-iphone-back-doors/80660024/|title=Ex-NSA chief backs Apple on iPhone 'back doors'|date=February 21, 2016|newspaper=USA Today}}</ref>
===Hacking attempts=== Clinton's server was configured to allow users to connect openly from the Internet and control it remotely using Microsoft's [[Remote Desktop Services]].<ref name=AP1013>{{cite news|author1=Jack Gillum |author2=Stephen Braun|title=Exclusive: Clinton server's software had hacking risk|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/467ff78858bf4dde8db21677deeff101/only-ap-clinton-server-ran-software-risked-hacking|accessdate=October 13, 2015|agency=Associated Press|date=October 13, 2015}}</ref>
It is known that hackers were aware of Clinton's non-public email address as early as 2011.<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/news/russian-hackers-tried-to-infiltrate-hillary-clintons-emails/ "Hackers linked to Russia tried to infiltrate Hillary Clinton's emails"], [[CBS News]] (September 30, 2015): "these messages show hackers had Clinton's email address, which was not public. ... "</ref> Secretary Clinton and her staff were aware of hacking attempts in 2011, and were reportedly worried about them.<ref>Gerstein, Josh. [http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/clinton-email-problems-223573 "Why Clinton’s email problems are here to stay"], ''[[Politico]]'', May 25, 2016.</ref>
In 2012, according to server records, a hacker in [[Serbia]] scanned Clinton's Chappaqua server at least twice, in August and in December 2012. It was unclear whether the hacker knew the server belonged to Clinton, although it did identify itself as providing email services for clintonemail.com.<ref name=AP1013/> During 2014, Clinton's server was the target of repeated intrusions originating in Germany, China, and South Korea. Threat monitoring software on the server blocked at least five such attempts. The software was installed in October 2013, and for three months prior to that, no such software had been installed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2015/10/08/clinton-server-hack-attempts-came-from-china-korea-germany/ADRRitdZev3O1FhIFQT1SP/story.html|title=Sources of attempts to hack Clinton's e-mail server ID'd|accessdate=February 21, 2016|author1=Ken Dilanian |author2=Jack Gillum}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/5ad0f6bb57eb487f84e98fe9a74a08b1/clinton-subject-hack-attempts-china-korea-germany|title=Clinton subject to hack attempts from China, Korea, Germany|agency=Associated Press}}</ref>
According to Pagliano, security logs of Clinton's email server showed no evidence of successful hacking.<ref name="nyt-apuzzo">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/04/us/politics/security-logs-of-hillary-clintons-email-server-are-said-to-show-no-evidence-of-hacking.html | title=Security Logs of Hillary Clinton's Email Server Are Said to Show No Evidence of Hacking | last=Apuzzo|first=Matt|newspaper=The New York Times| date=March 3, 2016 | accessdate=March 6, 2016}}</ref> The ''New York Times'' reported that "forensic experts can sometimes spot sophisticated hacking that is not apparent in the logs, but computer security experts view logs as key documents when detecting hackers," adding the logs "bolster Mrs. Clinton's assertion that her use of a personal email account ... did not put American secrets into the hands of hackers or foreign governments."<ref name="Greenberg">Andy Greenberg, [https://www.wired.com/2015/03/clintons-email-server-vulnerable Why Clinton's Private Email Server Was Such a Security Failure], ''Wired'', March 4, 2015.</ref><ref name="nyt-apuzzo"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/live-from-boulder/2015/10/2016-presidential-debate-hillary-clinton-emails-215291|title=Debate fact check: No evidence Clinton's server was hacked|last=Marks|first=Joseph|newspaper='[[Politico]]|date=October 28, 2015|accessdate=March 2, 2016}}</ref>
In 2013, [[Romanian people|Romanian]] hacker Marcel Lehel Lazăr (aka "[[Guccifer]]") distributed private memos from [[Sidney Blumenthal]] to Clinton on [[Libyan Civil War (2011)|events in Libya]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thesmokinggun.com/buster/sidney-blumenthal/hacker-distributes-memos-784091|title=Hacker Begins Distributing Confidential Memos Sent To Hillary Clinton On Libya, Benghazi Attack|date=March 18, 2013|publisher=The Smoking Gun|accessdate=March 20, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.propublica.org/article/private-emails-reveal-ex-clinton-aides-secret-spy-network|title=Private Emails Reveal Ex-Clinton Aide's Secret Spy Network|date=March 27, 2015|publisher=ProPublica|accessdate=June 11, 2016}}</ref> In 2016, Lazăr was extradited from Romania to the U.S. to face unrelated federal charges related to his hacking into the accounts of a number of high-profile U.S. figures,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-guccifer-idUSKCN0WY5MK|title=Hacker 'Guccifer' extradited from Romania, appears in U.S. court|date=April 1, 2016|accessdate=June 11, 2016|agency=Reuters}}</ref> pleading guilty to these charges.<ref>Catherine Herridge & Pamela K. Browne. [http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2016/05/25/hacker-who-claims-breached-clinton-server-pleads-guilty-strikes-deal-with-feds.html Hacker who claims he breached Clinton server pleads guilty, strikes deal with feds], Fox News (May 25, 2016).</ref><ref>Hosenball, Mark. [https://www.reuters.com/article/us-clinton-emails-hacker-idUSKCN0YF2KZ "Hacker who exposed Hillary Clinton's email server expected to plead guilty"], Reuters.com, May 24, 2016.</ref> While detained pending trial, Lazăr claimed to the media that he had successfully hacked Clinton's server, but provided no proof of this claim.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2016/05/04/us/politics/ap-us-clinton-email.html|title=US Judge: Clinton May Be Ordered to Testify in Records Case|date=May 4, 2016|accessdate=November 14, 2016|agency=Associated Press}}</ref> Officials associated with the investigation told the media that they found no evidence supporting Lazăr's assertion,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/federal-prosecutors-in-virginia-assisting-in-clinton-email-probe/2016/05/05/f0277faa-12f0-11e6-81b4-581a5c4c42df_story.html|title=Officials: Scant evidence that Clinton had malicious intent in handling of emails|date=May 5, 2016|accessdate=May 6, 2016|work=The Washington Post|last=Zapotosky|first=Matt}}</ref> and Clinton press secretary [[Brian Fallon (press secretary)|Brian Fallon]] said "There is absolutely no basis to believe the claims made by this criminal from his prison cell."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/hacker-guccifer-i-got-inside-hillary-clinton-s-server-n568206|title=Hacker 'Guccifer': I Got Inside Hillary Clinton's Server|author=Cynthia McFadden|publisher=NBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2016/05/04/romanian-hacker-guccifer-breached-clinton-server-it-was-easy.html?intcmp=hpbt1|title=Romanian hacker Guccifer: I breached Clinton server, 'it was easy'|author=Catherine Herridge, Pamela K. Browne|publisher=Fox News Channel}}</ref> FBI Director James Comey later stated in a congressional hearing that Guccifer admitted his claim was a lie.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/fbi-director-set-to-appear-before-congressional-committee-to-answer-questions-on-clinton-investigation/2016/07/07/eb43ec7e-43c1-11e6-88d0-6adee48be8bc_story.html?tid=sm_fb|last=Zapotosky|first=Matt|title=House Republicans grill FBI director Comey on Clinton emails|work=The Washington Post|date=July 7, 2016|accessdate=July 13, 2016}}</ref>
According to security researchers at [[Secureworks]] the email leak was caused by Threat Group-4127 (TG-4127), a unit that targets governments, military, and international non-governmental organizations. The researchers report moderate confidence that the unit gathers intelligence on behalf of the Russian government.<ref name="secureworks.com">{{Cite web|url=https://www.secureworks.com/research/threat-group-4127-targets-hillary-clinton-presidential-campaign|title=Hillary Clinton Email Targeted by Threat Group-4127|publisher=secureworks.com|access-date=2017-10-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160720175418/https://www.secureworks.com/research/threat-group-4127-targets-hillary-clinton-presidential-campaign#|archive-date=July 20, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Deletion of emails==
In 2014, months prior to public knowledge of the server's existence, Clinton chief of staff [[Cheryl Mills]] and two attorneys worked to identify work-related emails on the server to be archived and preserved for the State Department. Upon completion of this task in December 2014, Mills instructed Clinton's computer services provider, Platte River Networks (PRN), to change the server's [[retention period]] to 60 days, allowing 31,830 older personal emails to be automatically deleted from the server, as Clinton had decided she no longer needed them. However, the PRN technician assigned for this task failed to carry it out at that time.<ref name="factcheck.org">{{cite web|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2016/09/the-fbi-files-on-clintons-emails/|title=The FBI Files on Clinton's Emails - FactCheck.org|date=September 7, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=August 30, 2018}}</ref>
After the existence of the server became publicly known on March 2, 2015,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/03/us/politics/hillary-clintons-use-of-private-email-at-state-department-raises-flags.html|title=Hillary Clinton Used Personal Email Account at State Dept., Possibly Breaking Rules|publisher=|accessdate=August 30, 2018}}</ref> the [[Select Committee on Benghazi]] issued a subpoena for Benghazi-related emails two days later. Mills sent an email to PRN on March 9 mentioning the Committee's retention request.<ref name="factcheck.org"/> The PRN technician then had what he described to the FBI as an "oh shit moment," realizing he had not set the personal emails to be deleted as instructed months earlier. The technician then erased the emails using a free utility, [[BleachBit]], sometime between March 25 and March 31.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/03/us/politics/hillary-clinton-fbi.html|title=F.B.I. Papers Offer Closer Look at Hillary Clinton Email Inquiry|publisher=|accessdate=August 30, 2018}}</ref>
Since this episode, Clinton critics have accused her or her aides of deleting emails that were under subpoena, alleging the server had been "bleached" or "acid-washed" by a "very expensive" process<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2016/09/trump-pence-acid-wash-facts/|title=Trump, Pence 'Acid Wash' Facts - FactCheck.org|date=September 8, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=August 30, 2018}}</ref> in an effort to destroy evidence, with candidate Donald Trump stating the day before the 2016 election that "Hillary Clinton erased more than 30,000 emails as part of a cover-up."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://factba.se/search#30,000+emails|title=Donald Trump Complete - Search Tweets, Speeches, Policies - Factbase|first=|last=Factbase|website=Factbase|accessdate=August 30, 2018}}</ref> Trump continued with this narrative as late as August 2018, asking "Look at the crimes that Clinton did with the emails and she deletes 33,000 emails after she gets a subpoena from Congress, and this Justice Department does nothing about it?"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://factba.se/search#emails|title=Donald Trump Complete - Search Tweets, Speeches, Policies - Factbase|first=|last=Factbase|website=Factbase|accessdate=August 30, 2018}}</ref>
==Classified information in emails== In various interviews, Clinton has said that "I did not send classified material, and I did not receive any material that was marked or designated classified."<ref name=Allen0821 /> However, in June and July 2016, a number of news outlets reported that Clinton's emails did include messages with some paragraphs marked with a "(c)" for "Confidential."<ref name="BBC20160705">{{cite news|author=Staff|title=FBI recommends no charges against Hillary Clinton over emails|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-36711711|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=July 5, 2016|accessdate=November 14, 2016|quote=But investigators found that a number of messages that were marked classified at the time were sent from her account.}}</ref><ref name="FoxNews2016-06-11">{{cite news|last1=Herridge|first1=Catherine|last2=Browne|first2=Pamela K.|date=June 11, 2016|title=Despite Clinton claims, 2012 email had classified marking|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2016/06/11/despite-clinton-claims-2012-email-had-classified-marking.html|publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]|accessdate=June 13, 2016}}</ref> The FBI investigation found that 110 messages contained information that was classified at the time it was sent. Sixty-five of those emails were found to contain information classified as "Secret;" more than 20 contained "Top-Secret" information.<ref name="PolitiFact2016-07-06">{{cite news|last=Carroll|first=Lauren|date=July 5, 2016|title=FBI investigation undermines Clinton email defense|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/article/2016/jul/05/fbi-investigation-undermines-clinton-email-defense|newspaper=[[PolitiFact]]|accessdate=July 5, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Wapo-2016-07-05">{{cite news|last=Cillizza|first=Chris|date=July 5, 2016|title=Hillary Clinton's email problems might be even worse than we thought|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/07/05/hillary-clintons-email-problems-might-be-even-worse-than-we-thought|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=July 5, 2016}}</ref> Three emails, out of 30,000, were found to be marked as classified, although they lacked classified headers and were only marked with a small "c" in parentheses, described as "portion markings" by Comey.
