He added it was possible Clinton was not "technically sophisticated" enough to understand what the three classified markings meant<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/fbi-director-james-comey-hillary-clinton-email-probe/story?id=41044927|title=What FBI Director James Comey Really Said About Hillary Clinton Email Probe|publisher=ABC News|date=August 2, 2016|accessdate=September 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://video.cnbc.com/gallery/?video=3000548237|title=Clinton not technically sophisticated: FBI interview|publisher=CNBC|accessdate=September 7, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Kiely">{{cite web|url=http://www.factcheck.org/2016/07/revisiting-clinton-and-classified-information|title=Revisiting Clinton and Classified Information|last=Kiely|first=Eugene|date=July 7, 2016|accessdate=July 22, 2016|publisher=Factcheck.org}}</ref> which is consistent with Clinton's claim that she wasn't aware of the meaning of such markings.<ref name="BusinessInsider20160902">{{cite news|author=Pamela Engel|title=Hillary Clinton said she didn't know what the 'C' markings in emails stood for|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/hillary-clinton-fbi-report-classified-markings-2016-9|publisher=[[Business Insider]]|date=September 2, 2016|accessdate=September 16, 2018|quote=Hillary Clinton told investigators that she wasn't aware that a "C" marking in emails she received on her private server indicated that the information was classified }}</ref>
Clinton personally wrote 104 of the 2,093 emails that were retroactively<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/clinton-on-her-private-server-wrote-104-emails-the-government-says-are-classified/2016/03/05/11e2ee06-dbd6-11e5-81ae-7491b9b9e7df_story.html|title=Clinton, on her private server, wrote 104 emails the government says are classified|first1=Rosalind S.|last1=Helderman|first2=Tom|last2=Hamburger|date=March 5, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=April 21, 2018|via=www.washingtonpost.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/jul/06/hillary-clinton/fbi-findings-tear-holes-hillary-clintons-email-def/|title=FBI tears holes in Hillary Clinton's email defense|publisher=|accessdate=April 21, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/article/2016/jul/19/politifact-sheet-hillary-clintons-email-controvers/|title=The GOP's opening over Hillary Clinton's email|publisher=|accessdate=April 21, 2018}}</ref> found to contain information classified as "confidential."<ref name="IGReportPractices">Helderman, Rosalind and Hamburger, Tom. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/state-dept-inspector-general-report-sharply-criticizes-clintons-email-practices/2016/05/25/fc6f8ebc-2275-11e6-aa84-42391ba52c91_story.html State Dept. inspector general report sharply criticizes Clinton's email practices], ''The Washington Post'', May 25, 2016.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/clinton-on-her-private-server-wrote-104-emails-the-government-says-are-classified/2016/03/05/11e2ee06-dbd6-11e5-81ae-7491b9b9e7df_story.html|title=Clinton, on her private server, wrote 104 emails the government says are classified|author=Rosalind S. Helderman|date=March 5, 2016|work=The Washington Post}}</ref> Of the remaining emails that were classified after they were sent, Clinton aide [[Jake Sullivan]] wrote the most, at 215.<ref name="auto1"/>
According to the State Department, there were 2,093 email chains on the server that were retroactively marked as classified by the State Department as "Confidential," 65 as "Secret," and 22 as "Top Secret."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/01/us/politics/last-batch-of-hillary-clintons-emails-is-released.html|title=Last Batch of Hillary Clinton's Emails Is Released|date=March 1, 2016|work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2016-02-29/state-dept-wins-dispute-over-clinton-email-on-north-korea|title=State Dept completes Clinton email release, more than 52k out including 2,100 with info now deemed classified|last=Klapper|first=Bradley|date=February 29, 2016|newspaper=U.S. News and World Report|accessdate=March 1, 2016|last2=Lee|first2=Matthew}}</ref> TG-4127 accessed Hillary for America Campaign Gmail accounts through spoofed login pages. Victims thought they were standard pages and hackers were able to access their email account.<ref name="secureworks.com"/>{{third-party inline|date=October 2017}}
===State Department inspector general reports and statements=== A June 29, 2015, memorandum from the Inspector General of the State Department, Steve A. Linick, said that a review of the 55,000-page email release found "hundreds of potentially classified emails."<ref name=CNN3>Labott, Elise.[http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/24/politics/hillary-clinton-email-justice-department "Clinton emails Included Classified Information"], CNN, July 24, 2015.</ref> A July 17, 2015, follow-up memo, sent jointly by Linick and the [[United States Intelligence Community|Intelligence Community]] (IC) inspector general, I. Charles McCullough III, to [[Under Secretary of State for Management]] [[Patrick F. Kennedy]], stated that they had confirmed that several of the emails contained classified information that was not marked as classified, at least one of which was publicly released.<ref name=CNN3/>
On July 24, 2015, Linick and McCullough said they had discovered classified information on Clinton's email account,<ref name=NYT72415>{{cite news|author1=Michael S. Schmidt |author2=Matt Apuzzo|title=Hillary Clinton Emails Said to Contain Classified Data|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/25/us/politics/hillary-clinton-email-classified-information-inspector-general-intelligence-community.html|accessdate=July 25, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=July 24, 2015}}</ref> but did not say whether Clinton sent or received the emails.<ref name=NYT72415/> Investigators from their office, searching a randomly chosen sample of 40 emails, found four that contained classified information that originated from U.S. intelligence agencies, including the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) and the National Security Agency (NSA).<ref name=NYT72415/> Their statement said that the information they found was classified when sent, remained so as of their inspection, and "never should have been transmitted via an unclassified personal system."<ref name=NYT72415/>
In a separate statement in the form of a letter to Congress, McCullough said that he had made a request to the State Department for access to the entire set of emails turned over by Clinton, but that the Department rejected his request.<ref name=NYT72415/><ref name=WSJ3>Byron Tau, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/investigation-sought-into-hillary-clintons-emails-1437714369 Hillary Clinton Sent Classified Information Over Email While at State Department], ''The Wall Street Journal'', July 24, 2015.</ref> The letter stated that none of the emails were marked as classified, but because they included classified information they should have been marked and handled as such, and transmitted securely.<ref name=WSJ3/>
On August 10, 2015, the IC inspector general said that two of the 40 emails in the sample were "Top Secret/[[Sensitive Compartmented Information]]" and subsequently given classified labels of "TK" (for "Talent Keyhole," indicating material obtained by aerial or space-based imagery sources and [[NOFORN]]).<ref name=AP81415 /> One is a discussion of a news article about a [[Drone strikes in Pakistan|U.S. drone strike operation]].<ref name=AP81415/> The second, he said, either referred to classified material or else was "parallel reporting" of [[open-source intelligence]], which might still be classified by the government "owning agency" that sourced the information by secret means even though the same information was also available in the public domain.<ref name=AP81415/><ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|title=US State Department 'Top secret' emails on Clinton server discussed drone program, reference classified info.|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2015/08/14/top-secret-emails-on-clinton-server-discussed-drone-program-may-reference/?intcmp=ob_article_footer_text&intcmp=obinsite|accessdate=August 24, 2015|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=August 14, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/06/us/politics/agencies-battle-over-what-is-top-secret-in-hillary-clintons-emails.html|title=Agencies Battle Over What Is 'Top Secret' in Hillary Clinton's Emails|date=February 5, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=April 21, 2018|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> Clinton's presidential campaign and the State Department disputed the letter, and questioned whether the emails had been over-classified by an arbitrary process. According to an unnamed source, a secondary review by the CIA and the [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency]] endorsed the earlier inspectors general findings concluding that the emails (one of which concerned North Korea's nuclear weapons program) were "Top Secret" when received by Clinton through her private server in 2009 and 2011, a conclusion also disputed by the Clinton campaign.<ref>Schmidt, Michael S. [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/08/us/politics/second-review-says-classified-information-was-in-hillary-clintons-email.html "Second Review Says Classified Information Was in Hillary Clinton's Email"] ''The New York Times'', September 7, 2015.</ref>
The IC inspector general issued another letter to Congress on January 14, 2016. In this letter he stated that an unnamed intelligence agency had made a sworn declaration that "several dozen emails [had been] determined by the IC element to be at the CONFIDENTIAL, SECRET, and TOP SECRET/[[Special access program|SAP]] levels." Other intelligence officials added that the several dozen were not the two emails from the previous sample and that the clearance of the IC inspector general himself had to be upgraded before he could learn about the programs referenced by the emails.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Hillary Clinton Email Said to Include Material Exceeding 'Top Secret'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/20/us/politics/hillary-clinton-email-said-to-include-material-exceeding-top-secret.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=January 19, 2016|accessdate=January 20, 2016|issn=0362-4331|first=Mark|last=Mazzetti}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hillary Clinton Emails Held Info Beyond Top Secret: IG|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/hillary-clinton-emails-contained-info-above-top-secret-ig-n499886|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=January 20, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Intelligence community watchdog reconfirms that dozens of Clinton emails were classified|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/01/19/intelligence-community-watchdog-reconfirms-that-dozens-of-clinton-emails-were-classified|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=January 19, 2016|accessdate=January 20, 2016|issn=0190-8286|first=Rosalind S.|last=Helderman|first2=Tom|last2=Hamburger}}</ref> NBC News reported on January 20, 2016 that senior American officials described these emails as "innocuous" because—although they discussed the CIA drone program that is technically classified TOP SECRET/[[Special access program|SAP]]—the existence of the CIA drone program had been widely known and discussed in the public domain for years. These officials characterized the IC inspector general as unfair in how he had handled the issue.<ref name="nbcnews.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/officials-new-top-secret-clinton-emails-innocuous-n500586|title=Officials: New Top Secret Clinton Emails 'Innocuous'|publisher=|accessdate=April 21, 2018}}</ref>
On January 29, 2016, the State Department announced that 22 documents from Clinton's email server would not be released because they contained highly classified information that was too sensitive for public consumption. At the same time, the State Department announced that it was initiating its own investigation into whether the server contained information that was classified at the time it was sent or received.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Byron Tau|title=State Department: 22 of Hillary Clinton's Emails Considered Too Classified to Release|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/state-department-says-22-of-clintons-emails-contain-highly-classified-information-1454101286|accessdate=February 1, 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=January 29, 2016}}</ref>
In February 2016, State Department IG Linick addressed another report to Under Secretary of State Kennedy, stating his office had also found classified material in 10 emails in the personal email accounts of members of former Secretary [[Condoleezza Rice]]'s staff and in two emails in the personal email account of former Secretary of State [[Colin Powell]].<ref name="PowellRice">{{cite news|authors=Jose Pagliery, Deirdre Walsh and Elise Labott|title=State Department: Colin Powell, Condoleezza Rice staffers received classified info via personal email|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/02/04/politics/hillary-clinton-email-classified-colin-powell-condoleezza-rice/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=February 9, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnn/2016/images/02/04/memo.pdf|title=Memorandum for Under Secretary Kennedy|date=February 3, 2016|last=Linick|first=Steve}}</ref> None of the emails were classified for intelligence reasons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/secretaries-handled-classified-material-private-email-state-dept/story?id=37404084|title=Other Secretaries Handled Classified Material on Private Email, State Dept. Concludes|publisher=ABC News}}</ref> PolitiFact found a year earlier that Powell was the only former secretary of state to use a personal email account.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fact-checking Chuck Schumer's defense of Hillary Clinton's private email|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2015/mar/08/charles-schumer/fact-checking-chuck-schumers-defense-hillary-clint|website=PolitiFact|accessdate=February 10, 2016}}</ref> In February 2016, Clinton's campaign chairman issued a statement claiming that her emails, like her predecessors,' were "being inappropriately subjected to over-classification."<ref name="PowellRice"/>
===FBI investigation=== ====July 2015 – Security referral==== The State Department and [[United States Intelligence Community|Intelligence Community]] (IC) inspector generals' discovery of four emails containing classified information, out of a random sample of 40, prompted them to make a security referral to the FBI's counterintelligence office, to alert authorities that classified information was being kept on Clinton's server and by her lawyer on a [[USB flash drive|thumb drive]].<ref name=NYT72415 /><ref name=WSJ3/> As part of an FBI probe at the request of the IC [[inspector general]], Clinton agreed to turn over her email server to the [[U.S. Department of Justice]], as well as thumb drives containing copies of her work-related emails. Other emails were obtained by the [[United States House Select Committee on Benghazi]] from other sources, in connection with the committee's inquiry. Clinton's own emails are being made public in stages by the State Department on a gradual schedule.<ref>{{cite web|title=House GOP split over Clinton email probe|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/11/hillary-clinton-emails-republicans-server-congress-215498|publisher=Politico|accessdate=November 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/06/tracking-the-clinton-controversies-from-whitewater-to-benghazi/396182|title=From Whitewater to Benghazi: A Clinton-Scandal Primer|work=David A. Graham|date=June 10, 2016|accessdate=June 14, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/personalities/hillary-clinton|title=Hillary Clinton's file|publisher=Politifact.com|accessdate=June 14, 2016}}</ref>
''The New York Times'' ran a front-page story on July 24, 2015 with the headline "Criminal Inquiry Sought In Clinton's Use of Email," with the lead sentence stating, "Two inspectors general have asked the Justice Department to open a criminal investigation into whether Hillary Rodham Clinton mishandled sensitive government information on a private email account she used as secretary of state, senior government officials said Thursday."<ref name="mediamatters.org">{{cite web|url=https://www.mediamatters.org/blog/2015/07/25/ny-times-issues-second-major-correction-to-botc/204596|title=NY Times Issues Second Major Correction To Botched Report On Clinton's Emails|date=July 25, 2015|publisher=|accessdate=October 9, 2018}}</ref> Shortly after the publication of the story, the Inspectors General of the Intelligence Community and the Department of State issued a statement clarifying, "An important distinction is that the IC IG did not make a criminal referral - it was a security referral made for counterintelligence purposes."<ref>https://www.stateoig.gov/system/files/statement_of_the_icig_and_oig_regarding_review_of_clintons_emails_july_24_2015_0.pdf</ref> The ''Times'' later made two corrections, first that Clinton was not a specific target of the referral, then later that the referral was not "criminal" in nature.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/24/us/politics/inquiry-is-sought-in-hillary-clinton-email-account.html|title=Inquiry Sought in Hillary Clinton's Use of Email|publisher=|accessdate=October 9, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mediamatters.org/research/2015/07/24/ny-times-walks-back-flimsy-report-on-probe-into/204576|title=NY Times Walks Back Flimsy Report On Probe Into Clinton's Email|date=July 24, 2015|publisher=|accessdate=October 9, 2018}}</ref><ref name="mediamatters.org"/>
Clinton's IT contractors turned over her personal email server to the FBI on August 12, 2015,<ref name="server"/> as well as thumb drives containing copies of her emails.<ref name=ABC0812>Justin Fishel & Mike Levine, [http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/hillary-clinton-emails-questions-answered/story?id=33037501 Hillary Clinton Emails: Your Questions Answered], ABC News, August 12, 2015.</ref><ref>Anita Kumar, Marisa Taylor & Greg Gordon, [http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/nation-world/national/article30714762.html "Top Secret' emails Found as Clinton Probe Expands to Key Aides], McClatchy Washington Bureau, August 11, 2015.</ref>
In a letter describing the matter to Senator [[Ron Johnson (Wisconsin politician)|Ron Johnson]], Chairman of the Senate Homeland Security Committee, Clinton's lawyer [[David E. Kendall]] said that emails, and all other data stored on the server, had earlier been erased prior to the device being turned over to the authorities, and that both he and another lawyer had been given security clearances by the State Department to handle thumb drives containing about 30,000 emails that Clinton subsequently also turned over to authorities. Kendall said the thumb drives had been stored in a safe provided to him in July by the State Department.<ref name=AP0819>{{cite news|last1=Sacks|first1=Mike|title=Clinton Lawyer Informs Congress About Security Clearance, Email Safeguards|url=http://www.nationallawjournal.com/id=1202735059877/Clinton-Lawyer-Informs-Congress-About-Security-Clearance-Email-Safeguards|accessdate=September 19, 2015|work=National Law Journal|date=August 18, 2015}}</ref>
====August 2015 – Investigation continues; email recovery==== On August 20, 2015, U.S. District Judge [[Emmet G. Sullivan]] stated that Hillary Clinton's actions of maintaining a private email server were in direct conflict with U.S. government policy. "We wouldn't be here today if this employee had followed government policy," he said, and ordered the State Department to work with the FBI to determine if any emails on the server during her tenure as Secretary of State could be recovered.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Jason Donner|title=Judge orders State Dept. to work on recovering emails, suggests Clinton violated policy|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2015/08/20/judge-orders-state-to-work-with-fbi-on-clinton-email-investigation/?intcmp=ob_article_footer_text&intcmp=obnetwork|accessdate=August 27, 2015|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=August 20, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Schmidt>{{cite news|last1=Schmidt|first1=Michael|title=Judge Says Hillary Clinton Didn't Follow Government Email Policies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/21/us/judge-says-hillary-clinton-didnt-follow-government-email-policies.html|accessdate=August 27, 2015|publisher=NYT|date=August 20, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Gerstein>{{cite news|last1=Gerstein|first1=Josh|title=Judge says Hillary Clinton's private emails violated policy|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/08/judge-says-hillary-clintons-private-emails-violated-policy-121568.html|accessdate=August 28, 2015|publisher=Politico|date=August 20, 2015}}</ref>
Platte River Networks, the Denver-based firm that managed the Clinton server since 2013, said it had no knowledge of the server being wiped. "Platte River has no knowledge of the server being wiped," company spokesman Andy Boian told the ''[[Washington Post]]''. "All the information we have is that the server wasn't wiped."<ref name=WP0912>{{cite news|last1=Helderman|first1=Rosalind S.|last2=Hamburger|first2=Tom|last3=Leonnig|first3=Carol D.|title=Tech company: No indication that Clinton's e-mail server was 'wiped'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/tech-company-no-indication-that-clintons-e-mail-server-was-wiped/2015/09/12/10c8ce52-58c6-11e5-abe9-27d53f250b11_story.html|accessdate=September 13, 2015|publisher=Washington Post''|date=September 12, 2015}}</ref> When asked by the ''Washington Post'', the Clinton campaign declined to comment.<ref name=WP0912/>
In September 2015, FBI investigators were engaged in sorting messages recovered from the server.<ref name="wilbur">{{cite news|author1=Del Quentin Wilber|title=FBI Said to Recover Personal E-Mails From Hillary Clinton Server|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2015-09-22/fbi-said-to-recover-personal-e-mails-from-hillary-clinton-server|accessdate=September 23, 2015|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=September 22, 2015}}</ref> In November 2015, the FBI expanded its inquiry to examine whether Clinton or her aides jeopardized national security secrets, and if so, who should be held responsible.<ref name=Bade1110>Rachael Bade, [http://www.politico.com/story/2015/11/hillary-clinton-email-fbi-probe-215630 "FBI steps up interviews in Clinton email probe; Questions focus on whether State officials improperly sent classified material"], Politico.com, November 10, 2015. Retrieved November 14, 2016.</ref><ref name=HNGN1110>Taylor Tyler, [http://www.hngn.com/articles/148950/20151110/clinton-emails-fbi-expands-investigation-email-setup.htm "Clinton Emails: FBI Expands Investigation Into Clinton Email Setup"], ''Headlines & Global News'', November 10, 2015. Retrieved November 14, 2016.</ref>
<!-- inclusion and lang per current consensus on Talk -->Conflicting media sources sized the FBI investigation from 12<ref name="msnbc-ari">{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/fed-source-about-12-fbi-agents-working-clinton-email-inquiry-n548026|publisher=MSNBC|last=Melber|first=Ari|date=March 30, 2016|accessdate=April 29, 2016|title=Fed Source: About 12 FBI Agents Working on Clinton Email Inquiry}}</ref> to 30 agents<ref name="time">{{cite news|url=http://time.com/4276988/jim-comey-hillary-clinton|work=Time|last=Calabresi|first=Massimo|date=March 31, 2016|accessdate=April 29, 2016|title=Inside the FBI Investigation of Hillary Clinton's E-Mail}}</ref> as of March 2016.<!-- end of current consensus lage per Talk -->
====May–July 2016 – Public statements==== In May 2016, FBI Director [[James Comey]] said he was "not familiar with the term 'security inquiry'" as the Clinton campaign was characterizing the probe, adding that the word ''investigation'' is "in our name" and "We're conducting an investigation ... That's what we do. That's probably all I can say about it."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/hillary-clinton-email-investigation-fbi-james-comey-223071|title=FBI's James Comey: I feel 'pressure' to quickly finish Clinton email probe|publisher=politico.com|date=May 11, 2016}}</ref><ref name="fbi.gov">{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/news/pressrel/press-releases/director-comey-remarks-during-may-11-2018pen-and-pad2019-briefing-with-reporters|title=Director Comey Remarks During May 11 'Pen and Pad' Briefing with Reporters|website=Federal Bureau of Investigation|accessdate=October 13, 2018}}</ref> Comey noted in his 2018 memoir that he did not publicly contradict Clinton's characterization of the investigation as a "security inquiry" while it was underway<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/13/us/politics/comey-book-clinton-emails.html|title=As Clinton Camp Denied Reports of Criminal Inquiry, F.B.I. Was Investigating, Comey Says|publisher=|accessdate=October 13, 2018}}</ref> despite being directly prompted by a reporter to do so in May 2016.<ref name="fbi.gov"/> In April 2017 it became known that the FBI had, in fact, opened a criminal investigation on July 10, 2015, telling ''The New York Times'' they had received a "criminal referral," although the following day they issued a public statement: "The department has received a referral related to the potential compromise of classified information. It is not a criminal referral."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/22/us/politics/james-comey-election.html|title=Comey Tried to Shield the F.B.I. From Politics. Then He Shaped an Election.|publisher=|accessdate=October 9, 2018}}</ref>
<!-- exact text per RfC on Talk --> In late June 2016, it was reported that Bill Clinton met privately with Attorney General [[Loretta Lynch]] on her private plane on the tarmac at [[Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport]]. Officials indicated that the 30 minute meeting took place when Clinton became aware that Lynch's plane was on the same tarmac at the airport. When the meeting became public, Lynch stated that it was "primarily social" and "there was no discussion of any matter pending for the department or any matter pending for any other body." Lynch was criticized for her involvement in the meeting and was called on by some critics to recuse herself from involvement in the FBI's investigation of the email case. In response, she stated "The F.B.I. is investigating whether Mrs. Clinton, her aides or anyone else broke the law by setting up a private email server for her to use as secretary of state," but "the case will be resolved by the same team that has been working on it from the beginning" and "I will be accepting their recommendations."<ref name="https">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/02/us/politics/loretta-lynch-hillary-clinton-email-server.html|title=Lynch to Accept F.B.I. Recommendations in Clinton Email Inquiry, Official Says |work=NYT|date=July 1, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/attorney-general-loretta-lynch-calls-perfectly-reasonable-question/story?id=40272091|title=Attorney General Loretta Lynch Calls It 'Perfectly Reasonable' to Question Bill Clinton Meeting|publisher=ABC News|date=July 1, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/06/30/loretta-lynch-bill-clinton-meeting/86555274/|title=Loretta Lynch, Bill Clinton meeting raises eyebrows|work=USA Today|date=June 30, 2016}}</ref> <!-- end of current consensus text per RfC on Talk -->
On July 1, 2016, the ''New York Times'' reported in the name of a "Justice Department official" that Attorney General Loretta Lynch will accept "whatever recommendation career prosecutors and the F.B.I. director make about whether to bring charges related to Hillary Clinton's personal email server."<ref name="https"/>
Clinton maintained she did not send or receive any confidential emails from her personal server. In a Democratic debate with [[Bernie Sanders]] on February 4, 2016, Clinton said, "I never sent or received any classified material." In a Meet the Press interview on July 2, 2016, she stated: "Let me repeat what I have repeated for many months now, I never received nor sent any material that was marked classified."<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/fbi-investigation-sheds-light-hillary-clintons-past-email/story?id=40350589|title=FBI Contradicts Clinton's Email Claims on Classified Info|date=July 5, 2016|publisher=ABC News}}</ref><ref name="politifact.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/jul/06/hillary-clinton/fbi-findings-tear-holes-hillary-clintons-email-def|title=FBI tears holes in Hillary Clinton's email defense|publisher=politifact.com}}</ref><ref name="washingtonpost.com1">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2015/08/27/clintons-claims-about-receiving-or-sending-classified-material-on-her-private-email-system|title=Clinton's claims about receiving or sending 'classified material' on her private e-mail system|work=The Washington Post|date=August 27, 2015}}</ref>
====July 2016 – Investigation concludes==== On July 5, 2016, FBI Director Comey announced in a statement he read to press and television reporters at FBI headquarters in Washington, DC, that the FBI had completed its investigation and was referring it to the State Department with the recommendation "that no charges are appropriate in this case."<ref name=Comey>{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/news/pressrel/press-releases/statement-by-fbi-director-james-b.-comey-on-the-investigation-of-secretary-hillary-clintons-use-of-a-personal-e-mail-system|title=Statement by FBI Director James B. Comey on the Investigation of Secretary Hillary Clinton's Use of a Personal E-Mail System|publisher=[[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]|date=July 5, 2016|accessdate=July 13, 2016}}</ref><ref name="News">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/fbi-completes-investigation-hillary-clintons-personal-email-server/story?id=40346712|title=FBI Recommends No Charges Over Clinton Email Use|first=A.B.C.|last=News|date=July 6, 2016|publisher=ABC News}}</ref><ref name=ZapHel>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/fbi-chief-plans-remarks-to-media-amid-heightened-focus-on-clinton-email-probe/2016/07/05/a53513c4-42b9-11e6-bc99-7d269f8719b1_story.html|last1=Zapotosky|first1=Matt|last2=Helderman|first2=Rosalind S.|title=FBI recommends no criminal charges in Clinton email probe|work=The Washington Post|date=July 5, 2016|accessdate=July 5, 2016}}</ref> He added, "Although there is evidence of potential violations of the statutes regarding the handling of classified information, our judgment is that no reasonable prosecutor would bring such a case."<ref name="Comey"/><ref name="News"/>
With regard to mishandling of classified information, Comey said, "there is evidence that they [Clinton and her team] were extremely careless in their handling of very sensitive, highly classified information." The investigation found 110 emails that should have been regarded as classified at the time they were sent; another 2,000 emails were retroactively classified which means they were not classified at the time they were sent.<ref name="Comey"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/watch-live-fbi-director-speaks-at-11-a-m-edt|title=FBI director recommends 'no charges' over Clinton's emails|last=Epatko|first=Larisa|date=July 5, 2016|work=PBS|accessdate=November 4, 2016}}</ref> Comey said that "any reasonable person in Secretary Clinton's position, or in the position of those government employees with whom she was corresponding ... should have known that an unclassified system was no place for that conversation."<ref name="FBI-Report">{{cite web|url=https://vault.fbi.gov/hillary-r.-clinton|title=Clinton e-mail Investigation|publisher=[[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]|date=July 2016|accessdate=October 28, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/05/politics/fbi-director-doesnt-recommend-charges-against-hillary-clinton/index.html|title=FBI: Clinton 'extremely careless' but no charges recommended|first=Collinson, Stephen & Tal Kopan|last=CNN|publisher=}}</ref>
The FBI learned that Clinton used her personal email extensively while outside the United States, both sending and receiving work-related emails in the territory of sophisticated adversaries. The FBI did not find "direct evidence that Secretary Clinton's personal e-mail domain ... was successfully hacked;" they assessed it "possible that hostile actors gained access" to it.<ref name=Comey/><ref name=ZapHel/> Investigators found that State Department employees often used private emails to conduct business. Comey noted, "We also developed evidence that the security culture of the State Department in general, and with respect to use of unclassified e-mail systems in particular, was generally lacking in the kind of care for classified information found elsewhere in the government."<ref name="Graff">{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/09/hillary-clinton-emails-2016-server-state-department-fbi-214307|title=What the FBI Files Reveal About Hillary Clinton's Email Server|last=Graff|first=Garrett M.|date=September 30, 2016|work=Politico|accessdate=November 4, 2016}}</ref>
On July 6, 2016, Lynch confirmed that the investigation into Hillary Clinton's use of private email servers while secretary of state would be closed without criminal charges.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/justice-department-closes-clinton-email-probe-without-charges/2016/07/06/0ad8feda-43c2-11e6-88d0-6adee48be8bc_story.html|last=Zapotosky|first=Matt|title=Justice Department closes Clinton email probe without charges|work=The Washington Post|date=July 6, 2016|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref>
====October 2016 – Additional investigation==== In early October 2016, FBI criminal investigators working on a case involving former Congressman [[Anthony Weiner]] allegedly [[Anthony Weiner sexting scandals|sending sexually explicit texts to a fifteen-year-old girl]] discovered emails from Weiner's estranged wife, [[Huma Abedin]], vice chair of Hillary Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign, that they considered potentially relevant to the Clinton server investigation. FBI officials reportedly decided to disclose the development despite its potential effect on the pending presidential election to preempt the possibility that it would be leaked in another way.<ref name="CNN Weiner">{{cite web|last=Perez|first=Evan|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/30/politics/clinton-emails-fbi-abedin/index.html|title=FBI discovered Clinton-related emails weeks ago|date=October 30, 2016|publisher=CNN|accessdate=November 14, 2016}}</ref>
On October 28, 2016, Comey informed Congress that "in connection with an unrelated case, the FBI has learned of the existence of emails that appear pertinent to the investigation." He said the FBI will take "appropriate investigative steps designed to allow investigators to review these emails to determine whether they contain classified information, as well as to assess their importance to our investigation." He added that the FBI "cannot yet assess whether or not this material may be significant."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/28/politics/fbi-reviewing-new-emails-in-clinton-probe-director-tells-senate-judiciary-committee/|title=Comey notified Congress of email probe despite DOJ concerns|last1=Perez|first1=Evan|last2=Brown|first2=Pamela|date=October 29, 2016|publisher=CNN|accessdate=October 29, 2016}}</ref> The FBI obtained a new search warrant to allow them to review Abedin's emails.<ref name="CNN Weiner"/>
Comey informed Congress of this additional investigation despite having been advised by Justice Department officials that such an announcement would violate department policies and procedures, including a policy not to comment on investigations close to an election.<ref name="despite">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/28/politics/fbi-reviewing-new-emails-in-clinton-probe-director-tells-senate-judiciary-committee/|title=Comey notified Congress of email probe despite DOJ concerns|date=October 30, 2016|publisher=CNN|accessdate=November 5, 2016}}</ref> Comey later explained, in a letter to FBI employees, "We don't ordinarily tell Congress about ongoing investigations, but here I feel an obligation to do so given that I testified repeatedly in recent months that our investigation was completed." Law enforcement sources added that he feared he would be accused of concealing relevant information if he did not disclose it.<ref name="despite"/>
News of this renewed investigation being revealed shortly before the [[United States presidential election, 2016|U.S. presidential election]] led to the announcement being described as an "[[October surprise]],"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/a/furor-over-fbi-email-bombshell/3572062.html|title=Officials: FBI Knew About Possible New Clinton Emails Weeks Before Friday Announcement|last=Bowman|first=Michael|newspaper=VOA|access-date=2016-10-31}}</ref> and prompted statements from both the Democratic and Republican campaigns. [[Donald Trump]] repeated his characterization that Hillary Clinton's email usage as secretary of state was "worse than [[Watergate]]."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/4534375/donald-trump-hillary-clinton-emails-watergate/|title=Donald Trump: Hillary Clinton Email Scandal 'Worse Than Watergate'|work=Time|date=October 17, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/fbi-clinton-new-probe-trump-hails-230460|title=Trump hails new Clinton FBI review as 'bigger than Watergate'|last=Schreckinger|first=Ben|date=October 28, 2016|work=Politico|accessdate=October 31, 2016}}</ref> Clinton called for the FBI to immediately release all information about the newly discovered emails and said she was confident the FBI would not change its earlier conclusion that there is no basis for criminal prosecution.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/10/28/fbi-probe-newly-discovered-hillary-clinton-emails-and-reopen-inv|title=Hillary Clinton demands answers and Democrats call foul as FBI reopens investigation over files found on sexting congressman's computer|date=October 30, 2016|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=November 14, 2016}}</ref> Senator [[Dianne Feinstein]] (D-CA) said she was "shocked" by the letter, saying it "played right into the political campaign of Donald Trump."<ref name="despite"/>
On November 6, in another letter to Congress, Comey stated that, after working "around the clock" to review all of the newly discovered emails, the FBI had not changed the conclusion it reached in July.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/fbi-completes-review-newly-revealed-hillary-clinton-emails-finds-no-n678701|title=FBI finds no criminality in review of newly discovered Clinton emails|accessdate=November 14, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/07/us/politics/hilary-clinton-male-voters-donald-trump.html|title=Emails Warrant No New Action Against Hillary Clinton, F.B.I. Director Says|date=November 6, 2016|work=The New York Times|accessdate=November 6, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/election-us-2016-37892138|title=No criminality in Clinton emails – FBI|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=November 6, 2016|accessdate=November 14, 2016}}</ref> An unnamed government official added that the newly discovered emails turned out to be either personal or duplicates of emails previously reviewed, and that Comey's letter represents a conclusion of the investigation.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/fbi-director-comey-says-agency-wont-recommend-charges-over-clinton-email/2016/11/06/f6276b18-a45e-11e6-ba59-a7d93165c6d4_story.html|title=FBI director says agency once again won't recommend charges over Clinton email|date=November 6, 2016|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=November 14, 2016}}</ref> The following day, stock and currency markets around the world surged in response.<ref name=Shell>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/markets/2016/11/07/asian-stocks-bounce-after-fbi-clears-clinton-over-emails/93412244|title=Dow surges 300 points as FBI clears Clinton on eve of election|work=[[USA Today]]|date=November 7, 2016|accessdate=November 7, 2016|author1=Shell, Adam |author2=Jane Onyanga-Omara}}</ref><ref name=Imbert>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/11/07/us-markets.html|title=Dow soars 350 points higher on eve of US election; financials, health care lead|publisher=[[CNBC]]|date=November 7, 2016|accessdate=November 14, 2016|author=Imbert, Fred}}</ref><ref name=Mikolajczak>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-markets-idUSKBN13115N|title=Stocks, dollar jump as FBI clears Clinton in email probe|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=November 7, 2016|accessdate=November 16, 2016|author=Mikolajczak, Chuck}}</ref>
On November 12, during a conference call to top donors, Hillary Clinton attributed her [[United States presidential election, 2016|presidential election]] loss to Comey's announcements, saying they stopped her momentum.<ref>{{cite web |last=Lawler |first=David |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/11/12/hillary-clinton-blames-election-loss-on-fbis-james-comey-in-call/ |title=US election: Hillary Clinton blames loss on FBI's James Comey in call with top donors |date=November 13, 2016 |work=The Telegraph |accessdate=January 13, 2017}}</ref> In January 2017, the US Justice Department started an investigation of Comey's announcements.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ainsley |first1=Julia Edwards |last2=Harte |first2=Julia |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-idUSKBN14W2NT |title=FBI investigated over pre-election decisions on Clinton email |date=January 13, 2017 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=January 13, 2017}}</ref>
=== Senate probes Loretta Lynch interference === According to Comey's June 8, 2017, testimony to the Senate Intelligence Committee, then-Attorney General Loretta Lynch had asked him to downplay the investigation into Clinton's emails by calling it a "matter" rather than an investigation. He said the request "confused and concerned" him. He added that Lynch's tarmac meeting with [[Bill Clinton]] also influenced his decision to publicly announce the results of the FBI probe.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/james-comey-loretta-lynch-told-me-not-to-call-clinton-email-probe-an-investigation/article/2625335|title=James Comey: Loretta Lynch told me not to call Clinton email probe an 'investigation'|last=Cohen|first=Kelly|work=Washington Examiner|access-date=2017-07-05|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/senate-probes-loretta-lynchs-alleged-interference-clinton-email/story?id=48237960|title=Senate probes Loretta Lynch's alleged interference in Clinton investigation|last=News|first=A. B. C.|date=2017-06-23|publisher=ABC News|access-date=2017-07-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://time.com/4831849/loretta-lynch-hillary-clinton-fbi-senate/|title=Senate Investigating Loretta Lynch's Alleged Interference in Hillary Clinton Email Probe|access-date=2017-07-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
On June 23, 2017, several members of the Senate Judiciary Committee opened a bipartisan inquiry into whether former Attorney General Lynch interfered in the FBI's investigation into Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/senate-investigates-loretta-lynch-clinton-email-investigation-2017-6|title=The Senate is investigating whether former Attorney General Loretta Lynch interfered in the Clinton email investigation|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-07-05|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/senate-probes-loretta-lynchs-alleged-interference-clinton-email/story?id=48237960|title=Senate probes Loretta Lynch's alleged interference in Clinton investigation|last=Parkinson|first=John|date=2017-06-23|publisher=ABC News|access-date=2017-07-05}}</ref>
===Internal State Department investigation=== On July 7, 2016, the internal State Department resumed its review of whether classified information had been mishandled. The review had been suspended until the completion of the Justice Department investigation.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Labott|first1=Elise|last2=Lee|first2=MJ|title=Clinton reiterates email use was a 'mistake' as State Dept. reopens probe|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/07/07/politics/state-department-reopens-probe-into-clinton-emails|accessdate=November 5, 2016|work=Salon|date=July 9, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/election-us-2016-36742095|title=Hillary Clinton emails: US State Department restarts probe|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
=== Department of Justice Inspector General's report ===
{{main|Inspector General report on FBI and DOJ actions in the 2016 election}}
The [[Inspector General of the Department of Justice]] (IG) launched an investigation into how the DOJ and FBI had handled the investigation into Clinton's email. On June 14, 2018, the IG issued a report that was highly critical of Comey's actions.<ref name = highlights/> Regarding his July press conference, in which he criticized Clinton even while announcing the investigation was over, the IG said it was "extraordinary and insubordinate for Comey to conceal his intentions (about the press conference) from his superiors," and that "we found none of his reasons to be a persuasive basis for deviating from well-established Department policies."<ref name = slams>{{cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/doj-watchdog-slams-insubordinate-james-comey-over-clinton-email_us_5b22a82be4b0d4fc01fc61e6|title=DOJ Watchdog Slams 'Insubordinate' James Comey Over Clinton Email News Conference|last=Reilly|first=Ryan J.|date=June 14, 2018|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=16 June 2018}}</ref> Comey's October decision to send a letter notifying Congress that the investigation had been re-opened one week before the election was described as "[[ad-hoc]]" and "a serious error in judgment."<ref name = slams/> However, the IG concluded that prosecutorial decisions in the Clinton case were consistent with precedent and were not affected by bias.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/14/politics/ig-report-clinton-email-investigation/index.html|title=Comey's actions 'extraordinary and insubordinate,' report says|date=June 14, 2018|work=CNN|accessdate=16 June 2018}}</ref>
===Opinions of journalists and experts=== According to the ''New York Times'', if Clinton was a recipient of classified emails, "it is not clear that she would have known that they contained government secrets, since they were not marked classified."<ref name=Allen0821>{{cite web|last1=Allen|first1= Jonathan|title=Exclusive: Dozens of Clinton emails were classified from the start, U.S. rules suggest|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/08/21/us-usa-election-clinton-emails-idUSKCN0QQ0BW20150821|agency=Reuters|accessdate=August 28, 2015|date=August 21, 2015}}</ref><ref name=NYT72415/> The newspaper reported that "most specialists believe the occasional appearance of classified information in the Clinton account was probably of marginal consequence".<ref name=NYT8815/> Steven Aftergood, director of the Project on Government Secrecy at the [[Federation of American Scientists]], said that inadvertent "spillage" of classified information into an unclassified realm is a common occurrence.<ref name="NYT8815"/>
[[Reuters]]' August 2015 review of a set of released emails found "at least 30 email threads from 2009, representing scores of individual emails," which include what the State Department identifies as "foreign government information," defined by the U.S. government as "any information, written or spoken, provided in confidence to U.S. officials by their foreign counterparts." Although unmarked, Reuters' examination appeared to suggest that these emails "were classified from the start."<ref name=Allen0821/> [[J. William Leonard]], a former director of the NARA [[Information Security Oversight Office]], said that such information is "born classified" and that "[I]f a foreign minister just told the secretary of state something in confidence, by U.S. rules that is classified at the moment it's in U.S. channels and U.S. possession."<ref name=Allen0821/> According to Reuters, the standard U.S. government [[nondisclosure agreement]] "warns people authorized to handle classified information that it may not be marked that way and that it may come in oral form." The State Department "disputed Reuters' analysis" but declined to elaborate.<ref name=Allen0821/>
The [[Associated Press]] reported, "Some officials said they believed the designations were a stretch—a knee-jerk move in a bureaucracy rife with over-classification."<ref name=AP81415/> [[Jeffrey Toobin]], in an August 2015 ''[[The New Yorker|New Yorker]]'' article, wrote that the Clinton email affair is an illustration of overclassification, a problem written about by Senator [[Daniel Patrick Moynihan]] in his book ''Secrecy: The American Experience''.<ref name="Toobin">Jeffrey Toobin, [http://www.newyorker.com/news/daily-comment/hillarys-problem-the-government-classifies-everything Hillary's Problem: The Government Classifies Everything], ''The New Yorker'', August 18, 2015.</ref> Toobin writes that "government bureaucracies use classification rules to protect turf, to avoid embarrassment, to embarrass rivals—in short, for a variety of motives that have little to do with national security."<ref name="Toobin"/> Toobin wrote that "It's not only the public who cannot know the extent or content of government secrecy. Realistically, government officials can't know either—and this is Hillary Clinton's problem. Toobin noted that "one of Clinton's potentially classified email exchanges is nothing more than a discussion of a newspaper story about [[Drone strikes in Pakistan|drones]]" and wrote: "That such a discussion could be classified underlines the absurdity of the current system. But that is the system that exists, and if and when the agencies determine that she sent or received classified information through her private server, Clinton will be accused of mishandling national-security secrets."<ref name="Toobin"/>
In an analysis of the Clinton email controversy published by the [[Brookings Institution]], Richard Lempert wrote that "security professionals have a reputation for erring in the direction of overclassification."<ref name="German">German, Ben. [http://www.nationaljournal.com/twentysixteen/2015/08/19/other-top-secret-problem-hurting-hillary-clinton The Other 'Top Secret' Problem Hurting Hillary Clinton] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017184847/http://www.nationaljournal.com/twentysixteen/2015/08/19/other-top-secret-problem-hurting-hillary-clinton |date=October 17, 2015 }}, ''National Journal'', August 19, 2015.</ref> Elizabeth Goitein, co-director of the liberty and national security program at the [[Brennan Center for Justice]] at [[New York University School of Law]], says that "The odds are good that any classified information in the Clinton emails should not have been classified," since an estimated 50 percent to 90 percent of classified documents could be made public without risking national security.<ref name="German" /> Nate Jones, an expert with the [[National Security Archive]] at [[George Washington University]], said: "Clinton's mistreatment of federal records and the intelligence community's desire to retroactively overclassify are two distinct troubling problems. No politician is giving the right message: Blame Clinton for poor records practices, but don't embrace overclassification while you do it."<ref name="German" />
==House Oversight Committee hearing== On July 7, 2016, Comey was questioned for 5 hours by the [[United States House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform]]. Comey stated that there was "evidence of mishandling" of classified information and that he believed that Clinton was "extremely careless; I think she was negligent." He defended the FBI's recommendation against bringing charges because it "... would have been unfair and virtually unprecedented ..."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/fbi-director-james-comey-hillary-clinton-email-probe/story?id=41044927|title=What FBI Director Really Said About Clinton Email Probe|first=Mike|last=Levine|date=August 2, 2016|publisher=ABC}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/fbi-director-set-to-appear-before-congressional-committee-to-answer-questions-on-clinton-investigation/2016/07/07/eb43ec7e-43c1-11e6-88d0-6adee48be8bc_story.html|last=Zapotosky|first=Matt|title=House Republicans grill FBI director Comey on Clinton emails|work=The Washington Post|date=July 7, 2016|accessdate=July 7, 2016}}</ref>
==Responses and analysis== ===Clinton's initial response=== [[File:2015 03 10 Hillary Clinton by Voice of America (cropped to collar).jpg|thumb|left|Clinton addressing email controversy with the media at the [[Headquarters of the United Nations|UN Headquarters]] on March 10, 2015]] Clinton's spokesman Nick Merrill defended Clinton's usage of her personal server and email accounts as being ''in compliance with the "letter and spirit of the rules."''
Clinton herself stated she had done so as a matter of "convenience."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/03/10/politics/hillary-clinton-email-scandal-press-conference|title=Hillary Clinton email scandal does damage control – CNN|author=Alexandra Jaffe and Dan Merica, CNN|date=March 10, 2015|publisher=CNN|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref>
On March 10, 2015, while attending a conference at the [[headquarters of the United Nations|headquarters of the United Nation]]s in [[Manhattan]], Clinton spoke with reporters for about 20 minutes.<ref name=WashPost3>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/hillary-clinton-to-answer-questions-about-use-of-private-e-mail-server/2015/03/10/4c000d00-c735-11e4-a199-6cb5e63819d2_story.html|title=Clinton: It 'might have been smarter' to use a State Dept. e-mail account|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=April 1, 2015}}</ref> Clinton said she had used a private email for convenience, "because I thought it would be easier to carry just one device for my work and for my personal emails instead of two."<ref name="cnn03312015">{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/03/31/politics/hillary-clinton-ipad-e-mail-devices|title=Source: Clinton used iPad for personal email at State|publisher=CNN|date=March 31, 2015|accessdate=August 16, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2015/03/10/first-take-hillary-clinton-emails/24705871|title=First Take: Clinton's even tone edges into exasperation | work=USA Today | date=March 11, 2015 | accessdate=April 1, 2015}}</ref> It was later determined that Clinton had used both an [[iPad]] and a [[BlackBerry]] while Secretary of State.<ref name=cnn03312015/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/64f85b3a72184bd1b4604d5e1870116d/clinton-also-used-ipad-email-mixed-personal-work-chats|title=State Department found 4 emails about drones sent by Clinton|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=August 16, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/hillary-clinton-actually-used-two-devices-while-secretary-of-state-records-show-10147082.html|title=Hillary Clinton actually used two devices while secretary of state, records show |work=The Independent| accessdate=August 16, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2015/03/31/hillary-clinton-also-used-an-ipad-for-e-mails-undercutting-her-single-device-defense|title=Hillary Clinton also used an iPad for e-mails, undercutting her single-device defense|work=The Washington Post| accessdate = August 16, 2015}}</ref>
Clinton turned over copies of 30,000 State Department business-related emails from her private server that belonged in the public domain; she later explained that she instructed her lawyer to err on the side of disclosure, turning over any emails that ''might'' be work-related. Her aides subsequently deleted about 31,000 emails from the server dated during the same time period that Clinton regarded as personal and private.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/politics/politicsnow/la-pn-hillary-clinton-email-un-20150310-story.html#page=2|title=Hillary Clinton tries to end controversy over private email account |quote=she disclosed that her aides had deleted more than 30,000 emails that she deemed personal. ... Clinton said that when she and her staff reviewed the emails last year, she instructed her lawyer to err on the side of turning over anything that might be considered work-related.|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=April 1, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/10/hillary-clinton-spam-deleted-214351|title=Most Clinton Spam Messages Likely Deleted|publisher=Politico|date=October 1, 2015|authors=Josh Gerstein and Joseph Marks|quote=[A]ccording to little-noticed language in a statement Clinton's office issued earlier this year. ... 'After her work-related emails were identified and preserved, Secretary Clinton chose not to keep her private, personal messages. ... '}}</ref><ref name="SchmidtPrivateEmails">Michael S. Schmidt, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/12/us/justice-dept-says-hillary-clinton-had-authority-to-delete-certain-emails.html?_r=0 Justice Dept. Says Hillary Clinton Had Authority to Delete Certain Emails], ''The New York Times'', September 11, 2015.</ref> State Department employees do have the right to delete personal emails.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hillary Clinton had right to delete personal emails, says US justice department|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/sep/12/hillary-clinton-had-right-to-delete-personal-emails-says-us-justice-department|accessdate=November 4, 2016|work=The Guardian|agency=Associated Press|date=September 11, 2015}}</ref>
Clinton has used humor to try to shrug off the scandals.<ref>O'Harrow, Robert. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/how-clintons-email-scandal-took-root/2016/03/27/ee301168-e162-11e5-846c-10191d1fc4ec_story.html "How Clinton's email scandal took root"], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', March 27, 2016.</ref><ref>Vorhees, Josh. [http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2015/08/20/hillary_clinton_email_scandal_explained.html A Crystal-Clear Explanation of Hillary's Confusing Email Scandal], ''Slate'', August 20, 2015.</ref> In August 2015, when asked by a reporter whether she had "wiped" her server, Clinton laughed and said: "What? Like with a cloth or something? I don't know how it works digitally at all."<ref>Struyk, Ryan & Liz Kreutz, [http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/hillary-clinton-jokes-wiping-email-server-cloth/story?id=33165517 Hillary Clinton Jokes About Wiping Email Server 'With A Cloth Or Something'], ABC News, August 18, 2015.</ref> In September 2015, Clinton was asked in an interview with [[Jimmy Fallon]] on ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' about the content of the emails. She laughed it off, saying there was nothing interesting and joking that she was offended people found her emails 'boring.'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/jimmy-fallon-gives-hillary-a-pass-on-boring-emails|title=Jimmy Fallon Gives Hillary a Pass on 'Boring' Emails|author=Wilstein, Matt|accessdate=April 16, 2016|publisher=Mediaite}}</ref>
====Later responses==== Clinton's responses to the question, made during her presidential campaign, evolved over time.<ref name="Toobin"/><ref name=politics>{{cite news|author1=Leonnig, Carol D., Karen Tumulty & Rosalind S. Helderman|title=Clinton's team went from nonchalant to nervous over e-mail controversy|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/how-clintons-team-went-from-nonchalant-to-nervous-over-e-mail-controversy/2015/08/14/347f1066-405e-11e5-9561-4b3dc93e3b9a_story.html|accessdate=August 18, 2015|work=The Washington Post|date=August 14, 2015|quote= ... it has become clear that a number of her statements defending her actions now appear to be false.}}</ref> Clinton initially said that there was no classified material on her server. Later, after a government review discovered some of her emails contained classified information, she said she never sent or received information that was ''marked'' classified.<ref name="Toobin" /> Her campaign claimed other emails contained information that is now classified, but was ''retroactively'' classified by U.S. intelligence agencies after Clinton had received the material.<ref name="Campaign Classified">Tau, Byron & Robert McMillan. [https://www.wsj.com/articles/hillary-clinton-says-classified-emails-were-on-server-1440030491 Hillary Clinton Campaign Says Classified Emails Were on Server], ''The Wall Street Journal'', August 19, 2015.</ref> See also the section above on the [[Hillary Clinton email controversy#May 2016 report from State Department's inspector general|May 2016 IG report]] for a number of Clinton statements that were contradicted by the report, and how she and her supporters responded afterward.
Campaign spokesman Brian Fallon said: "She was at worst a passive recipient of unwitting information that subsequently became deemed as classified."<ref name="Campaign Classified"/> Clinton campaign spokeswoman [[Jennifer Palmieri]] has "stressed that Clinton was permitted to use her own email account as a government employee and that the same process concerning classification reviews would still be taking place had she used the standard 'state.gov' email account used by most department employees."<ref name=AP81415>{{cite news|author1=Bradley Klapper |author2=Ken Dilanian|title=Top secret Clinton emails include drone talk|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/b54a250a40e9410baaaca5f9fb58ea94/ap-exclusive-top-secret-clinton-emails-include-drone-talk|accessdate=August 19, 2015|work=AP Big Story|agency=Associated Press|date=August 14, 2015|quote=part of a covert program that is widely known and discussed}}</ref><ref name="KesslerFactCheck">Kessler, Glenn, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/fact-checker/wp/2015/07/09/hillary-clintons-claim-that-everything-i-did-on-emails-was-permitted "Hillary Clinton's claim that everything I did on e-mails was permitted"], ''The Washington Post'', July 9, 2015.</ref> Palmieri later stated: "Look, this kind of nonsense comes with the territory of running for president. We know it, Hillary knows it, and we expect it to continue from now until Election Day."<ref name=AP0813>Eric Tucker, [http://www.aol.com/article/2015/08/13/clinton-aides-agree-to-preserve-emails-after-judges-order/21222558 "Clinton Aides Agree to Preserve Emails after Judge's Order"], Associated Press, August 13, 2015.</ref>
In her first national interview about the 2016 presidential race, on July 7, 2015, Clinton was asked by [[CNN]]'s [[Brianna Keilar]] about her use of private email accounts while serving as Secretary of State. She said:
{{quote|Everything I did was permitted. There was no law. There was no regulation. There was nothing that did not give me the full authority to decide how I was going to communicate. Previous secretaries of state have said they did the same thing ... Everything I did was permitted by law and regulation. I had one device. When I mailed anybody in the government, it would go into the government system.<ref>[http://cnnpressroom.blogs.cnn.com/2015/07/07/cnn-exclusive-hillary-clintons-first-national-interview-of-2016-race "Hillary Clinton's first national interview of 2016 Race"], CNN, July 7, 2015.</ref>}}
On September 9, 2015, Clinton apologized during an ABC News interview for using the private server, saying she was "sorry for that."<ref name="abcsorry">{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/hillary-clinton-private-email-mistake-im/story?id=33608970|title=Hillary Clinton on Private Email: 'That Was a Mistake. I'm Sorry'|last=Kreutz|first=Liz|date=September 8, 2015|publisher=ABC News}}</ref> Appearing on NBC's ''[[Meet the Press]]'' on September 27, 2015, Clinton defended her use of the private email server while she was secretary of state, comparing the investigations to Republican-led probes of her husband's presidential administration more than two decades ago, saying, "It is like a drip, drip, drip. And that's why I said, there's only so much that I can control."<ref name=Lerer0927>Lisa Lerer, [http://www.aol.com/article/2015/09/27/clinton-compares-email-attacks-to-white-house-controversies/21241424/ Clinton Compares email Attacks to White House Controversies], Associated Press, September 27, 2015.</ref>
Clinton and the State Department said the emails were not marked classified when sent. However, Clinton signed a [[non-disclosure agreement]] which stated that classified material may be "marked or unmarked."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/27/opinions/cox-clinton-email-controversy|title=Hillary Clinton email controversy: How serious is it?|author=Douglas Cox|date=July 27, 2015|publisher=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2016/02/04/how-did-top-secret-emails-end-up-on-hillary-clintons-server|title=How did 'top secret' emails end up on Hillary Clinton's server?|author=Glenn Kessler|date=February 4, 2016|work=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/clinton-emails-held-indirect-references-undercover-cia-officers-n510741|title=Clinton Emails Held Indirect References to Undercover CIA Officers|author=Ken Dilanian|publisher=NBC News}}</ref> Additionally, the author of an email is legally required to properly mark it as classified if it contains classified material, and to avoid sending classified material on a personal device, such as the ones used exclusively by Clinton.<ref>Gearan, Anne. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/new-batch-of-clinton-e-mails-due-monday-minus-150-deemed-classified/2015/08/31/dcbdcbbc-501e-11e5-8c19-0b6825aa4a3a_story.html "Big batch of Clinton e-mails released; some have redactions"], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', August 31, 2015: "Under the law, it is the responsibility of the author of e-mails to properly mark them as classified and to make sure they avoid discussing classified material over a nongovernment or personal device. Because the State Department deals in so many sensitive secrets, many employees use two computer networks for their daily communications: a non-classified system called the "low side" and a more secure classified system called the "high side." But Clinton had no official State Department e-mail address and exclusively used a personal domain and personal server set up in her home for electronic correspondence."</ref>
Clinton maintained that she did not send or receive any confidential emails from her personal server. In a Democratic debate with [[Bernie Sanders]] on February 4, 2016, Clinton said, "I never sent or received any classified material." In a Meet the Press interview on July 2, 2016, Clinton stated: "Let me repeat what I have repeated for many months now, I never received nor sent any material that was marked classified."<ref name="auto"/><ref name="politifact.com"/><ref name="washingtonpost.com1"/>
In an interview with Fox News in late July 2016, Clinton stated "Director Comey said my answers were truthful, and what I've said is consistent with what I have told the American people, that there were decisions discussed and made to classify retroactively certain of the emails." The Washington Post awarded Clinton four "Pinocchios", its worst rating, for her statement saying "While Comey did say there was no evidence she lied to the FBI, that is not the same as saying she told the truth to the American public."<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2016/07/31/clintons-claim-that-the-fbi-director-said-her-email-answers-were-truthful "Clinton’s claim that the [[FBI]] director at the time, James Comey, said that Clinton's email answers were ''truthful''"], ''The Washington Post'', July 31, 2016.</ref><ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2016/08/01/politics/washington-post-clinton-four-pinnochios-comey-emails/index.html][[Washington Post]]<span> hits Clinton with four 'Pinnochios' on emails</span>, CNN (August 1, 2016).</ref><ref>[http://nation.foxnews.com/2016/08/01/wapo-gives-hillary-four-pinocchios-claiming-comey-called-her-truthful-about-her-emails "WaPo Gives Hillary Four Pinocchios For Claiming Comey Called Her ''Truthful'' About Her Emails"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819034501/http://nation.foxnews.com/2016/08/01/wapo-gives-hillary-four-pinocchios-claiming-comey-called-her-truthful-about-her-emails# |date=August 19, 2016 }}, Fox News Channel, August 1, 2016.</ref>
===Democratic response=== In August 2015, the ''New York Times'' reported on "interviews with more than 75 Democratic governors, lawmakers, candidates and party members" on the email issue.<ref name="FrustratesDems">Patrick Healy, Jonathan Martin & Maggie Haberman, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/28/us/politics/hillary-clintons-handling-of-email-issue-frustrates-democratic-leaders.html Hillary Clinton’s Handling of Email Issue Frustrates Democratic Leaders], ''The New York Times'', August 27, 2015.</ref> The ''Times'' reported, "None of the Democrats interviewed went so far as to suggest that the email issue raised concerns about Mrs. Clinton's ability to serve as president, and many expressed a belief that it had been [[manufactured controversy|manufactured]] by Republicans in Congress and other adversaries."<ref name="FrustratesDems"/> At the same time, many Democratic leaders showed increasing frustration among party leaders of Clinton's handling of the email issue. For example, [[Edward G. Rendell]], former [[governor of Pennsylvania]], a Clinton supporter, said that a failure of the Clinton campaign to get ahead of the issue early on meant that the campaign was "left just playing defense."<ref name="FrustratesDems"/> Other prominent Democrats, such as Governor [[Dannel P. Malloy]] of [[Connecticut]], were less concerned, noting the campaign was at an early stage and that attacks on Clinton were to be expected.<ref name="FrustratesDems"/>
At the October 2015 primary debate, Clinton's chief rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, Senator [[Bernie Sanders]] of [[Vermont]], defended Clinton, saying: "Let me say this. Let me say something that may not be great politics. But I think the secretary is right. And that is that the American people are sick and tired of hearing about your damn emails!"<ref name="DamnEmailsRoy">Roy, Jessica. [http://www.latimes.com/nation/politics/politicsnow/la-pol-prez-bernie-sanders-damn-emails-20151013-htmlstory.html "Watch Bernie Sanders slay the room with 'damn emails' line"], ''Los Angeles Times'', October 13, 2015.</ref><ref name="Terkel">Terkel, Amanda. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/bernie-sanders-hillary-clinton-emails_5623adaee4b02f6a900ca3b9 "Bernie Sanders: No Regrets Defending Hillary Clinton on Emails"], ''HuffPost'', October 19, 2015.</ref> Sanders later clarified that he thought Clinton's emails were a "very serious issue,"<ref name="Foley">Foley, Elise. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/bernie-sanders-hillary-clinton-emails_us_56ae254be4b077d4fe8e7023 Bernie Sanders Calls Hillary Clinton’s Emails ‘A Very Serious Issue’], Huffington Post (January 31, 2016).</ref> but Americans want a discussion on issues that are "real" to them, such as paid [[Family leave|family]] and [[medical leave]], [[College tuition in the United States|college affordability]], and [[campaign finance reform]].<ref name="Terkel"/>
"But her emails!" became a meme during and following the 2016 election, often used in a joking or mocking way.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.brandwatch.com/blog/react-but-her-emails/|title="But Her Emails!" Unpicking the Social Media Phenomenon That Is Hillary Clinton's Emails|last=Joyce|first=Gemma|date=October 12, 2017|work=Brandwatch|accessdate=3 August 2018}}</ref> Clinton herself echoed the phrase in June 2018, when the Justice Department's Inspector General issued a [[Inspector General report on FBI and DOJ actions in the 2016 election|report]] on how the investigation of her use of email was conducted. It revealed that FBI Director Comey had used a personal email account to conduct FBI business; Clinton's response was a Twitter comment, "But my emails!"<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2018/06/14/hillary-clinton-justice-report-fbi/703886002/|title='But my emails': Hillary Clinton claps back after report reveals Comey used Gmail|last=Cummings|first=William|date=June 14, 2018|work=USA Today|accessdate=3 August 2018}}</ref>
===Republican response=== [[Chairman of the Republican National Committee|Republican National Committee chairman]] [[Reince Priebus]] said, in a statement regarding the June 30, 2015 email releases, "These emails ... are just the tip of the iceberg, and we will never get full disclosure until Hillary Clinton releases her secret server for an independent investigation."<ref name=LATimes2/> [[Trey Gowdy]] said on June 29, 2015, that he would press the State Department for a fuller accounting of Clinton's emails, after the Benghazi panel retrieved 15 additional emails to Sidney Blumenthal that the department had not provided to the Committee.<ref name=Memoli1>Memoli, Michael A. [http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-hillary-clinton-state-emails-20150629-story.html Next batch of Hillary Clinton's emails will be released], ''Los Angeles Times'', June 30, 2015.</ref>
On September 12, 2015, Republican Senators [[Charles Grassley]] and [[Ron Johnson (Wisconsin politician)|Ron Johnson]], chairmen of the Senate [[Senate Judiciary Committee|Judiciary]] and [[Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee|Homeland Security]] committees, respectively, said they would seek an independent review of the deleted emails, if they were recovered from Clinton's server, to determine if there were any government related items among those deleted.<ref name=WP0912/>
===Comparisons and media coverage=== Analyses by Columbia Journalism Review, the [[Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society|Berkman Klein Center]] for Internet and Society at Harvard University, and the [[Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy|Shorenstein Center]] at the Harvard Kennedy School show that the Clinton email controversy received more coverage in mainstream media outlets than any other topic during the 2016 presidential election.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /> The ''New York Times'' coverage of the email controversy was notoriously extensive; according to a Columbia Journalism Review analysis, "''in just six days, ''The New York Times'' ran as many cover stories about Hillary Clinton's emails as they did about all policy issues combined in the 69 days leading up to the election'' (and that does not include the three additional articles on October 18, and November 6 and 7, or the two articles on the emails taken from John Podesta)."<ref name=":4" /> In attempting to explain the lopsided coverage, the Columbia Journalism Review speculates, "In retrospect, it seems clear that the press in general made the mistake of assuming a Clinton victory was inevitable, and were setting themselves as credible critics of the next administration."<ref name=":4" />
[[Pundit|Media commentators]] drew comparisons of Clinton's email usage to past political controversies. ''Pacific Standard Magazine'' published an article in May 2015, comparing email controversy and her response to it with the [[Whitewater controversy|Whitewater]] investigation 20 years earlier.<ref name="PS031615">{{cite news|last1=Gerth|first1=Jeff|title=Hillary Clinton's Email Scandal Looks a Lot Like the Whitewater Investigation of 20 Years Ago|url=https://psmag.com/news/hillary-clintons-email-scandal-looks-a-lot-like-the-whitewater-investigation-of-20-years-ago|accessdate=October 13, 2015|work=Pacific Standard|date=March 16, 2015}}</ref>
In August 2015, ''Washington Post'' associate editor and [[investigative journalist]] [[Bob Woodward]], when asked about Clinton's handling of her emails, said they remind him of the [[Nixon White House tapes|Nixon tapes]] from the [[Watergate scandal]].<ref>[http://www.msnbc.com/morning-joe/watch/security-questions-linger-in-clinton-emails-508380739552 Security questions linger in Clinton emails], ''[[Morning Joe]]'', August 19, 2015.</ref> On March 9, 2015, liberal columnist and Clinton supporter [[Dana Milbank]] wrote that the email affair was "a needless, self-inflicted wound" brought about by "debilitating caution" in "trying to make sure an embarrassing e-mail or two didn't become public," which led to "obsessive secrecy." Milbank pointed out that Clinton herself had justifiably criticized the George W. Bush administration in 2007 for its "secret" White House email accounts.<ref name=CT3915>{{cite news|last1=Milbank|first1=Dana|title=Hillary Clinton, too cautious for her own good|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/hillary-clintons-debilitating-caution/2015/03/06/e3225638-c411-11e4-9ec2-b418f57a4a99_story.html|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=March 9, 2015}}</ref><ref name=GWBSalon>{{cite news|last1=Boehlert|first1=Eric|title=The George W. Bush email scandal the media has conveniently forgotten|url=http://www.salon.com/2015/03/12/the_george_w_bush_email_scandal_the_media_has_conveniently_forgotten_partner/|work=Salon|date=March 12, 2015|accessdate=July 5, 2016}}</ref>
On ''[[Fox News Sunday]]'', [[political analyst]] [[Juan Williams]] contrasted the [[media coverage]] of Clinton's emails to the coverage of the 2007 [[Bush White House email controversy]] which he claimed received "just about zero press coverage."<ref name=":7">{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/punditfact/statements/2015/mar/15/juan-williams/media-reaction-george-w-bushs-email-controversy|title=The media reaction to George W. Bush's email controversy|publisher=[[PolitiFact]]|date=March 15, 2015|accessdate=October 13, 2015|last=Carroll|first=Lauren}}</ref> PolitiFact found Williams' assertion to be "mostly false," concluding "We found hundreds of articles and television transcripts referencing the issue. Still, Williams has something of a point that compared to the extensive recent coverage of Clinton's use of private email, media coverage of the 2007 Bush White House email controversy was thin."<ref name=":7" />
The ''[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]'' published an editorial opining that "the only believable reason for the private server in her basement was to keep her emails out of the public eye by willfully avoiding freedom of information laws. No president, no secretary of state, no public official at any level is above the law.
