Terry's leadership is crucial to Chelsea, the game is now full of very, very quiet players |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |first=Harry |last=Redknapp |date=23 August 2015 |accessdate=13 May 2016}}</ref> he is considered to be one of the greatest central defenders of his generation.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2317994/The-best-20-England-defenders.html |title=The best 20 England defenders |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |first=David |last=Miller |date=31 July 2007}}</ref> Terry was named [[UEFA Club Football Awards|UEFA Club Defender of the Year]] in 2005, 2008 and 2009,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=1498485.html |title=UEFA Club Defender of the Year |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=2 November 2009}}</ref> [[PFA Players' Player of the Year]] in 2005,<ref name=pfa>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/4478329.stm |title=Terry claims player of year award |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 April 2005 |accessdate=20 December 2017}}</ref> and was included in the [[FIFPro]] [[FIFPro World XI|World XI]] for five consecutive seasons, from 2005 to 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/news/2005/lampard_and_terry_honoured |title=Lamps and Terry honoured |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=5 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140505161924/http://www.thefa.com/England/news/2005/lampard_and_terry_honoured |archivedate=5 May 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/5414328.stm |title=Ronaldinho regains FifPro crown |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 November 2006 |accessdate=16 December 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/7030442.stm |title=Kaka wins world players' accolade |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 October 2007 |accessdate=7 October 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/7681948.stm |title=Ronaldo wins world players' award |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 October 2008 |accessdate=27 October 2008}}</ref> He was also named in the all-star squad for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], the only English player to make the team.
Terry is Chelsea's most successful captain, having led them to five [[Premier League]] titles, four [[FA Cup]]s, three [[EFL Cup|League Cup]]s, one [[UEFA Europa League]] and one [[UEFA Champions League]] title since 2004. He is one of five players to have made [[List of Chelsea F.C. records and statistics#All-time appearances|over 500 appearances]] for Chelsea and is also the club's all-time highest scoring defender.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1575860 |title=After the whistle: Backs hitting the back of the net |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |date=2 March 2009 |accessdate=5 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140505161832/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1575860 |archivedate=5 May 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> In 2007, he became the first captain to lift the FA Cup at the new [[Wembley Stadium]] in Chelsea's 1–0 win over [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], and also the first player to score an international goal there, scoring a header in England's 1–1 draw with [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/news/2007/englandbrazil_matchreport |title=England come home |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=4 October 2007}}</ref> In his final season at Chelsea in 2017, he became the first ever player to captain a team to the Premier League title on five occasions.
Following his departure from Chelsea, Terry spent one season with [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] in the [[EFL Championship]] before retiring.
==Club career== ===Chelsea=== ====Early years==== Born in [[Barking, London|Barking]], London, Terry attended [[Eastbury Comprehensive School]]<ref>{{cite news |title=John Terry: Defender of the faith |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/john-terry-defender-of-the-faith-412513.html |newspaper=The Independent |date=19 August 2006 |location=London |first=James |last=Lawton}}</ref> and played for local [[Sunday league football|Sunday league]] team [[Senrab F.C.|Senrab]], which also featured future [[Premier League]] players [[Sol Campbell]], [[Jermain Defoe]], [[Bobby Zamora]], [[Ledley King]] and [[Jlloyd Samuel]].<ref name = "senrab">{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1378677/John-Terry-saves-Senrab-Seeing-faces-children-brilliant-says-club-secretary.html |title=John Terry saves Senrab: Seeing the faces of the children will be brilliant, says club secretary |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London |date=20 April 2011 |accessdate=24 December 2013 |first=Laurie |last=Whitwell}}{{Unreliable source?|date=June 2017}}</ref> As a boy, he initially was part of [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]'s youth system, joining them as a midfielder in 1991.<ref>Keogh, Frank (3 May 2010). [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/w/west_ham_utd/8650295.stm#seven "West Ham honour youth boss who nurtured £80m of talent"]. BBC Sport. Retrieved 3 May 2010.</ref> He moved to Chelsea at 14, playing for the club's youth and reserve teams. It was due to a shortage of central defenders that he was moved to centre-back, the position he plays today. After finishing school, he joined the club on a [[Youth Training Scheme|YTS]] at age 16 and signed professional terms a year later.<ref name=manforallseasons/>
Terry made his Chelsea debut on 28 October 1998 as a late substitute in a [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] tie with [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]; his first start came later that season in an [[FA Cup]] third-round match, a 2–0 win over [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]].{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} He spent a brief period on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] with [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] in 2000 to build up his first team experience and was the subject of interest from both Forest manager [[David Platt (footballer)|David Platt]] and [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] manager [[Steve Bruce]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,12876_5864456,00.html |title=Terry was almost a terrier |publisher=Sky Sports |date=16 January 2010 |accessdate=14 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ptt.cc/man/Chelsea/D70/DD67/D51F/M.1123831651.A.ABC.html |title=Bruce knows value of Terry |website=Sporting Life |date=28 March 2005 |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2011501 |title=The Thursday Interview: John Terry |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |date=1 April 2010 |accessdate=5 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140505161835/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2011501 |archivedate=5 May 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1436328 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612191125/https://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1436328 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 June 2018 |title=Ten Years Terry Talking |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |date=28 October 2008 |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref>
In 2002, Terry was involved in an altercation with a bouncer at a West London nightclub with Chelsea teammate [[Jody Morris]] and [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]]'s [[Des Byrne]], which led to him being charged with assault and [[affray]]. In August 2002, Terry was acquitted of the charges in court.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/england/2205505.stm |title=Footballers cleared over club brawl |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=10 September 2006 |date=22 August 2002}}</ref> During the affair, he was given a temporary ban from the [[England national football team|English national team]] by [[The Football Association]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/1768694.stm |title=Terry faces England exile |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 January 2002 |accessdate=27 September 2007}}</ref> Previously, along with Chelsea teammates [[Frank Lampard]], Jody Morris, [[Eiður Guðjohnsen]] and former teammate [[Frank Sinclair]], in September 2001 Terry was fined two weeks wages by Chelsea after drunkenly harassing grieving American tourists in the immediate aftermath of the [[September 11 attacks]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/1558855.stm |title=Chelsea stars fined for binge |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 September 2001 |accessdate=14 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/the-first-xi-of-shame-united-6948817.html |title=The First XI of Shame United |newspaper=Evening Standard |location=London |date=11 September 2001 |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref> During his early days at Chelsea, Terry shared a flat with [[Andrew Crofts (footballer)|Andrew Crofts]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/internationals/chelsea-fan-crofts-looks-to-hero-terry-for-welsh-inspiration-509721.html |title=Chelsea fan Crofts looks to hero Terry for Welsh inspiration |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=6 October 2005 |accessdate=14 June 2010 |first=Paul |last=Walker}}{{Dead link|date=May 2014}}</ref>
====First-team breakthrough==== Terry began to establish himself in the Chelsea first team from the [[2000–01 Chelsea F.C. season|2000–01 season]], making 23 starts and was voted the club's Player of the Year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/chelsea-article/article/1336454/title/player-stats |title=Historical stats |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |accessdate=5 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140611075437/http://www.chelseafc.com/chelsea-article/article/1336454/title/player-stats |archivedate=11 June 2014}}</ref> He continued his progress during [[2001–02 Chelsea F.C. season|2001–02]], becoming a regular in the defence alongside club captain and [[France national football team|France international]] [[Marcel Desailly]].{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} On 5 December 2001, he captained Chelsea for the first time, in a League match against [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sportskeeda.com/football/5-best-moments-from-john-terry-chelsea-career/2 |title=#4 Captaining the Chelsea Team |publisher=Sportskeeda |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref> Chelsea reached the [[FA Cup Final]], following wins against London rivals West Ham United and [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in the fourth and six rounds respectively, and [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in the semi-final – where Terry scored the only goal in a 1–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/fulham/3025919/Terry-is-all-gold-for-Chelsea.html |title=Terry is all gold for Chelsea |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref> A virus denied Terry a place in the starting line-up for the [[2002 FA Cup Final|final]], although he came on as a second-half substitute while Chelsea lost 2–0 to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/fa_cup/1959840.stm |title=Arsenal lift FA Cup |publisher=BBC |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref> In 2003–04 season, his performances led to him being handed the captain's armband by manager [[Claudio Ranieri]] when Desailly was out of the team.{{cn|date=October 2018}} He played well in the absence of the French international, forming a strong defensive partnership with [[William Gallas]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.caughtoffside.com/2015/03/28/ranking-john-terrys-five-best-defensive-partnerships-at-chelsea/3/ |title=Ranking John Terry's five best defensive partnerships at Chelsea |publisher=Caught Offside |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref>
====Captaincy and successes==== [[File:Champions 2004-5.jpg|thumb|upright|Terry (right of trophy) celebrates winning the [[2004–05 Premier League]] with [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]]]
Following Desailly's retirement, new Chelsea manager [[José Mourinho]] chose Terry as his club captain, a choice which was vindicated throughout the 2004–05 season as Chelsea won the Premier League title in record-breaking fashion with the best defensive record in [[English Football League|Football League]] history with the most clean sheets and the most points accrued.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2016/11/14/three-best-defensive-teams-in-premier-league-history-including-a |title=Three best defensive teams in Premier League history, including Arsenal |publisher=HITC |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref> He was voted [[PFA Players' Player of the Year|Player of the Year]] by his fellow professionals in England<ref name=pfa/> and scored eight goals, including a late winner against [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]], in the [[UEFA Champions League]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/columnists/henrywinter/2356406/Terry-supplies-a-sensational-finish.html |title=Terry supplies a sensational finish |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=9 March 2005 |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref> He was voted the best defender in the Champions League for the season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=318936.html |title=Best Defender 2005 |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref> In September 2005, he was selected as a member of the World XI at the [[FIFPro]] awards. The team was chosen by a vote of professional footballers based in 40 countries.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/SeniorTeam/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2005/09/Lampard_and_Terry_honoured.htm?WBCMODE=PresentationUnpublished%3Fpagedefault.htm |title=Lamps and Terry honoured |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=15 October 2006 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20081227021247/http://www.thefa.com/England/SeniorTeam/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2005/09/Lampard_and_Terry_honoured.htm?WBCMODE=PresentationUnpublished%3Fpagedefault.htm |archivedate=27 December 2008 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
[[File:John Terry original.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Terry celebrating after Chelsea won the [[2005–06 Premier League]]]]
Chelsea defended their Premier League title in [[2005–06 Chelsea F.C. season|2005–06]], earning 91 points, and confirming the title with a 3–0 victory against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/ranked-20-greatest-premier-league-sides-points-total?page=0%2C3 |title=Ranked! The 20 greatest Premier League sides by points total |publisher=FourFourTwo |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref>
In a match on 14 October 2006 against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], Terry had to take over in goal for Chelsea in the final minutes of the match after goalkeepers [[Petr Čech]] and [[Carlo Cudicini]] were injured and Chelsea had no substitutes remaining.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.getreading.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/flashback-chelseas-john-terry-goes-12027098 |title=Flashback: Chelsea's John Terry goes in goal against Reading FC |publisher=Getreading |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref> Terry kept a clean sheet as Chelsea held out to win 1–0, although he did not have a single save to make and his goalkeeping experience was limited to taking a free kick from inside the penalty area.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} On 5 November 2006, playing against Tottenham Hotspur, Terry was sent off for the first time in his Chelsea career after receiving two yellow cards as the Blues lost at [[White Hart Lane]] for the first time since 1987.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2006/nov/06/match.sport15 |title=Terry sees red as Lennon ends Tottenham's 16-year hoodoo |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref> Terry was charged with misconduct by the FA for questioning the integrity of match referee [[Graham Poll]] after the match.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/sport/misconduct-charge-for-terry-287348.html |title=Misconduct charge for Terry |newspaper=Irish Examiner |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref> On 10 January 2007, Terry was ordered to pay £10,000 for the inappropriate conduct after he changed his mind and pleaded [[guilt (law)|guilt]]y to the FA.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/terry-fined-16310000-but-escapes-ban-after-poll-comments-431452.html |title=Terry fined £10,000 but escapes ban after Poll comments |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref>
[[File:John Terry during a match vs Everton at Stamford Bridge in 2006.jpg|thumb|upright|Terry playing for Chelsea in 2006]]
In the 2006–07 season, Terry missed matches for Chelsea due to a recurring back problem. On 26 December 2006, José Mourinho stated that his captain might require surgery to fix the problem. In Terry's absence Chelsea drew 2–2 at home to both Reading and Fulham over Christmas, draws that were to prove crucial in the destiny of the Premier League title for that season.<ref>{{Cite book |title=The Official Chelsea FC Annual 2008 |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |publisher=Grange Communications Ltd |year=2007 |isbn= |location=Edinburagh |pages=7 |quote= |via=}}</ref> On 28 December, Chelsea released a press statement saying Terry had had back surgery: "The operation to remove a sequestrated lumbar [[intervertebral disc]] was successful."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/6215445.stm "Terry has surgery on back injury"] BBC Sport</ref> Although he was expected to return in the match against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]], which Chelsea won 3–2 thanks to a late goal from winger [[Arjen Robben]],<ref>{{Cite news |last=Mossop |first=James |title=Robben revives Chelsea |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2352806/Robben-revives-Chelsea.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=24 December 2006 |accessdate=27 September 2017}}</ref> Terry was missing once again, due to the recurring back problem.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} He made his return in Chelsea's 1–0 victory over Charlton Athletic on 3 February 2007 coming on in the 88th minute for Claude Makelele.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/6305409.stm |title=Charlton 0–1 Chelsea |publisher=BBC |accessdate=25 May 2018}}</ref> Terry played his first 90 minutes of football for nearly three months in Chelsea's 3–0 victory over [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] and received much applause from the Chelsea faithful. Didier Drogba scored two goals for Chelsea in that match, while the other goal came courtesy of an own goal from [[Abel Xavier]] of Middlesbrough.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/6327029.stm |title=Chelsea 3–0 Middlesbrough |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Saj |last=Chowdhury |date=10 February 2007 |accessdate=26 November 2016}}</ref>
Playing in the UEFA Champions League round of 16 away against [[FC Porto|Porto]], he suffered another injury, this time to his ankle, and was set to miss the [[2007 Football League Cup Final|2007 League Cup Final]] against Arsenal, but managed to recover from the injury within days and played in the final. During the second half of the match, at an attacking corner, he threw himself at the ball with a diving header; Arsenal's [[Abou Diaby]], in an attempt to clear the ball, kicked Terry in the face. Terry was unconscious for several minutes, at which point he nearly swallowed his tongue. He was carried off the field on a stretcher and immediately transferred to the [[University Hospital of Wales]]. Terry discharged himself the same day and returned to the [[Millennium Stadium]] to celebrate his team's 2–1 win. The only recollection he had of the second half is walking out onto the pitch and he did not remember the ten minutes he played prior to his injury.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/6395301.stm |title=Terry recovers after head injury |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 February 2007 |accessdate=26 February 2007}}</ref> He went on to lead Chelsea to the [[2006–07 UEFA Champions League#Semi-finals|semi-final]] of the [[2006–07 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]], the third time in four years that Chelsea had made it to the final four of the competition.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2008/matches/round=15107/match=301907/postmatch/quotes/index.html |title=Grant relief after Fenerbahçe fright |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref> In May 2007, Terry captained Chelsea in the [[2007 FA Cup Final]], in the first FA Cup final at the new [[Wembley Stadium]].{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
Despite failing to agree terms to a new contract immediately following 2006–07, Terry stated on several occasions that he had no intention of leaving Chelsea. In late July, he signed a new five-year contract with a base salary of between £131,000<ref>{{cite news |date=27 July 2007 |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11668/2632304/lampard-gets-pay-boost |title=Lampard gets pay boost |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=5 May 2014 |first=Chris |last=Harvey}}</ref> and £135,000<ref name="Dominic Fifield">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/jul/28/newsstory.sport1 |title=Terry becomes highest-paid player in Premier League history |newspaper=The Guardian |first=Dominic |last=Fifield |location=London |date=28 July 2007 |accessdate=29 September 2016}}</ref> per week, making him the highest-paid player in the Premier League at the time.<ref name="Dominic Fifield"/>
[[File:John George Terry.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Terry playing for Chelsea in 2008]]
On 16 December 2007, whilst playing against Arsenal, while going to clear a ball Terry's foot was stepped on by [[Emmanuel Eboué]] and Terry had suffered 3 broken bones in his foot.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/dec/18/newsstory.chelsea |title=Terry faces up to three months out with broken bones in foot |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref> He was expected to be out for at least three months but made a speedy recovery and managed to captain Chelsea to the [[2008 Football League Cup Final|2008 League Cup Final]] against Tottenham, which Chelsea lost 2–1.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2291848/FA-Cup-John-Terry-returns-to-Chelsea-squad.html |title=FA Cup: John Terry returns to Chelsea squad |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/7256729.stm |title=Tottenham 2–1 Chelsea |publisher=BBC |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref> On 11 May 2008, whilst playing in the last league match of the season against Bolton, he collided with goalkeeper Petr Čech and suffered a partially dislocated elbow, which was eventually put back into place en route to the hospital.{{cn|date=October 2018}} This injury did not prevent him playing in the [[2008 UEFA Champions League Final]] against Manchester United.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2300954/Champions-League-final-John-Terry-elbows-out-expert-advice-to-bounce-back-for-Chelsea.html |title=Champions League final: John Terry elbows out expert advice to bounce back for Chelsea |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref> The match went to [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalties]], and Terry missed a penalty which would have won Chelsea the match (and the Champions League).<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2301208/Champions-League-final-Tears-for-John-Terry-and-Chelsea-after-cruel-ending.html |title=Champions League final: Tears for John Terry and Chelsea after cruel ending |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref> His standing leg slipped as he took his kick, and the ball missed the goal.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3015920/Chelsea-captain-John-Terry-haunted-penalty-miss-2008-Champions-League-final-against-Manchester-United.html |title=Chelsea captain John Terry is still haunted by his penalty miss in the 2008 Champions League final against Manchester United |newspaper=Daily Mail |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref> Chelsea lost the shootout 6–5, which Terry reacted to by breaking down in tears.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/may/22/championsleague.chelsea2 |title=Terry was a stand-in for key penalty miss |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref> On 28 August 2008, Terry was awarded the Defender of The Year award from [[UEFA]] at the Champions League group stage draw in [[Monaco]], together with Frank Lampard and Petr Čech, who received the award for their respective positions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/8/main/2008/08/28/838526/chelsea-ronaldo-win-champions-league-awards |title=Chelsea, Ronaldo Win Champions League Awards |publisher=Goal.com |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref>
On 13 September 2008, Terry received the first straight [[Red card (sports)|red card]] of his career against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] for rugby-tackling [[Jô]]. However, this was later rescinded on appeal.<ref>{{cite web |title=John Terry red card rescinded; Chelsea captain available for Manchester United |website=Starting Eleven: European and World Soccer Blog |url=http://startingeleven.blogspot.com/2008/09/john-terry-red-card-rescinded-chelsea.html |accessdate=28 December 2008}}</ref> Despite being a defender, he occasionally scores important goals for Chelsea, such as in the [[2008–09 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] Group A home match against [[A.S. Roma|Roma]].<ref>{{cite news |title=John Terry rises to the challenge as Chelsea go clear with Roma win in Champions League |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/leagues/premierleague/chelsea/3243463/John-Terry-rises-to-the-challenge-as-Chelsea-go-clear-with-Roma-win-in-Champions-League-Football.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |last=Ley |first=John |accessdate=28 December 2008 |date=22 October 2008}}</ref> However, Chelsea went on to lose the away leg 3–1.<ref>{{cite news |last=Fifield |first=Dominic |title=Blues on red alert as messy Mikel sums up limp show |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/nov/05/championsleague-roma |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=4 November 2008 |accessdate=29 September 2016}}</ref>
====Double and Champions League==== [[File:Ancellotidouble.jpg|thumb|upright|Terry (right) celebrates winning the double with Chelsea in 2010]]
In July 2009, Manchester City made a third bid for Terry, but Chelsea coach [[Carlo Ancelotti]] insisted Terry would remain at Chelsea.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_5445798,00.html |title=Carlo expects Terry stay |date=21 July 2009 |accessdate=21 July 2009 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> He made his debut for the new season against Premier League team [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]], a match Chelsea won.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/8199453.stm |title=Chelsea 2–1 Hull |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref> On 8 November 2009, Terry scored the decisive goal in Chelsea's match against Manchester United at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] to preserve their perfect home record for the season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/9/english-football/2009/11/08/1612659/chelsea-1-0-manchester-united-john-terry-header-wins-battle |title=Chelsea 1–0 Manchester United: John Terry Header Wins Battle Of Stamford Bridge |publisher=Goal.com |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref>
On 9 May 2010, Terry captained Chelsea as they won their fourth Premier League title after an 8–0 win against Wigan Athletic at Stamford Bridge.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/8663686.stm |title=Chelsea 8–0 Wigan |date=9 May 2010 |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Phil |last=McNulty |accessdate=10 May 2010}}</ref> A week later, on 15 May 2010, Terry captained Chelsea as he won his fourth FA Cup medal, defeating [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] in the [[2010 FA Cup Final|final]] by 1–0 at Wembley Stadium.<ref>{{cite news |first=Kevin |last=McCarra |title=Didier Drogba wins FA Cup but Champions League is Chelsea's goal |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/may/17/chelsea-portsmouth-fa-cup-final |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=17 May 2010 |accessdate=29 September 2016}}</ref>
On 31 December 2011, in a home match against Aston Villa, Terry captained the Chelsea team for the 400th time of his career, a record for the club.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/match/60383/chelsea-fc-vs-aston-villa/play-by-play |title=Chelsea FC vs Aston Villa live commentary |publisher=Goal.com |date=31 December 2011 |accessdate=16 January 2012}}</ref>
Terry was the world's third best passer in 2011 for players with over 1,000 passes, with a 91.6% pass accuracy rate. Only Barcelona player [[Xavi]] (93.0%) and [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] player [[Leon Britton]] (93.3%) were better.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sport.uk.msn.com/blog/talking-tactics-blogpost.aspx?post=26cdeb4c-c467-4fe3-b412-f8412cd8d9d2&_nwpt=1 |title=The Xavi from the Valley Talking tactics football blogpost, MSN Sport UK |publisher=MSN}}</ref>
[[File:John Terry Champions League Winner parade.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Terry celebrating Chelsea's [[2011–12 UEFA Champions League]] triumph]]
On 24 April 2012, Terry was sent off for violent conduct after driving a knee into Barcelona's [[Alexis Sánchez]] in an off-the-ball incident in the [[2011–12 UEFA Champions League]] [[2011–12 UEFA Champions League#Semi-finals|semi-final]] at the [[Camp Nou]]. Chelsea's 3–2 aggregate victory over the holders qualified them for the [[2012 UEFA Champions League Final|final]] against [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]], for which Terry would be suspended. Terry later apologised for letting his teammates and Chelsea fans down.<ref>{{cite news |title=John Terry apologises to Chelsea's fans after dismissal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/17835147 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=30 April 2012 |date=25 April 2012}}</ref> Terry scored his sixth league goal of the season, seventh in all competitions, in the final match of the season, a 2–1 victory over already-relegated Blackburn. The goal meant that it was Terry's most prolific season and he told the Chelsea website, "I am delighted with seven... It's always good to end a league season with a win."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2771336 |title=Latest Chelsea Football Club |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140611093957/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2771336 |archivedate=11 June 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
Even though Terry was suspended for the Champions League Final, along with teammates [[Ramires]], [[Branislav Ivanović]] and [[Raul Meireles]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/sports/2012/05/17/stoppage-time-champions-league-final-tarnished-by-suspensions/ |publisher=Fox News Channel |title=Stoppage Time: Champions League final tarnished by suspensions |date=17 May 2012}}</ref> he took part in celebrations at the final whistle after Chelsea triumphed 4–3 on penalty kicks, with striker [[Didier Drogba]] netting the decisive penalty.<ref>{{cite news |last=White |first=Duncan |title=Bayern Munich 1 Chelsea 1 aet; (Chelsea win 4–3 on pens): match report |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/champions-league/9272510/Bayern-Munich-1-Chelsea-1-aet-Chelsea-win-4-3-on-pens-match-report.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=19 May 2012 |location=London}}</ref>
====Later career==== Terry was snubbed by [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] defender [[Anton Ferdinand]] in the pre-match handshake against QPR.<ref>{{cite web |last=Phillips |first=Owen |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19528273 |title=QPR 0–0 Chelsea |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 September 2012}}</ref> Terry was banned for four matches when he was found guilty of racially abusing Ferdinand.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19723020 |title=John Terry banned and fined by FA over Anton Ferdinand incident |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 September 2012}}</ref>
On 11 November 2012, in his first match back from the four-match ban, Terry scored his 50th goal for Chelsea against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20196350 |title=Chelsea 1–1 Liverpool |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 November 2012 |accessdate=20 December 2017}}</ref> He went off injured in the 39th minute of the same match and was suspected to have ligament damage on his right knee, but a scan the next day showed that there was "no significant damage."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20291156 |title=John Terry: Chelsea skipper out for 'approximately three weeks' |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 November 2012 |accessdate=20 December 2017}}</ref> On 7 December 2012, new Chelsea manager [[Rafael Benítez]] confirmed Terry would not be back from injury in time to play in the [[2012 FIFA Club World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20639295 |title=John Terry: Chelsea skipper will miss Club World Cup |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 December 2012 |accessdate=20 December 2017}}</ref> Terry's knee injury kept him out of action for 16 first-team matches in total, including the Club World Cup defeat.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} He made a 45-minute comeback for Chelsea's under-21 team on 10 January,<ref>{{cite news |title=John Terry makes comeback from knee injury for Chelsea Under-21 side |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/jan/10/john-terry-comeback-chelsea |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |agency=Press Association |date=10 January 2013 |accessdate=29 September 2016}}</ref> before returning to the first team in a 2–2 draw away to [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] in the [[2012–13 FA Cup#Fourth Round Proper|FA Cup]] fourth round on 24 January.{{cn|date=October 2018}}
[[File:John Terry Didier Drogba'14.JPG|thumb|upright|Terry (right) playing for Chelsea in 2014]]
On 17 April 2013, Terry scored twice in the [[West London derby|derby match]] against Fulham that ended 3–0.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea/10002311/Chelsea-interim-manager-Rafael-Benitez-delighted-with-John-Terry-on-return-against-Fulhan-after-being-dropped.html |title=Chelsea interim manager Rafael Benítez delighted with John Terry on return against Fulham after being dropped |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=17 April 2013 |location=London}}</ref> On 13 May 2014, Terry signed a new one-year deal with the Blues.<ref>{{cite web |title=Terry signs |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/3829568/title/terry-signs |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |date=13 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140515012851/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/3829568/title/terry-signs |archivedate=15 May 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
On 18 October 2014, Terry captained Chelsea for the 500th time against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].{{cn|date=October 2018}} In the next match, on 21 October, Terry scored in Chelsea's record Champions League win against Slovenian team [[NK Maribor|Maribor]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29362738 |title=Chelsea 6–0 NK Maribor |publisher=BBC sport |date=21 October 2014 |first=Gary |last=Rose}}</ref> Later, he scored Chelsea's fastest-ever goal in the Champions League by heading in a goal after 90 seconds against [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Jurejko |first=Jonathan |title=FC Schalke 04 0–5 Chelsea |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29363005 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 November 2014 |accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref>
[[File:Chelsea 3 Sunderland 1 Champions! (17975567060).jpg|thumb|left|upright|Terry (right) with the [[2014–15 Premier League]] trophy]]
In the [[2015 Football League Cup Final|League Cup]] final on 1 March 2015, Terry opened the scoring was named Man of the Match in Chelsea's 2–0 victory over Tottenham.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/31572594 |title=Chelsea 2–0 Tottenham Hotspur |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Phil |last=McNulty |date=1 March 2015 |accessdate=27 April 2015}}</ref> On 26 March, Terry signed one-year extension to his contract.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/mar/26/chelsea-john-terry-new-contract |title=John Terry signs new Chelsea contract until end of 2015–16 season |newspaper=The Guardian |first=Dominic |last=Fifield |location=London |date=26 March 2015 |accessdate=29 September 2016}}</ref> On 26 April, Terry, along with five of his Chelsea teammates, was voted into the PFA Premier League Team of the Year.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/32472834 |title=Chelsea's Eden Hazard named PFA Player of the Year |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 April 2015 |accessdate=27 April 2015}}</ref> On 29 April, Terry became the joint highest-scoring defender in the Premier League with 38 goals, having scored the second goal in a 3–1 win over [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].{{cn|date=October 2018}} On 10 May, Terry surpassed [[David Unsworth]] as the highest-scoring defender in the Premier League after scoring his 39th in the opening five minutes against Liverpool, an eventual 1–1 draw.{{cn|date=October 2018}}
On 23 August 2015, Terry received his first league red card for over five years, being dismissed for a foul on [[Salomón Rondón]] in a 3–2 win at [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Magowan |first=Alistair |title=West Bromwich Albion 2–3 Chelsea |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/33950789 |accessdate=23 August 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 August 2015}}</ref> On 15 January 2016, Terry scored an own goal in the 50th minute as well as his first goal of the season in the 98th minute, earning a 3–3 draw against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Chelsea 3–3 Everton |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/35270645 |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Neil |last=Johnston |date=15 January 2016 |accessdate=15 January 2016}}</ref> On 1 February 2016, Terry announced that he would leave Chelsea in the summer of 2016, saying "It's not going to be a fairytale ending."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/john-terry-stunned-as-chelsea-decide-to-ship-out-skipper-34411809.html |title=John Terry stunned as Chelsea decide to ship out skipper |newspaper=Irish Independent |location=Dublin |date=31 January 2016 |accessdate=8 April 2017}}</ref>
Although Terry announced in February that there were no talks held to discuss a new contract, on 18 May 2016, Terry signed a new one-year contract to remain at Chelsea until the end of the [[2016–17 Chelsea F.C. season|2016–17 season]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36320583 |title=Chelsea's John Terry signs new one-year deal at Stamford Bridge |date=18 May 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=18 May 2016}}</ref> Ten days previously, Terry had been sent off in a 3–2 loss to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] at the [[Stadium of Light]] in what was widely believed to have been his final appearance for the club.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/07/john-terry-red-card-last-game-for-chelsea |title=John Terry red card rules him out of Chelsea's final two games |date=8 May 2016 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London}}</ref>
During [[Antonio Conte]]'s first press conference as the new Chelsea manager, Conte confirmed that Terry will remain the club captain.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11668/10501503/john-terry-will-remain-chelsea-captain-antonio-conte-confirms |title=John Terry will remain Chelsea captain, Antonio Conte confirms |date=14 July 2016 |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=14 July 2016}}</ref> On 11 September 2016, during the closing minutes of the match against Swansea City, Terry suffered an ankle injury and required crutches to leave the pitch after the final whistle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11668/10574754/john-terry-leaves-liberty-stadium-on-crutches-after-chelsea-draw-with-swansea |title=John Terry leaves Liberty Stadium on crutches after Chelsea draw with Swansea |date=12 September 2016 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref>
On 8 January 2017, making his first start for Chelsea since an [[2016–17 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]] defeat to West Ham United in October 2016, Terry was given a straight red card for a foul on [[Lee Angol]] as Chelsea beat [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] 4–1 in the [[2016–17 FA Cup|FA Cup]] third round.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/sport/football/john-terry-sent-off-but-pedro-willian-batshuayi-ensure-chelsea-beat-peterborough/news-story/b0d151fb50bf09d108006b8501a9bcd5 |title=John Terry sent off but Pedro, Willian, Batshuayi ensure Chelsea beat Peterborough |date=9 January 2017 |newspaper=Adelaide Advertiser}}</ref> On 17 April, he announced that he would be leaving Chelsea at the end of the 2016–17 season.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/john-terry-to-leave-chelsea-end-of-the-season-epl-premier-league-news-latest-next-club-a7687706.html |title=John Terry to leave Chelsea at the end of the season as he will continue playing career elsewhere |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |first=Jack |last=De Menezes |date=17 April 2017 |accessdate=17 April 2017}}</ref> After Chelsea celebrated their Premier League victory, Terry played his 717th and final match for Chelsea on 21 May in a 5–1 home win over Sunderland, coming off in the 28th minute (the substitution board went up in the 26th minute, the same as that of his shirt number),<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39912027 |title=Chelsea 5–1 Sunderland |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Phil |last=Dawkes |date=21 May 2017 |accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref> and received a guard of honour from his teammates.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39994193 |title=John Terry: 26th-minute substitution was my idea says departing Chelsea captain |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 May 2017 |accessdate=21 May 2017}}</ref>
===Aston Villa===
[[File:2018 EFL Championship play-off Final (cropped) 2.jpg|thumb|upright|Terry lining up for [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] in the [[2018 EFL Championship play-off Final|2018 Championship play-off Final]]]]
On 3 July 2017, Terry signed a one-year contract with [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club Aston Villa on a free transfer.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40476873 |title=John Terry: Aston Villa sign ex-Chelsea & England captain |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 July 2017 |accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref> He was appointed as the captain for the [[2017–18 Aston Villa F.C. season|2017–18 season]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Gregg |last=Evans |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/john-terry-named-aston-villa-13336828 |title=John Terry named as Aston Villa captain for 2017/18 season |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=15 July 2017 |accessdate=3 September 2017}}</ref> He made his debut for Aston Villa on 5 August 2017 in a 1–1 home draw with Hull City in the Championship.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/08/05/aston-villa-1-hull-city-1-john-terry-makes-debut-underwhelming/ |title=Aston Villa 1 Hull City 1: John Terry makes debut in underwhelming home performance |first=Jon |last=Culley |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=5 August 2017 |accessdate=24 May 2018}}</ref> Terry scored his only goal for Aston Villa in a 2–1 victory over Fulham in the Championship on 21 October 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/john-terry-aston-villa-chelsea-13794151 |title=John Terry scores first Aston Villa goal since joining from Chelsea |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref>
On 30 May 2018, Terry left Aston Villa after the club failed to gain promotion to the Premier League as they lost 1–0 against Fulham in the [[2018 EFL Championship play-off Final|Championship play-off final]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44308522 |title=John Terry: Aston Villa captain leaves after play-off final defeat |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 May 2018 |accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref>
In September 2018, Terry underwent a medical with [[FC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moscow]], but declined their offer of a contract, citing family reasons.<ref>https://www.instagram.com/p/BnofRuRhgEP/</ref> He announced his retirement from playing on 7 October 2018.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45780152 |title=John Terry: Former England and Chelsea captain retires from football |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 October 2018 |accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:John-Terry-England-2010.jpg|thumb|upright|Terry playing for [[England national football team|England]] in 2010]]
Terry made his England debut in June 2003 against [[Serbia and Montenegro national football team|Serbia and Montenegro]], and started his first match for England on 20 August 2003 at [[Portman Road]], [[Ipswich]], in a friendly against [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]]. England won 3–1.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/england/3163143.stm |title=Beckham inspires England win |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 August 2003 |accessdate=24 May 2018}}</ref> His main central defensive partner had been [[Rio Ferdinand]].{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} He played for his country at [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]], and England Manager [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]] stated that Terry was the first-choice centre-back, ahead of Sol Campbell.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
In 2005 during a [[FIFA World Cup]] qualifying match against [[Poland national football team|Poland]], Terry wore England's captain armband, replacing [[Michael Owen]] as captain after the latter was substituted.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/gallery/2010/feb/05/john-terry-career-in-pictures |title=John Terry's international career in pictures |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=24 May 2018}}</ref>
He has cemented his place in the England squad by being selected for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2006/teams/england/4983618.stm |title=Walcott & Lennon in England squad |publisher=BBC |accessdate=24 May 2018}}</ref> In a warm-up match for that tournament against [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]] on 30 May 2006, Terry scored his first goal for England, the team's second in a 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-india/slideshow/468/3 |title=3. First goal v Hungary, 2006 |publisher=Goal.com |accessdate=24 May 2018}}</ref> Despite an injury scare in a [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendly]] against [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]], he recovered to play in England's opening fixture against [[Paraguay national football team|Paraguay]], a 1–0 victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2006/4852606.stm |title=England 1–0 Paraguay |publisher=BBC |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref> In the next match against [[Trinidad and Tobago national football team|Trinidad and Tobago]], [[Carlos Edwards]] beat England's [[Paul Robinson (footballer, born 1979)|Paul Robinson]] to a cross and as [[Stern John]] bundled a header towards the goal, Terry cleared the ball off the line with an overhead kick.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/15/sports/15iht-web.0615england.1981908.html |title=England 2, Trinidad and Tobago 0: Crouch uses head to atone for lapses – Sports – International Herald Tribune |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref> In the quarter-final match against Portugal, Terry played the entire match, but England lost on penalties and he was left in tears with his fellow players.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Six days later, he was the only English player to be named in the tournament's all-star squad.<ref name=WC2006>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2006/5158636.stm |title=Terry makes Fifa World Cup squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 July 2006 |accessdate=10 September 2006}}</ref>
On 10 August 2006, [[Steve McClaren]] named John Terry as the England captain, succeeding [[David Beckham]]. McClaren said, "Choosing a captain is one of the most important decisions a coach has to make. I'm certain I've got the right man in John Terry. I'm convinced he will prove to be one of the best captains England has ever had."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/4780745.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Terry named new England skipper |date=10 August 2006 |accessdate=3 April 2010}}</ref> Terry scored a goal on his debut as the England captain, in a friendly international against [[Greece national football team|Greece]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/4794867.stm |title=England 4–0 Greece |publisher=BBC |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref> This was the first goal of the match and also the first goal during McClaren's reign as manager.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} However, with Terry as captain, England did not qualify for [[UEFA Euro 2008]] – their first absence from a tournament finals since the [[1994 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/sports/sounders/england-loses-to-croatia-fails-to-qualify-for-euro-2008/ |title=England loses to Croatia, fails to qualify for Euro 2008 |newspaper=The Seattle Times |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref> Midway through the qualification campaign, Terry had accepted that he would "bear full responsibility" should England fail to qualify.<ref>{{cite news |date=6 June 2007 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6725433.stm |title=Terry will take blame for failure |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=2 February 2008}}</ref>
On 1 June 2007, Terry became the first player in the senior England team to score an international goal at the new Wembley Stadium when he scored England's goal from a header in the box after a free kick cross by David Beckham in a 1–1 draw with Brazil.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/6712043.stm |title=England 1–1 Brazil |publisher=BBC |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref> Almost a year later, he scored a similar headed goal once again from a free kick cross by David Beckham to put England 1–0 up against the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] on 28 May 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2008-05-29/terry-scores-as-england-downs-us/2452144?pfm=ms |title=Terry scores as England downs US |publisher=ABC |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref>
Terry was confirmed as the England captain in August, and captained England in qualifying for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]].{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} During his first match after being reinstated as the permanent England captain he was given a torrid time by [[Milan Baroš]] and was turned far too easily when Baros scored the first goal for the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]].{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} The match ended 2–2 with [[Joe Cole]] scoring a fortunate equaliser for England in the 92nd minute of the match.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} He scored his first competitive England goal against [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]] in the qualifiers for the World Cup, grabbing a late winner after earlier giving away a free kick which saw [[Andriy Shevchenko]] equalise for Ukraine.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
On 5 February 2010, following [[#Extramarital affair allegations|allegations regarding Terry's private life]], England manager [[Fabio Capello]] announced that Terry was removed as the captain of the England team.<ref name=dropped>{{cite news |url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/news/latest-news/top-stories/john-terry-no-comment-from-fa-over-future-as-england-captain-1-2238887 |title=Breaking: John Terry dropped as England captain |newspaper=Yorkshire Evening Post |location=Leeds |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref> He was replaced by fellow defender Rio Ferdinand.<ref name=strips>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8495604.stm |title=Fabio Capello strips John Terry of England captaincy |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=5 February 2010 |date=5 February 2010}}</ref>
At the 2010 FIFA World Cup, England started with two draws against the United States and [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]], which received heavy criticism from the English media.<ref>{{cite news |first=Kevin |last=McCarra |title=England labour to goalless draw with Algeria |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/jun/18/england-algeria-world-cup-2010-match-report |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=18 June 2006 |accessdate=29 September 2016}}</ref>
[[File:Mario Balotelli and John Terry England-Italy Euro 2012.JPG|thumb|upright|Terry (right) playing for England at [[UEFA Euro 2012]]]]
Two days after the Algeria match in a media interview, Terry hinted at dissatisfaction with Capello's team selection and stated that the players were bored with little to do in the evenings at their training base; he also said that a clear-the-air team meeting would take place that evening.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2010/8751854.stm |title=Fabio Capello hits out at John Terry's 'big mistake' |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 June 2010 |accessdate=20 December 2017}}</ref> The next day, Capello responded by saying that Terry had made "a very big mistake" in challenging his authority to the media.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/jun/21/world-cup-2010-fabio-capello-john-terry |title=World Cup 2010: Fabio Capello berates John Terry for 'very big mistake' |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |agency=Press Association |date=21 June 2010 |accessdate=29 September 2016}}</ref>
On 19 March 2011, Capello reinstated Terry as England captain following a long-term injury to previous captain Rio Ferdinand.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/3284/euro-2012/2011/03/19/2402787/chelseas-john-terry-reinstated-as-england-captain-on |title=Chelsea's John Terry reinstated as England captain on permanent basis |publisher=Goal.com |first=Nathan |last=Lowe |date=19 March 2011 |accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> On 3 February 2012, with Terry due to stand trial due to [[#Racial abuse allegations|allegations that Terry had racially abused]] QPR's Anton Ferdinand, the FA stripped Terry of the England captaincy for the second time. This led to Capello resigning.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/feb/03/john-terry-stripped-england-captaincy-racism |title=John Terry stripped of England captaincy by FA ahead of racism trial |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=3 February 2012 |accessdate=29 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/16941457 |title=Capello quits as England manager |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 February 2012 |accessdate=8 February 2012}}</ref>
Terry was named in new manager [[Roy Hodgson]]'s squad for [[UEFA Euro 2012]] while Rio Ferdinand was left out, leading to heavy speculation that this was to avoid potential conflict due to Terry's upcoming trial for racially abusing Ferdinand's brother Anton.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/18093759 |title=Rio Ferdinand 'gutted' at England Euro 2012 snub |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 May 2012}}</ref> Terry played 90 minutes in all four of England's matches at the Euros.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.whoscored.com/Players/70/History/John-Terry |title=John Terry – History |website=whoscored.com |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref>
Terry announced on 23 September 2012 he had retired from international football.<ref>{{cite web |title=John Terry retires from England duty |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19695430 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=23 September 2012}}</ref>
==Coaching career== On 10 October 2018, Terry was appointed assistant manager of Aston Villa with newly appointed [[Dean Smith (footballer, born 1971)|Dean Smith]] as manager.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.iambirmingham.co.uk/2018/10/10/aston-villa-appoint-dean-smith-new-manager-john-terry-assistant-coach/|title=Aston Villa appoint Dean Smith as new manager and John Terry as Assistant Coach {{!}} I Am Birmingham|date=2018-10-10|work=I Am Birmingham|access-date=2018-10-10}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/oct/10/aston-villa-manager-search-dean-smith-brentford-john-terry-no2|title=Dean Smith appointed Aston Villa manager with John Terry as assistant|last=James|first=Stuart|date=2018-10-10|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-10}}</ref><ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45818275</ref>
==Sponsorship== On the UK version of ''[[Pro Evolution Soccer 6]]'', he appears on the front cover with [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] international [[Adriano (footballer, born 1982)|Adriano]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.qj.net/psp/news/john-terry-the-face-of-pro-evolution-soccer-6.html |title=John Terry: The Face of Pro Evolution Soccer 6 |publisher=Qj.net |accessdate=14 June 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929110716/http://www.qj.net/psp/news/john-terry-the-face-of-pro-evolution-soccer-6.html |archivedate=29 September 2011 |deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://acegamez.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/12/Pro-Evolution-Soccer-6-Pack.jpg |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918010048/http://acegamez.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/12/Pro-Evolution-Soccer-6-Pack.jpg |archivedate=18 September 2010 |title=Pro Evolution Soccer 6 |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref>
==Family and personal life== [[File:John Terry with mascots.jpg|thumb|upright|Terry (centre) with children mascots in 2009]]
He Is married to Toni (née Poole).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.7msport.com/news/newsdata/20100206/43548.shtml |title=John Terry: Notes on a scandal |publisher=Kickette.com |date=5 February 2010 |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref> In 2009, Terry was named "Dad of the Year" after he came top of a poll of UK adults in a [[Daddies]] Sauce survey.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/john-terry-voted-dad-of-the-year-1709667.html |title=John Terry was voted 'Dad of the Year' |last=Bird |first=Daniel |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=19 June 2009 |accessdate=29 January 2010}}</ref>
Terry's older brother, [[Paul Terry (footballer)|Paul]] (born 1979), is a former professional footballer, having notably played for [[Dagenham & Redbridge F.C.|Dagenham & Redbridge]] and [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]].
Terry was a Manchester United supporter growing up.<ref name=manforallseasons>{{cite news |last=Garfield |first=Simon |title=The man for all seasons |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2006/may/07/newsstory.sport6 |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |date=7 May 2006 |accessdate=29 September 2016}}</ref>
Terry is one of a very small group of footballers to have been paid more than £1 million for their autobiography.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Why+Faria+Alam+is+a+not-so-sweet+FA.-a0137244187 |title=Why Faria Alam is a not-so-sweet FA. – Free Online Library |publisher=Thefreelibrary.com |accessdate=14 June 2010}}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> His deal with publisher [[HarperCollins]] was negotiated in 2004 by [[Chris Nathaniel]] of NVA Management.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Castles |first1=Duncan |title=Chelsea want John Terry to put up or shut up |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/premier_league/chelsea/article6689692.ece |accessdate=1 July 2010 |newspaper=The Times |date=12 July 2009 |first2=Jonathan |last2=Northcroft |location=London}}</ref>
In 2016, Terry paid the £1,600 funeral costs for an eight-year-old Chelsea fan with [[leukemia]] who died from an unsuccessful [[bone marrow transplantation]].<ref>{{cite news |title=John Terry pays for young Chelsea fan's funeral |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-cambridgeshire-36014630 |date=11 April 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=11 April 2016}}</ref>

ground."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/8423968.stm |title=Chelsea back John Terry over newspaper allegations |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 December 2009 |accessdate=2 November 2011}}</ref>

====Racial abuse allegations==== {{Further|R v Terry}}
On 2 November 2011, Terry was placed under police investigation following an allegation of racist abuse made at Anton Ferdinand during a match versus Queens Park Rangers.<ref>{{cite news |last=Fifield |first=Dominic |title=Police launch investigation into John Terry-Anton Ferdinand incident |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/nov/01/police-john-terry-anton-ferdinand |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=1 November 2011 |accessdate=29 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2011/11/01/john-terry_n_1069720.html |title=John Terry: Metropolitan Police confirm investigation into England captain's conduct |newspaper=The Huffington Post |date=1 November 2011 |accessdate=20 November 2011}}</ref> Video footage circulated on the internet led to accusations that Terry called Ferdinand a "fucking black [[cunt]]." In response to the video footage, Terry claimed that he was actually asking Ferdinand, "Oi, Anton, do you think I called you a black cunt?"<ref>{{cite news |first=Dominic |last=Fifield |title=John Terry to learn fate after alleged racial slur of Anton Ferdinand |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/oct/24/john-terry-anton-ferdinand-chelsea-qpr |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=24 October 2011 |accessdate=29 September 2016}}</ref> On 25 November 2011, Terry was interviewed under caution by the police.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-15932362 |title=John Terry 'interviewed by police' over race allegations |publisher=BBC News |date=28 November 2011}}</ref> On 21 December 2011, he was charged with using racist language by the [[Crown Prosecution Service]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-16284813 |title=John Terry to be charged over Anton Ferdinand race row |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 December 2011 |accessdate=21 December 2011}}</ref> On 3 February 2012, The Football Association stripped Terry of his England captaincy for the second time, stating that Terry would not captain the national team until the racial abuse allegations against him were resolved.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/16866149 |title=John Terry: FA strips England captaincy from Chelsea defender |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011}}</ref>
When the trial began in July 2012, Terry entered a not guilty plea and was acquitted of the charge on 13 July 2012. The court established that neither Ferdinand nor anyone else had heard Terry's words, but Terry himself admitted that he had directed the words "fucking black cunt" and "fucking knobhead" at Ferdinand, which was affirmed by two expert lip readers from video evidence. Terry maintained that he used the words as a form of [[sarcasm]] and that he was questioning what he thought had been an allegation of racism from Ferdinand; neither lip reader was able to "identify whether the statement was made as a question or in what type of voice it was said." Justice Riddle concluded that while there was no doubt Terry had uttered those words in anger, "it is impossible to be sure exactly what were the words spoken by [Terry] at the relevant time" and that there was a lack of evidence to prove beyond a doubt that Terry had used them as an insult instead of "a challenge to what he believed had been said to him." The court therefore found Terry not guilty.<ref>[http://www.judiciary.gov.uk/Resources/JCO/Documents/Judgments/r-v-john-terry.pdf] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120713143737/http://www.judiciary.gov.uk/Resources/JCO/Documents/Judgments/r-v-john-terry.pdf|date=13 July 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/football/epl/epl-news/Terry-cleared-of-racially-abusing-player-in-match/articleshow/14866169.cms |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120714053956/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/football/epl/epl-news/Terry-cleared-of-racially-abusing-player-in-match/articleshow/14866169.cms |archivedate=14 July 2012 |title=Terry cleared of racially abusing player in match |date=13 July 2012 |newspaper=The Times of India |location=Mumbai |deadurl=no}}</ref>
On 27 July 2012, the FA charged Terry for using "abusive and/or insulting words and/or behaviour" which "included a reference to the ethnic origin and/or colour and/or race of Ferdinand." The FA had delayed the charge until after the conclusion of Terry's criminal trial. Terry denied the charge.<ref>{{cite web |title=John Terry charged by the FA over Anton Ferdinand incident |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19021184 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=28 July 2012 |date=27 July 2012}}</ref> On the eve of the FA's hearing, Terry announced his retirement from the English national football team, saying his position had become "untenable" due to the disciplinary charge. On 27 September 2012, the hearing concluded with Terry being found guilty; he was punished with a four-match ban and a £220,000 fine.<ref>{{cite web |title=John Terry banned and fined by FA over Anton Ferdinand incident |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19723020 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=29 September 2012 |date=27 September 2012}}</ref>
The FA published a 63-page report<ref>{{cite web |title=Ruling of the full Regulatory Commission following the substantive disciplinary hearing held between 24th and 27th September 2012 |url=http://www.thefa.com/News/governance/2012/oct/~/media/22A83175745E44468105B57232F085B7.ashx |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=6 October 2012}}</ref> regarding the disciplinary proceedings conducted by an Independent Regulatory Commission; it labelled aspects of Terry's defence as "improbable, implausible and contrived," finding it "inherently unlikely that if he had been accused by Mr. Ferdinand of calling him something that ended with the words "black cunt", that Mr. Terry would have added the word "fucking" when he threw the words back, if he was genuinely doing so by way of forceful denial" and "inherently improbable" that he would call Anton Ferdinand a "fucking knobhead" for falsely accusing him of racial abuse. The Commission found it "implausible" that to robustly deny having used the words "black cunt" he "simply repeated" them. His defence in court was not that he had "simply repeated" the words but that he had "sarcastically" repeated them (see above), however, there was no reference to sarcasm in the Regulatory Commission's 63-page written report. The Commission concluded that it was "quite satisfied, on the balance of probabilities, that there [was] no credible basis for Mr. Terry's defence that his use of the words 'fucking black cunt' were directed at Ferdinand by way of forceful rejection and/or inquiry. Instead, [the Commission was] quite satisfied, and [found] on the balance of probabilities, that the offending words were said by way of insult."<ref>{{cite news |title=John Terry defence 'improbable, implausible and contrived' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19842795 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=6 October 2012 |date=5 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Summary of the reasons for John Terry's FA ban |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19845841 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=6 October 2012 |date=5 October 2012}}</ref>
The FA commission was also criticised as a "kangaroo court" and the FA for its lack of independence, for failing to disclose all evidence to the police, failing to tape record their interview with key witness [[Ashley Cole]], for lowering the required burden of proof after the incident had taken place,<ref name=Conseq>{{cite news |title=John Terry case highlights football's culture of abuse – now the Football Association must tackle it |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea/9590803/John-Terry-case-highlights-footballs-culture-of-abuse-now-the-Football-Association-must-tackle-it.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=21 January 2013 |date=5 October 2012 |location=London |first=Paul |last=Hayward}}</ref> and for punishing Terry for an offence he had already been cleared of in a criminal court,<ref name=Kangaroo>{{cite news |title=FA on rack over 'kangaroo court verdict' on John Terry |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/fa-on-rack-over-kangaroo-court-verdict-on-john-terry-8189767.html |newspaper=London Evening Standard |accessdate=22 October 2012 |date=28 September 2012}}</ref><ref name=Joke>{{cite news |title=FA disciplinary process is 'a joke' |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/fa-disciplinary-process-is-a-joke-8200705.html |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=22 October 2012 |date=7 October 2012 |location=London |first=Steve |last=Tongue}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=John Terry 'humiliated' by racism court case |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/today/hi/today/newsid_9754000/9754162.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=22 October 2012 |date=24 September 2012}}</ref> in contravention of its own rules, which state that verdicts in criminal cases are "presumed to be correct" unless "clear and convincing evidence" to the contrary emerges.<ref>{{cite news |title=John Terry quits England after FA over-rules own regulations to pursue case |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/9562149/John-Terry-quits-England-after-FA-over-rules-own-regulations-to-pursue-case.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=21 January 2013 |date=24 September 2012 |location=London}}</ref> Terry's four-match ban was contrasted with [[Luis Suárez]]'s eight-match ban for racially abusing [[Patrice Evra]] (Suárez received a longer ban for using the insults repeatedly) and a 14-year-old schoolboy's five-match ban for telling a referee his name was [[Santa Claus]].<ref name=Kangaroo/><ref name=Joke/>
On 18 October 2012, Terry decided not to appeal against the verdict and his four-match ban. He issued an apology for "the language [he] used in the game" and stated that it was "not acceptable on the football field or indeed in any walk of life." Chelsea announced that they had taken further disciplinary action against Terry while keeping the details confidential.<ref>{{cite news |title=John Terry decides not to appeal against four-match ban |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19989136 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 October 2012 |date=18 October 2012}}</ref> However, Terry and Chelsea still faced media condemnation; Terry was criticised for not directly and personally apologising to Ferdinand, while Chelsea were accused of hypocrisy and double standards by only fining Terry and not stripping him of his captaincy when they have a "zero-tolerance" approach to racism and had previously handed a life ban to a fan who racially abused former Chelsea player Didier Drogba.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/news/premier-league-paper-round-terrys-secret-punishment-revealed-065020589.html |title=Premier League: Paper Round: Terry's 'secret punishment' revealed |publisher=Yahoo! UK & Ireland Eurosport |accessdate=20 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022105542/http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/news/premier-league-paper-round-terrys-secret-punishment-revealed-065020589.html |archivedate=22 October 2012 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> In a radio interview, Chelsea chairman [[Bruce Buck]] and chief executive [[Ron Gourlay]] called the incident a "lapse of judgement" and "out of character" from Terry and stated that the club had "taken firm disciplinary action appropriate to the circumstances," adding that "we must not forget he was cleared in a court of law."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2012/10/20/soccer-england-chelsea-idINL3E8LK18720121020 |title=Terry remains as Chelsea captain, says chairman |agency=Reuters |date=22 October 2012 |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref>
In ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', [[Paul Hayward]] summed up his view of the consequences of the controversial incident, that "the cost has been high. Here, three vile words muttered by Terry at Loftus Road ultimately removed Fabio Capello from the England manager's job; inflicted much distress on the Ferdinand family; brought a £45,000 fine for Rio Ferdinand for his endorsement of a "choc ice" tweet aimed at Chelsea's left-back; removed Terry from the England reckoning and shed yet more light on the fantasy world of Ashley Cole."<ref name=Conseq/>
===In popular culture=== Terry has been part of a popular [[meme]] picturing him taking part in great moments in history and fiction following his decision to come on to the pitch to lift the European Cup in full kit despite being suspended for the [[2012 UEFA Champions League Final]], he repeated this when Chelsea won the [[2013 UEFA Europa League Final]] which he did not play in due to injury.<ref>{{cite web |title=Terry lifts trophy in full Chelsea kit |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/news/story/_/id/1449488/john-terry-lifts-europa-league-trophy-full-chelsea-kit |website=[[ESPN]] |accessdate=11 October 2018}}</ref> These included the fall of the [[Berlin Wall]], the freeing of [[Nelson Mandela]] and the triumph of [[Rocky Balboa]].{{cn|date=October 2018}}<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/champions-league/internet-pranksters-target-limelightloving-john-terry-after-champions-league-win-3115491.html |title=Internet pranksters target limelight-loving John Terry after Champion's League win |newspaper=Irish Independent |location=Dublin |date=2 December 2012}}</ref> Over the summer of 2012 this developed into his celebrating current sporting achievements such as [[2012 Summer Olympics]] medal wins by [[Team GB]].<ref>[http://www.talksport.co.uk/magazine/virals/120910/picture-john-terry-gatecrashes-team-gb-olympic-athletes-parade-180604 Picture: John Terry gatecrashes the Team GB Olympic athletes parade | talkSPORT]</ref>
