'''Relinquishment of United States nationality''' is the process under [[United States federal law|federal law]] by which a [[United States nationality law|U.S. citizen or national]] voluntarily and intentionally gives up that status and becomes an [[alien (law)|alien]] with respect to the United States. In U.S. law, '''renunciation of United States citizenship''' is a [[term of art|legal term]] encompassing two specific procedures for giving up U.S. citizenship by swearing an oath of renunciation before a designated U.S. government official, but the five other acts by which an American may give up U.S. citizenship are sometimes also informally referred to as "[[renunciation of citizenship]]". Relinquishment is distinct from [[denaturalization]], which in U.S. law refers solely to cancellation of illegally procured [[naturalization]].
[[List of former United States citizens who relinquished their nationality|People who relinquish U.S. citizenship]] generally have lived abroad for many years, and nearly all of them are citizens of another country. Unlike most other countries, the U.S. does not prohibit its citizens from making themselves [[statelessness|stateless]], but the [[United States Department of State|State Department]] strongly recommends against it, and very few choose to do so. It is usually impossible to relinquish citizenship while in [[United States territory|U.S. territory]], and courts have rejected arguments that U.S. state citizenship or [[Puerto Rican citizenship]] give an ex-U.S. citizen the right to enter or reside in the U.S. without the permission of the U.S. government. Like any other foreigner or stateless person, an ex-U.S. citizen requires permission from the U.S. government, such as a [[visa policy of the United States|U.S. visa]] or [[Visa Waiver Program|visa waiver]], in order to visit the United States.
Relinquishment of U.S. citizenship remains uncommon in absolute terms, but has become more frequent than relinquishment of the citizenship of most other developed countries. Between five and six thousand U.S. citizens relinquished citizenship each year in 2015 and 2016, compared to estimates of anywhere between three million and nine million [[American diaspora|U.S. citizens residing abroad]]. The number of relinquishments is up sharply from lows in the 1990s and 2000s, though only about three times as high as in the 1970s. Lawyers believe this growth is mostly driven by [[accidental American]]s who grew up abroad and only became aware of their U.S. citizenship and the tax liabilities for citizens abroad due to ongoing publicity surrounding the 2010 [[Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act]].
{{USCSub|8|1481|a}} explicitly lists '''potentially expatriating acts''' by which one can relinquish U.S. citizenship, such as naturalizing in a foreign country or serving in its government or military. Congress first defined a list of potentially expatriating acts [[Expatriation Act of 1907|in 1907]], and then expanded that list greatly [[Nationality Act of 1940|in 1940]] as part of a general reform of U.S. nationality law. Originally, the executive branch regarded voluntary performance of those acts as proving intent to relinquish citizenship, even if the individual wished to retain citizenship. The Supreme Court held this to violate the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]] in a series of cases beginning in the 1960s, and instead required that intent to relinquish citizenship must be demonstrated by the individual's words or actions. Though in some later cases in the 1980s the State Department was able to prove the requisite intent over the protests of the individuals involved, in 1990, the State Department adopted the administrative [[presumption]] that people performing most of those acts do not intend to give up citizenship.
As a result of these court rulings and policy changes, performance of a potentially expatriating act no longer creates a risk of unintentional loss of U.S. citizenship. Instead, an individual who commits a potentially expatriating act may decide whether to retain or relinquish U.S. citizenship. In the latter case, the individual may apply to the State Department for a [[Certificate of Loss of Nationality]]. Between 2010 and 2015 that began to become a difficult process with high barriers, including nearly year-long waitlists for appointments and the world's most expensive administrative fee, as well as [[#Taxation|complicated tax treatment]]. Legal scholars state that such barriers may constitute a breach of the United States' obligations under international law, and foreign legislatures have called upon the U.S. government to eliminate the fees, taxes, and other requirements, particularly with regard to accidental Americans who have few genuine links to the United States.
==Terminology== In general, "[[loss of citizenship]]" is a blanket term which may include both voluntary (citizen-initiated) and involuntary (government-initiated) termination of citizenship, though it is not always easy to make a clean distinction between the two categories: automatic loss of citizenship due to an initial action performed voluntarily could be seen either as "voluntary loss" or "involuntary loss".<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://eudo-citizenship.eu/docs/policy_brief_loss.pdf|first=Gerard René|last=De Groot|first2=Maarten|last2=Vink|first3=Iseult|last3=Honohan|title=Loss of Citizenship|journal=EUDO Citizenship Policy Brief|issue=3|year=2013|accessdate=2013-12-14|page=2}}</ref> Citizen-initiated termination of citizenship may be referred to as "renunciation", "relinquishment", or "expatriation", while the term "denationalization" refers to government-initiated termination.<ref>{{harvnb|De Groot|Vink|Honohan|2013|p=2}} and {{cite journal|url=http://engagedscholarship.csuohio.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1298&context=clevstlrev|first=Nora|last=Graham|title=Patriot Act II and Denationalization: An Unconstitutional Attempt to Revive Stripping Americans of Their Citizenship|journal=Cleveland State Law Review|volume=52|page=593, 596|date=2004|ref=harv}}</ref>
In U.S. law, "relinquishment" and "renunciation" are terms used in Subchapter III, Part 3 of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952 ({{USC|8|1481|1489}}). The term "expatriation" was used in the initial version of that act ({{USStat|66|163}}, 268) up until the Immigration and Nationality Act Amendments of 1986, when it was replaced by "relinquishment".<ref name="INAA1986">{{USBill|99|HR|4444}}; {{USPL|99|653}}; {{USStat|100|3655}}. See {{cite book|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=osu.32437010613111;view=1up;seq=443|author=House Committee on the Judiciary|title=House Report 99-916: Immigration and Nationality Act Amendments of 1986: report to accompany H.R. 4444|series=Congressional Serial Set|volume=No. 13710|publisher=Government Printing Office|date=September 26, 1986|accessdate=February 11, 2018|oclc=19585808}}</ref> The State Department continues to use both the terms "expatriation" and "relinquishment", and refers to the acts listed in {{USCSub|8|1481|a}} as "potentially expatriating acts".<ref name="7FAM1220">{{cite book|chapterurl=https://fam.state.gov/fam/07fam/07fam1220.html#M1226|chapter=7 FAM 1220: Developing a Loss-of-Nationality Case|title=[[Foreign Affairs Manual]]|publisher=Department of State|date=September 19, 2014|accessdate=June 17, 2017|ref=7 FAM 1220}}</ref> "Renunciation" specifically describes two of those acts (swearing an oath of renunciation before a U.S. diplomatic officer outside of the United States, or before a U.S. government official designated by the Attorney-General inside the United States during a state of war), while "relinquishment" may refer to any of those acts or to any of those acts besides swearing an oath of renunciation.<ref>[[#7 FAM 1220|7 FAM 1222(d)]] and {{cite web|last1=Loughran|first1=Robert F.|title=Relinquishment of U.S. citizenship; replaced with existing alternate nationality(ies)|url=http://www.fosterglobal.com/relinquishment-of-u-s-citizenship-replaced-with-existing-alternate-nationalityies/|website=Foster LLP|publisher=Foster LLP|accessdate=April 17, 2017}}</ref> In contrast, "[[denaturalization]]" is distinct from expatriation: that term is used solely in Subchapter III, Part 2 of the 1952 INA ({{USC|8|1421|1459}}) to refer to court proceedings for cancellation of fraudulently procured [[naturalization]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://scholarship.law.nd.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3425&context=ndlr|first=Daniel|last=Klubock|title=Expatriation: Its Origin and Meaning|journal=Notre Dame Law Review|volume=38|issue=1|year=1962|accessdate=April 15, 2018|page=9}}</ref>
Relinquishment of United States nationality encompasses relinquishment of United States citizenship. "Nationality" and "citizenship" are distinct under U.S. law: all people with U.S. citizenship also have U.S. nationality, but [[American Samoa]]ns and some residents of the [[Northern Marianas Islands]] have U.S. nationality without citizenship.<ref>{{cite book|chapterurl=https://fam.state.gov/fam/07fam/07fam1120.html|chapter=7 FAM 1220: Acquisition of U.S. nationality in U.S. territories and possessions|title=Foreign Affairs Manual|publisher=Department of State|location=United States|date=October 27, 2017|access-date=July 12, 2018}} {{cite journal|url=https://harvardlawreview.org/2017/04/american-samoa-and-the-citizenship-clause/|title=Developments in the Law — American Samoa and the Citizenship Clause: A Study in ''Insular Cases'' Revisionism|journal=Harvard Law Review|volume=130|page=1680|date=2017|access-date=July 12, 2018}}</ref> Both citizens and non-citizen nationals may undertake the process of relinquishment of United States nationality. A citizen who undertakes that process gives up both citizenship and nationality. It is not possible to relinquish U.S. citizenship while retaining U.S. nationality.<ref>{{cite case|url=https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/eoir/legacy/2012/08/17/2650.pdf|litigants=Matter of Davis|vol=16|reporter=I. & N. Dec.|opinion=514|pinpoint=525|court=Atty. Gen.|year=1978}}</ref>
People who relinquish U.S. citizenship are called "relinquishers", while those who specifically renounce U.S. citizenship are called "renunciants".<ref>[[#7 FAM 1220|7 FAM Exhibit 1227(A) and 1227(B)]]</ref> The informal term "last-generation Americans", wordplay on terminology for [[immigrant generations]] (such as "first-generation Americans" or "second-generation Americans"), is also seen.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://maisonneuve.org/article/2017/11/27/last-generation-americans/|first=Anders|last=Morley|title=Last-Generation Americans: Fifty years after the Vietnam War, Anders Morley talks to draft dodgers about their legacy in Canada|magazine=Maison Neuve|date=November 27, 2017|accessdate=April 20, 2018}}</ref> The terms "expatriation" or "expatriates" may lead to some confusion, as in modern parlance an "expatriate" is simply a person who resides abroad, without any implication of giving up citizenship.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://ahr.oxfordjournals.org/content/114/2/307.full.pdf|first=Nancy L.|last=Green|title=Expatriation, Expatriates, and Expats: The American Transformation of a Concept|journal=The American Historical Review|volume=114|number=2|page=307|date=April 2009|accessdate=June 15, 2017}}</ref>
==Numbers==
From 2014 to 2016, an average of about five thousand U.S. citizens gave up their citizenship each year. These numbers have risen by nearly ten times between 2005 and 2015, though they remain only about three times the annual numbers in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite book|ref=CITEREFJCT1995|url=https://www.jct.gov/publications.html?func=startdown&id=2944|title=Issues Presented By Proposals To Modify The Tax Treatment Of Expatriation|publisher=[[Joint Committee on Taxation]]|date=1995-06-01|page=7}}</ref><ref name="Lee2017">{{cite journal|url=https://dc.law.utah.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1037&context=scholarship|first=Young Ran|last=Lee|title=Considering 'Citizenship Taxation': In Defense of FATCA|journal=Florida Tax Review|volume=20|page=346–347|date=2017|ssrn=2972248|ref=harv}}</ref>
In absolute terms, few people relinquish U.S. citizenship or citizenship of any other developed country; in almost all countries, the number of people who give up citizenship each year is small relative to the total number of citizens abroad, let alone the total number of citizens in that country. In a 2017 study of citizenship relinquishments in twenty-eight countries, mostly [[OECD]] members, the U.S. came in sixth place in relative terms (i.e. relinquishers as a proportion of citizens abroad), behind [[Singapore]], [[South Korea]], [[Taiwan]], [[Estonia]], and [[Japan]]; and second in absolute numbers behind South Korea.<ref name="Lee2017"/> The study author noted that emotional factors and prohibitions on dual citizenship may affect the rates of citizenship relinquishment, and that military conscription may explain the high rates in the other top countries besides the United States.<ref>{{harvnb|Lee|2017|p=341, 348}}</ref><ref group="Note">For general discussion of conscription in the other countries mentioned, see [[Estonian Defence Forces#Conscription]], [[conscription in Singapore]], [[conscription in South Korea]], and [[conscription in Taiwan]] (Japan does not practice military conscription). For general discussion of the treatment of [[multiple citizenship]] in those countries, see [[Estonian nationality law#Dual citizenship]], [[Japanese nationality law#Dual nationality]], [[Singaporean nationality law#Dual citizenship]], [[South Korean nationality law#Dual citizenship]], and [[Nationality law of the Republic of China#Dual nationality and naturalization]].</ref> [[Peter Spiro]] notes that most countries with military conscription provide exemptions for non-resident citizens.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://repository.law.umich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1485&context=mjil|ssrn=2956020|first=Peter|last=Spiro|authorlink=Peter Spiro|title=Citizenship Overreach|journal=Michigan Journal of International Law|volume=38|issue=2|page=169|date=2017|ref=harv}}</ref> Regardless of the reasons, even for South Korea, the top country, only about 0.7% of citizens abroad relinquish each year, while for the U.S. the rate is only about 0.1%, though in both cases unreliability of population figures for citizens abroad means the rates are open to question.<ref>{{harvnb|Lee|2017|p=348}}</ref> One former Foreign Service Officer, noting that State Department estimates of the population of U.S. citizens abroad have grown from 3.2 million in 2004 to 9 million in 2017, cautions that these estimates were "generated to justify consular assets and budget" and so "may be self-serving".<ref>{{cite book|chapterurl=http://www.nyulawglobal.org/globalex/Fatca_Citizenship_Based_Taxation.html|first=Andrew|last=Grossman|chapter=FATCA: Citizenship-Based Taxation, Foreign Asset Reporting Requirements and American Citizens Abroad|editor-first=Lucie|editor-last=Olejnikova|title=[[GlobaLex]]|publisher=New York University|date=2018|accessdate=April 24, 2018|ref=harv|at=§ 2}}</ref>

==Process==
===Overview=== [[File:Certificate_of_Loss_of_Nationality_of_the_United_States.jpg|thumb|left|upright|A [[Certificate of Loss of Nationality]] of the United States, issued to an ex-citizen as official documentation of his decision to relinquish U.S. citizenship.]]
A person who performs a potentially expatriating act with the intention of giving up U.S. citizenship loses U.S. citizenship from the time of that act.<ref name="Berg2014">{{cite conference|url=http://moodysgartner.com/wp-content/uploads/Berg.-FATCA-Cure-for-US-Place-of-Birth.pdf|first=Roy|last=Berg|title=FATCA in Canada: The 'Cure' for a U.S. Place of Birth|location=Toronto|conference=66th Annual Canadian Tax Foundation Annual Conference|page=20|date=2014-11-30|accessdate=2017-10-31|ref=harv}}</ref><ref group="Note">In addition to the matters discussed by {{harvnb|Berg|2014}}, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit|Second Circuit]] has also held that "Congress sought by the enactment of Section 356 of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952, {{USC|8|1488}}, to have loss of nationality occur immediately upon the commission of expatriating acts". {{cite case|url=https://openjurist.org/315/f2d/673/united-states-marks-v-p-a-esperdy|litigants=United States ex. re. Marks v. Esperdy|vol=315|reporter=F.2d|opinion=673|pinpoint=|year=1963}} Affirmed by an equally divided Supreme Court: {{cite case|url=https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/377/214/|litigants=Marks v. Esperdy|vol=377|reporter=U.S.|opinion=214|year=1964}}</ref> The State Department will issue such a person with a [[Certificate of Loss of Nationality]] (CLN) upon request. U.S. nationality law does not require an ex-citizen to notify the State Department nor obtain a CLN, but obtaining one may be helpful to prove one's status as a non-U.S. citizen to other governments or private parties, and U.S. tax laws since 2004 ignore relinquishment of citizenship until the person notifies the State Department.<ref>{{harvnb|Berg|2014|p=20}}</ref>
Obtaining a CLN to demonstrate relinquishment of U.S. citizenship has become a lengthy process with high barriers. The total cost of renouncing U.S. citizenship for a person in France, including the cost of preparing the related tax paperwork, has been reported to be [[Euro|€]]10,000-20,000 on average.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-04-16/-accidental-americans-in-france-press-macron-for-irs-relief|first=Gregory|last=Viscusi|title='Accidental Americans' in France Press Macron for IRS Relief|work=Bloomberg|date=April 16, 2018|accessdate=April 17, 2017}}</ref> [[Allison Christians]] of McGill University and [[Peter Spiro]] of Temple University have suggested that the complexity and cost of the process, especially the $2,350 State Department fee and the potential penalties for failure to file related tax forms, may constitute a breach of the U.S.' obligation not to impose arbitrary barriers to change of nationality, particularly when applied to [[accidental American]]s who have few genuine links to the United States. Such an obligation can be found in the domestic law (the [[Expatriation Act of 1868]]), in international instruments such as the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]], and in general state practice.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://repository.law.umich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1486&context=mjil|first=Allison|last=Christians|title=A Global Perspective on Citizenship-Based Taxation|journal=Michigan Journal of International Law|volume=38|issue=2|page=241–242|date=2017|accessdate=June 6, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170912061809/http://repository.law.umich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1486&context=mjil|archivedate=September 12, 2017|ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Spiro|2017|p=182–3}}; see also blog posts by the same author: {{cite news|url=http://opiniojuris.org/2008/07/18/us-erects-a-berlin-tax-wall/|first=Peter|last=Spiro|title=U.S. erects a Berlin (Tax) Wall|work=Opinio Juris|date=2008-07-18|accessdate=2014-06-09}} {{cite news|url=http://opiniojuris.org/2012/05/17/will-congress-move-to-tax-ex-patriots/|first=Peter|last=Spiro|title=Will Congress Move to Tax 'Ex-Patriots'?|work=Opinio Juris|date=2012-05-17|accessdate=2014-05-09}}</ref> The difficulty of the process led to a proposal by members of France's [[National Assembly (France)|National Assembly]] that the French government should negotiate with the U.S. government for [[French nationality law|French citizens]] to enjoy a simplified procedure for renouncing U.S. citizenship that did not require payment of such fees, and subsequently a June 2018 resolution in the [[European Parliament]] calling on the [[European Commission]] to carry out similar negotiations in respect of all accidental Americans who were citizens of [[Member state of the European Union|European Union member states]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/conjoncture/2018/03/14/20002-20180314ARTFIG00324-americains-accidentels-l-assemblee-nationale-s-empare-du-dossier.php|first=Antoine|last=Garbay|title=«Américains accidentels» : l'Assemblée nationale s'empare du dossier|newspaper=[[Le Figaro]]|date=March 14, 2018|accessdate=April 12, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20180628IPR06837/meps-want-to-open-negotiations-on-an-eu-us-fatca-agreement|title=MEPs want to open negotiations on an EU-US FATCA agreement|publisher=European Parliament|date=July 5, 2018|access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref>
Tax filing is not a legal prerequisite to giving up U.S. citizenship, although there are various negative tax consequences if one fails to file U.S. taxes before giving up citizenship, or fails to file tax forms specific to ex-citizens in the year following relinquishment.<ref>{{harvnb|Spiro|2017|p=185}} and {{cite journal|first=William Thomas|last=Worster|title=The Constitutionality of the Taxation Consequences for Renouncing U.S. Citizenship|journal=Florida Tax Review|volume=9|issue=11|year=2010|ssrn=1628568|page=938}}</ref> The U.S. State Department instructs officers not to answer any inquiries about the tax treatment of ex-citizens, and refers all such inquiries to the IRS.<ref>[[#7 FAM 1240|7 FAM 1243(f)]]</ref>
===Interview and processing fee=== Obtaining a CLN by renouncing citizenship requires two interviews by U.S. consular officers; the first interview may be held by telephone, but State Department policy demands that the second must be in person.<ref name="7FAM1260">{{cite book|chapterurl=https://fam.state.gov/FAM/07FAM/07FAM1260.html|chapter=7 FAM 1260: Renunciation of U.S. Citizenship Abroad|title=[[Foreign Affairs Manual]]|publisher=Department of State|date=September 19, 2014|accessdate=November 4, 2017|ref=7 FAM 1260}}</ref> Obtaining a CLN through other forms of relinquishment, where the individual informs the consulate that he or she had the requisite intent when performing a potentially expatriating act, requires the individual to complete a questionnaire and return it to the consulate, after which the consular officer may request a follow-up interview, either by telephone or in person.<ref>[[#7 FAM 1220|7 FAM 1224.5]]. The questionnaire is {{cite web|url=https://eforms.state.gov/Forms/ds4079.pdf|title=DS-4079: Request for Determination of Possible Loss of United States Citizenship|publisher=Department of State|location=United States|year=2017|accessdate=April 15, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171015234317/https://eforms.state.gov/Forms/ds4079.pdf|archivedate=October 15, 2017}}</ref> In Canada, one of the countries with a high volume of relinquishments of U.S. citizenship, initial intake and review of the questionnaire prior to assignment of an appointment reportedly took 60 days in 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/us-citizenship-renunciation-procedures-95417/|title=US Citizenship Renunciation Procedures in Canada|journal=Canadian Tax Highlights|volume=24|issue=9|date=September 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2018}}</ref>
Interviews are normally conducted on an individual basis, but in 2011 the U.S. Consulate in Toronto held a group appointment for twenty-two people in an apparent attempt to address scheduling difficulties.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/americans-in-canada-driven-to-divorce-from-their-country/article4179937/|first=Barrie|last=McKenna|title=Americans in Canada driven to divorce from their country|work=The Globe and Mail|date=November 8, 2011|accessdate=June 17, 2017}}</ref> Backlogs remain long, with the Toronto consulate reportedly having a 10-month waiting list for appointments in 2015, and the [[Embassy of the United States, Dublin|U.S. Embassy in Dublin]] stating in April 2016 that no more appointments were available until December 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/1952125/unwilling-dual-citizens-face-10-month-wait-to-shed-u-s-citizenship-in-toronto/|title=Unwilling dual citizens face 10-month wait to shed U.S. citizenship in Toronto|work=Global News|date=April 22, 2015|accessdate=June 17, 2017}} {{cite web|url=https://dublin.usembassy.gov/service2/renunciation-of-citizenship.html|title=Renunciation of the United States|publisher=Embassy of the United States|location=Dublin, Ireland|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407091704/https://dublin.usembassy.gov/service2/renunciation-of-citizenship.html|archivedate=April 7, 2016|accessdate=June 15, 2017}}</ref> The appointment does not have to be conducted at the diplomatic post in the relinquisher's country of residence, but can be held at a post in another country instead.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/1671945/meet-the-alberta-man-who-went-to-tijuana-to-renounce-his-u-s-citizenship/|title=Meet the Alberta man who went to Tijuana to renounce his U.S. citizenship|work=Global News|date=November 18, 2014|accessdate=June 15, 2014}} 7 FAM 1211(g) specifically states that "There is no requirement that a U.S. citizen renouncing or relinquishing U.S. citizenship abroad be a resident of the U.S. consular district." {{cite book|chapterurl=https://fam.state.gov/fam/07fam/07fam1210.html|chapter=7 FAM 1210: Loss and Restoration of U.S. Citizenship|title=Foreign Affairs Manual|publisher=Department of State|date=December 19, 2014|accessdate=June 15, 2017|ref=7 FAM 1210}}</ref>
After the second interview, the person signs a statement confirming that they understand the rights they are giving up, and must pay a fee of $2,350.<ref>[[#7 FAM 1260|7 FAM 1262.4]]. In 2015, the fee was extended to cover relinquishments other than swearing an oath of renunciation: [[#80 FR 53704|80 FR 53704]]. The statement itself is {{cite web|url=https://eforms.state.gov/Forms/ds4081.pdf|title=DS-4081: Statement of Understanding Concerning Ramifications of Renunciation or Relinquishment of U.S. Nationality|publisher=U.S. Department of State, Bureau of Consular Affairs|date=July 2013|accessdate=April 12, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180412090032/https://eforms.state.gov/Forms/ds4081.pdf|archivedate=April 12, 2018|deadurl=no}}</ref> The fee was raised from its previous level of $450 in 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guampdn.com/story/news/local/bayanihan/2017/08/05/losing-your-united-states-citizenship/523579001/|first=Catherine Bejarana|last=Camacho|title=Losing your United States citizenship|work=Guam Pacific Daily News|date=2017-08-05|accessdate=2017-08-05}}</ref> This fee is believed to be the world's highest for giving up citizenship, more than twice the fee in the next highest country (Jamaica), and roughly twenty times the average fee charged by other developed countries.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/robertwood/2015/10/23/u-s-has-worlds-highest-fee-to-renounce-citizenship/|first=Robert|last=Woods|title=U.S. Has World's Highest Fee To Renounce Citizenship|work=Forbes|date=October 23, 2015|accessdate=February 8, 2018}}</ref>
===Waiting for a Certificate of Loss of Nationality===
Wait time to receive a CLN varies. Cuban spy [[René González]] received his CLN within days of renouncing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-cuban-spy-officially-stripped-of-us-citizenship-2013may10-story.html|title=Cuban spy officially stripped of US citizenship|newspaper=San Diego Union-Tribune|agency=Associated Press|date=May 10, 2013|accessdate=February 8, 2018}}</ref> Others have reported wait times of as long as a year. The loss of citizenship is deemed to take legal effect on the date of the actual relinquishing act, rather than the date of approval of the CLN.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/135454/use-of-certificate-of-loss-of-nationality-allowed-after-renunciation-of-us-citizenship|first=Lourdes Santos|last=Tancinco|title=Use of certificate of loss of nationality allowed after renunciation of US citizenship|newspaper=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=January 24, 2016|accessdate=February 8, 2018}}</ref> While approval of the CLN is pending, the State Department will not issue a U.S. visa to a person who has relinquished citizenship, meaning that in general the person cannot travel to the United States. In exceptional cases, the State Department says that it can permit a relinquisher with an "urgent need to travel" to the U.S. while the CLN is pending to use a [[United States passport|U.S. passport]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/expat/2015/03/16/u-s-government-changes-citizenship-renunciation-passport-policy-after-criticism/|first=Helen|last=Burggraf|title=U.S. Government Changes Citizenship Renunciation Passport Policy After Criticism|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=March 16, 2015|accessdate=April 15, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150323125313/https://blogs.wsj.com/expat/2015/03/16/u-s-government-changes-citizenship-renunciation-passport-policy-after-criticism/|archivedate=March 23, 2015}} Describes an update to [[#7 FAM 1220|7 FAM 1227(e)]].</ref>
Following confirmation by State Department officials in Washington, DC, the consulate provides a copy of the CLN to the former citizen, and returns his or her U.S. passport after cancelling it. The State Department also forwards copies of the CLN to the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]], the [[Department of Homeland Security]], and the [[Internal Revenue Service]].<ref>{{cite book|chapterurl=https://fam.state.gov/FAM/07FAM/07FAM1240.html|chapter=7 FAM 1240: Interagency Coordination and Reporting Requirements|title=Foreign Affairs Manual|publisher=Department of State|date=November 12, 2015|accessdate=June 15, 2017|ref=7 FAM 1240}}</ref>
==Legal elements== ===Voluntariness and intent===
[[File:US Consulate General Amsterdam Museumplein Dec 2013.JPG|thumb|right|The State Department now requires that a relinquisher seeking to obtain a [[Certificate of Loss of Nationality]] attend an in-person interview at a U.S. diplomatic mission abroad, such as the U.S. Consulate in Amsterdam ''(pictured)'', to assess the person's intent towards U.S. citizenship.]]
Beginning with the [[Expatriation Act of 1907]], Congress began to define concrete acts from which the intent to give up citizenship would be inferred, in what Nora Graham describes as the start of "the process of the government transforming voluntary expatriation into denationalization".<ref>{{harvnb|Graham|2004|p=697}}</ref> The constitutional basis for this was not the [[Naturalization Clause]], as Supreme Court [[obitur dictum|dicta]] limited the scope of this power. Rather, the government successfully argued for decades, beginning in ''[[Mackenzie v. Hare]]'', that this arose from the inherent power of sovereignty in foreign relations. The [[Nationality Act of 1940]] greatly expanded the list of acts regarded as criteria for a finding of voluntary expatriation.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://scholarship.law.upenn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=8181&context=penn_law_review|first=John P.|last=Roche|title=Loss of American Nationality: The Development of Statutory Expatriation|journal=University of Pennsylvania Law Review|volume=99|page=25, 26|date=1950}}</ref>
The Supreme Court eventually rejected this argument in ''[[Afroyim v. Rusk]]'' (1967), ruling that under the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]], Congress lacked the power to deprive a native-born or naturalized citizen of U.S. citizenship, and that loss of citizenship required the individual's assent. Then in ''[[Vance v. Terrazas]]'' (1980), the court further clarified that mere performance of expatriating acts could not be taken as "conclusive evidence" of assent to loss of citizenship, but rather that the [[trier of fact]] must also find an intent to relinquish citizenship either "in words" or "as fair inference from proven conduct".<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://via.library.depaul.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2996&context=law-review|first=Robert|last=Ward|title=Constitutional Law - Involuntary Expatriation - Specific Intent to Relinquish Citizenship Required|journal=DePaul Law Review|volume=19|issue=1|date=1969|page=202|accessdate=April 12, 2018|ref=harv}} {{cite journal|url=https://repository.law.miami.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=&httpsredir=1&article=1854&context=umialr|first=Matthew J.|last=Buckley|title=Loss of United States Citizenship: Fourteenth Amendment Limitations on Congressionally Mandated Expatriation, ''Vance v. Terrazas'', 444 U.S. 252 (1980)|journal=Inter-American Law Review|volume=12|issue=3|page=750|date=October 1980|accessdate=April 12, 2018|ref=harv}}</ref> Finally, in 1990, the State Department adopted an administrative presumption that U.S. citizens who performed three categories of potentially expatriating acts (naturalizing in a foreign state, making a "routine" oath of allegiance to a foreign country, or serving in a non-policy-level position in a foreign government) intended to retain U.S. citizenship, unless the person "affirmatively asserts" otherwise to a consular officer.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://repository.law.miami.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1455&context=umialr|first=H. Angsar|last=Kelly|title=Dual Nationality, the Myth of Election, and a Kinder, Gentler State Department|journal=Inter-American Law Review|volume=23|pages=421, 442|year=1991|ref=harv}} {{cite journal|url=https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-1996-06-12/pdf/96-13402.pdf|first=Mary A.|last=Ryan|title=22 CFR Part 50: Nationality Procedures|journal=Federal Register|volume=61|page=29652|date=June 12, 1996|accessdate=April 12, 2018}}</ref> An attempt in 2005 to force the State Department to revise this policy died in committee in the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]].<ref group="Note">Section 703 of the Enforcement First Immigration Reform Act of 2005 ({{USBill|109|HR|3938}}), a [[immigration reform in the United States|U.S. immigration reform]] bill sponsored by [[J. D. Hayworth]] (R-AZ-5) and co-sponsored by 33 other Republicans, would have required the State Department to "revise the 1990 memoranda and directives on dual citizenship and dual nationality and return to the traditional policy of the Department of State of viewing dual/multiple citizenship as problematic and as something to be discouraged not encouraged". Section 702 of the same act would have imposed a $10,000 fine and a prison sentence of up to one year on naturalized citizens who had taken the [[Oath of Allegiance (United States)|Oath of Allegiance]] and subsequently voted in an election, ran for elective office, served in any government body, used the passport, took an oath of allegiance, or served in the armed forces of their country of former citizenship. See {{cite news|url=http://www.actionamerica.org/constitution/citrefhoax.shtml|first=John|last=Gaver|title=Citizenship Reform Torpedos Immigration Bill|work=Action America|date=December 9, 2005|accessdate=April 14, 2018|postscript=none}}. The [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|House Judiciary Committee]] referred the bill to its [[United States House Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration and Border Security|Subcommittee on Immigration and Border Security]], while the [[United States House Committee on Armed Services|Armed Services Committee]] referred the bill to its [[United States House Armed Services Subcommittee on Emerging Threats and Capabilities|Subcommittee on Terrorism, Unconventional Threats and Capabilities]], but neither took further action on the bill by the end of the [[109th United States Congress|109th Congress]]' first session.</ref> Though cases restricting government-initiated termination of U.S. citizenship were seen as civil rights victories by people who hoped to regain or retain U.S. citizenship, in practice they have also resulted in involuntary retroactive restoration of U.S. citizenship, without notification, to people who were unwilling to have their citizenship restored.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://scholarworks.law.ubalt.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1004&context=ublr|title=The Income Tax Consequences of a Holding of Unconstitutionality of Expatriation Statutes|journal=University of Baltimore Law Review|date=1971|volume=1|issue=1|pages=49–59}} {{cite book|url=https://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Documents/tax598.pdf|first=Donald C.|last=Lubick|chapter=Relief for 'Unknowing' or 'Restored' Citizens|title=Income Tax Compliance by U.S. Citizens and U.S. Lawful Permanent Residents Residing Outside of the United States and Related Issues|publisher=United States Department of the Treasury|date=May 1998|accessdate=2018-02-12|ref=harv}} {{cite news|url=http://www.advisor.ca/tax/tax-news/is-it-possible-to-ditch-u-s-citizenship-retroactively-212929|first=Max|last=Reed|title=Can clients ditch U.S. citizenship retroactively|work=Advisor.ca|date=September 30, 2016|accessdate=February 12, 2018}} {{harnvb|Christians|2017|p=214}}</ref>
In general, the Department of Justice takes the position that renunciation pursuant to a plea bargain is voluntary and demonstrates intent to give up U.S. citizenship. However, the [[Office of Legal Counsel]] outlined some circumstances under which a court might regard such a renunciation as involuntary, including "physical or mental intimidation", material misrepresentation of the plea agreement, or withholding material evidence. In at least one case prior to 1984, a State Department official refused to certify that a renunciation under such a plea bargain was voluntary.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/olc/opinions/1984/09/31/op-olc-v008-p0220.pdf|first=Ralph W.|last=Tarr|title=Voluntariness of Renunciations of Citizenship under 8 U.S.C. 1481(a)(6)|journal=Opinion of the Office of Legal Counsel|volume=8|page=220|date=1984}}</ref>
Some cases from the late 1950s and 1960s held that a potentially expatriating act could not actually cause loss of citizenship absent awareness that one had citizenship.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://scholarship.law.stjohns.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=4279&context=lawreview|first=Abraham|last=Scharf|title=A Study of the Law of Expatriation|journal=St. John's Law Review|volume=38|issue=2|pages=251, 256|date=May 1964|accessdate=April 12, 2018}} Cites {{cite case|litigants=Rogers v. Patokoski|vol=271|reporter=F.2d|opinion=858|court=9th Cir.|year=1959}} {{cite case|url=https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/eoir/legacy/2012/08/27/1175.pdf|litigants=Matter of C.|vol=9 I. & N. Dec.|opinion=482|court=BIA|year=1961}} {{cite case|url=https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/eoir/legacy/2012/08/27/1218.pdf|litigants=Matter of C.|vol=9|reporter=I. & N. Dec.|opinion=670|pinpoint=675–77|court=Atty. Gen.|year=1962}} See further {{cite book|chapterurl=https://fam.state.gov/fam/07fam/07fam1100apK.html|chapter=7 FAM 1100 Appendix K: Defenses of unawareness, impossibility of performance, constructive compliance, and official misinformation|title=Foreign Affairs Manual|location=United States|publisher=Department of State|date=March 25, 2013|accessdate=April 12, 2018}}</ref> Later case law modulated this: in ''Breyer v. Meissner'' (2000), the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit|Third Circuit]] stated in ''dicta'' that voluntary service in the [[Waffen-SS]] during World War II would constitute "unequivocal renunciation of American citizenship whether or not the putative citizen [was] then aware that he has a right to American citizenship".<ref>{{cite paper|url=http://www.justice.gov/olc/expatriation.htm |first=John C. |last=Yoo |authorlink=John Yoo |title=Survey of the Law of Expatriation: Memorandum Opinion for the Solicitor General |publisher=Department of Justice |date=June 12, 2002 |accessdate=June 15, 2017 |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060603210348/http://www.justice.gov/olc/expatriation.htm |archivedate=June 3, 2006 }}</ref><ref group="Note">However, the Third Circuit upheld the district court's finding that the Waffen-SS service of plaintiff-appellant [[Johann Breyer]] was involuntary and that he had not thus relinquished U.S. citizenship. {{cite case|url=https://openjurist.org/214/f3d/416/johann-breyer-v-doris-meissner-us-immigration-and-naturalization-service|litigants=Breyer v. Meissner|vol=214|reporter=F.3d|opinion=416|court=3rd Cir.|year=2000|accessdate=8 February 2018}}</ref>
===Burden of proof and standard of evidence===
{{Multiple image | image1 = Letter from United States Consulate-General to naturalized Canadian citizen, 1980 (page 1).jpg | image2 = Letter from United States Consulate-General to naturalized Canadian citizen, 1980 (page 2).jpg | width = 150 | align = left | footer = A July 1980 letter from a U.S. consulate to a new Canadian citizen, stating that naturalization in Canada was "highly persuasive evidence" of intent to relinquish U.S. nationality. }}
{{USCSub|8|1481|b}} places the burden of proof for relinquishment of citizenship "upon the person or party claiming that such loss occurred, to establish such claim by a preponderance of the evidence", and establishes the presumption that a potentially expatriating act was performed voluntarily. Thus, when an individual citizen asserts that it was his or her intent to relinquish citizenship, the burden of proof is on the individual to prove that intent.<ref>[[#7 FAM 1220|7 FAM 1224.4(c)]]</ref>
The standard of [[preponderance of the evidence]] means that "it was more likely than not that the individual intended to relinquish citizenship at the time of the expatriating act"; the intent must be contemporaneous with the act.<ref>[[#7 FAM 1220|7 FAM 1225.2]]</ref> Prior to the enactment of 1481(b), the Supreme Court had held in ''[[Nishikawa v. Dulles]]'' that, in the absence of any Congressionally enacted standard of evidence, expatriation cases required the same standard of [[clear and convincing evidence]] as in denaturalization cases. Decades after the enactment of 1481(b), the Supreme Court upheld the new standard of evidence in ''Vance v. Terrazas'' in January 1980.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://scholarship.kentlaw.iit.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2405&context=cklawreview|first=Mary Kempers |last=McCarthy|title=Evidentiary Proof in Expatriation Proceedings|journal=Chicago-Kent Law Review|volume=57|issue=1|accessdate=June 15, 2017}}</ref>
This provision, recommended by the [[House Un-American Activities Committee]] (HUAC), passed into law in 1961.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/stream/annualreportfory1961unit#page/146/mode/2up|title=Annual report for the year 1961|publisher=House Un-American Activities Committee, United States Congress|date=1961|p=146|accessdate=June 15, 2017|ref=CITEREFHUAC1961}}</ref> HUAC chairman [[Francis E. Walter]] first introduced bills with this provision in February 1960 and January 1961, and it was eventually inserted into a Senate-originated bill on war orphans in August 1961.<ref name="HUAC1961-164">{{harvnb|HUAC|1961|p=164}}</ref> The House Judiciary Committee report on that bill stated that the burden of proof "would rest on the Government", whereas HUAC's later annual report noted that the burden of proof was on "the party claiming that such loss occurred".<ref name="HUAC1961-164"/> In the committee report on the bill, Walter described this provision as "forestall[ing] further erosion of the statute designed to preserve and uphold the dignity and priceless value of U.S. citizenship with attendant obligations".<ref>{{cite book|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.b3997056;view=1up;seq=1043|title=87th Congress, 1st Session, House Report 1086: Amending the Immigration and Nationality Act and for other purposes|series=Congressional Serial Set 12342|date=1961|access-date=2017-11-04|page=[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.b3997056;view=1up;seq=1083 40]}}</ref>
===Abandonment of right of U.S. residence=== [[File:Brasciudadano.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Some renunciants have unsuccessfully argued that their citizenship of Puerto Rico ''(citizenship certificate pictured)'' gave them the right to remain in Puerto Rico after renouncing U.S. citizenship.]]
In general, {{USCSub|8|1483|a}} requires that an individual be outside of the United States and its outlying possessions<ref group="Note">[[American Samoa]] and [[Swains Island]], per {{USCSub|8|1101|a|29}}</ref> in order to relinquish citizenship, except when the relinquishing act is [[#Renunciation within U.S. territory|renunciation during a state of war]] or [[#Treason, rebellion, or similar crimes|commission of treason, rebellion, or similar crimes]].<ref>[[#7 FAM 1210|7 FAM 1211(g)]] and [[#7 FAM 1220|7 FAM 1221(a)]].</ref> Additionally, relinquishment of citizenship requires giving up the right to enter and reside in the United States.<ref>[[#7 FAM 1220|7 FAM 1226(c)]]</ref> This does not mean that ex-citizens are banned from the country; the State Department routinely issues visas to ex-citizens.<ref>{{cite book|chapterurl=http://www.uianet.org/sites/default/files/safe_uploads/clients/37837/rapports/REPORT%20-%20CHOW,%20Eugene%20-%20131029.pdf|first=Eugene|last=Chow|chapter=Acquisition of Chinese nationality in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region and Expatriation under U.S. law|title=Nationality and Immigration Commission|series=57th Congress of the Union International des Avocats|date=2013-11-02|accessdate=2014-06-09}}</ref> However, entry into the United States is a privilege for which ex-citizens must apply, rather than a right which they can exercise freely, and they can be denied entry or [[deportation|deported]] just like any other alien.<ref name="Lorenz1972">{{cite journal|url=https://litigation-essentials.lexisnexis.com/webcd/app?action=DocumentDisplay&crawlid=1&doctype=cite&docid=46+Tul.+L.+Rev.+984&srctype=smi&srcid=3B15&key=5c58d4f5627ff219c0f8c0e7a04458bf|first=Milton C.|last=Lorenz|title=Aliens: Renunciation of Nationality Leaves Individual Stateless and Excludable as Any Alien|work=Tulane Law Review|date=June 1972|volume=46|issue=984|accessdate=2012-05-12|ref=harv}} {{cite case|url=http://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F2/441/1245/209932/|vol=441|reporter=F.2d|opinion=1245|litigants=Jolley v. Immigration and Naturalization Service|date=April 12, 1971}}</ref> Though it might be possible that an alien could be a citizen of a U.S. state without obtaining or even being eligible for U.S. citizenship, state citizenship cannot provide any rights to enter or remain in the United States.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2014/06/24/is-state-citizenship-the-answer-to-immigration-reform/state-citizenship-has-roots-in-american-history|first=Peter|last=Spiro|title=State Citizenship Has Roots in American History|work=The New York Times|date=June 24, 2014|accessdate=June 15, 2017}} {{cite news|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/opinions/2014/6/new-york-state-citizenshipfederalimmigrationreform.html|title=Why New York's proposal to grant state citizenship makes perfect sense|work=Al Jazeera America|date=June 14, 2017|accessdate=June 15, 2017}}</ref> Pseudo-legal arguments about U.S. citizenship by members of the [[sovereign citizen movement]], such as that a person can declare himself a "free-born citizen of a state" rather than a U.S. citizen and then continue to reside in the U.S. without being subject to federal law, have been found [[frivolous litigation|frivolous]] by courts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/anti-tax-law-evasion-schemes-law-and-arguments-section-iii|title=Anti-Tax Law Evasion Schemes - Law and Arguments (Section III)|publisher=Internal Revenue Service|date=2016-08-15|accessdate=2017-11-06|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170516210430/https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/anti-tax-law-evasion-schemes-law-and-arguments-section-iii|archivedate=2017-05-16}}</ref> Courts have also addressed other assertions of residual rights to U.S. residence by ex-citizens on the basis of sub-national citizenship at least twice in recent years.
[[Garry Davis]], who renounced U.S. citizenship in 1948 at the U.S. Embassy in Paris, attempted to return to the United States in 1978 without a visa, and was granted [[parole (United States immigration)|parole]] into the U.S. but not legal admission. In an appeal against deportation, he argued that he had only renounced United States citizenship but not the citizenship of the state of [[Maine]] where he was born. He further argued that the U.S. Constitution's [[Privileges and Immunities Clause]] meant that as a citizen of Maine he could not be denied the privilege of living in [[New Hampshire]] which New Hampshire citizens enjoyed. Judge [[Thomas Aquinas Flannery]] of the [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia|DC District Court]] did not address the first argument but rejected the second, writing that while the state of New Hampshire could not restrict Davis' travel or access there, under the Constitution's [[Naturalization Clause]] Congress has sole and absolute authority to make laws regarding the entry and deportation of people other than United States citizens.<ref>{{cite case|url=http://www.leagle.com/decision/19791659481FSupp1178_11490/DAVIS%20v.%20DISTRICT%20DIRECTOR,%20IMMIGRATION,%20ETC.|litigants=Davis v. District Director, INS|vol=481|reporter=F.Supp.|opinion=1178|court=D.D.C.|date=1979}}</ref>
In 1998, the DC District Court considered another case involving a renunciant who returned to the United States without a visa.<ref name="LozadaColonCase">{{cite case|url=http://www.leagle.com/decision/1998452FSupp2d43_141/LOZADA%20COLON%20v.%20U.S.%20DEPT.%20OF%20STATE|litigants=Lozada Colon v. U.S. Dept. of State|vol=452|reporter=F.Supp.2d|opinion=43|court=D.D.C.|date=1998}}</ref> In the mid-1990s, a number of [[independence movement in Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican independence]] supporters, including Alberto Lozada Colón and [[Juan Mari Brás]], renounced U.S. citizenship at U.S. embassies in nearby countries and then returned to Puerto Rico almost immediately while they were waiting to receive CLNs. In 1998, the State Department formally refused to issue a CLN to Lozada Colón, stating that his continued assertion of the right to reside in the United States without obtaining a visa demonstrated his lack of intent to relinquish United States citizenship.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1998-02-02/news/9802020254_1_puerto-rico-puerto-rican-citizenship|first=Lance|last=Oliver|title=Citizenship Questions Not Settled|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=February 2, 1998|accessdate=June 15, 2017}} {{cite journal|url=http://scholarsarchive.library.albany.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1003&context=lacs_fac_scholar|first=Pedro|last=Caban|title=The Puerto Rican Colonial Matrix: The Etiology of Citizenship|journal=Centro Journal|volume=XXV|number=1|date=2013|accessdate=June 15, 2017}}</ref> Lozada Colón petitioned for a [[writ of mandamus]] to compel the State Department to issue his CLN, arguing that he could relinquish U.S. citizenship while keeping [[Puerto Rican citizenship]] and thus the right to return to his homeland of Puerto Rico. Judge [[Stanley Sporkin]] rejected the argument that a non-U.S. citizen had the right to enter Puerto Rico, noting that Puerto Rico was part of the United States for purposes of the Immigration and Nationality Act, and so aliens required documentation from the U.S. government in order to enter and reside there.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.puertorico-herald.org/issues/vol3n22/lempres_lozada-en.html|title=Federal Court Says Congress Decides Citizenship Not Puerto Rico|work=Puerto Rico Herald|accessdate=June 15, 2017}}</ref> Sporkin further ruled that the court was not an appropriate venue to decide the [[political question]] of whether [[Puerto Rican citizenship]] could stand separately from U.S. citizenship.<ref name="LozadaColonCase"/> Following the ruling, the State Department also revoked Mari Brás' CLN.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.puertorico-herald.org/issues/vol2n10/maribras-berrios.html|title=Berrios: Decision on Mari Bras Shows P.R. Still a Colony|work=Puerto Rico Herald|agency=Associated Press|date=June 7, 1998|accessdate=June 15, 2017}}</ref>
===Other citizenship recommended but not required=== [[File:Mike Gogulski, 2007 (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Mike Gogulski]] voluntarily gave up his U.S. citizenship without acquiring any other.]]
The United States is not a signatory to either the 1954 [[Convention relating to the Status of Stateless Persons]] nor the 1961 [[Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness]]. As such, the United States permits citizens to relinquish their citizenship even when those citizens have no other citizenship, without regard to the conventions' attempts to prevent statelessness from occurring as a result of voluntary relinquishment of nationality.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.vanderbilt.edu/wp-content/uploads/sites/78/Price-FINAL.pdf|first=Polly|last=Price|title=Stateless in the United States: Current Reality and a Future Prediction|journal=Vanderbilt Journal of Transnational Law|volume=46|pages=443, 452–3|year=2013|accessdate=April 13, 2018}}</ref> The State Department warns that "severe hardship" could result to individuals making themselves stateless, that even those with permanent residence in their country "could encounter difficulties continuing to reside there without a nationality", and that a foreign country might deport stateless ex-U.S. citizens back to the United States. However, "[i]n making all these points clear to potentially stateless renunciants, the Department of State will, nevertheless, afford them their right to expatriate."<ref>[[#7 FAM 1210|7 FAM 1215]] and [[#7 FAM 1260|7 FAM 1261(g)]].</ref>
There are several known cases in which former U.S. citizens made themselves stateless voluntarily. [[Henry Martyn Noel]] moved to [[Allied-occupied Germany]] in the aftermath of World War II and voluntarily made himself stateless to protest "a climax of nationalism" he saw rising around him in the United States.<ref name="Daytona">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1873&dat=19480218&id=V9QpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YcgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2999,5647704|title=Harvard Man Gives Up His Citizenship|work=Daytona Beach Morning Journal|date=February 18, 1948|accessdate=April 14, 2018}}</ref> [[Thomas Jolley]] renounced U.S. citizenship in 1967 after acquiring [[Permanent residency in Canada|landed immigrant status in Canada]] (but not citizenship there) in order to avoid being drafted to serve in the Vietnam War.<ref name="Lorenz1972"/> [[Raffi Hovannisian]] renounced U.S. citizenship in April 2001 and made himself stateless to protest a decade-long delay in the processing of his application for [[Armenian nationality law|Armenian citizenship]]; he was subsequently granted Armenian citizenship by presidential degree about four months later.<ref name="Makaryan2013">{{cite web|url=http://eudo-citizenship.eu/docs/CountryReports/Armenia.pdf|first=Shushanik|last=Makaryan|title=Country report: Armenia|publisher=EUDO Citizenship Observatory|date=March 2013|accessdate=April 22, 2018|page=12|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304083200/http://eudo-citizenship.eu/docs/CountryReports/Armenia.pdf|archivedate=March 4, 2016}}</ref> [[Garry Davis]] and [[Mike Gogulski]] made themselves stateless because they felt that their respective political philosophies precluded allegiance to any one country.<ref name="Mendoza2011">{{cite news|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/europe/111205/stateless-slovakia--renounce-us-citizenship-mike-gogulski|first=Moises|last=Mendoza|title=Stateless in Slovakia: What if you renounce US citizenship … and you have no nationality to fall back on? Meet Mike Gogulski, refugee by choice.|work=Global Post|date=2011-12-06|accessdate=2012-05-08}}</ref>
One case in which a stateless ex-U.S. citizen was deported back to the United States, as warned of by the State Department, was that of [[Joel Slater]]. Slater, motivated by opposition to the [[foreign policy of the Ronald Reagan administration]], renounced in Perth, Australia, in 1987. After Australia deported him back to the United States, he subsequently proceeded to Canada en route to the French [[Overseas territory (France)|overseas territory]] of [[Saint Pierre and Miquelon]], but failed to secure permission to remain there, and was deported from Canada back to the United States as well.<ref name="SeattleTimes19921127">{{cite news|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19921127&slug=1526849|first=Kim|last=Boatman|title=A Man Without A Country, Literally|work=The Seattle Times|date=November 27, 1992|accessdate=April 14, 2018}}</ref> In other cases, renunciation of U.S. citizenship forestalled or prevented the stateless individual's deportation. [[Clare Negrini]] renounced U.S. citizenship in Italy in 1951 and made herself stateless in an effort to prevent Italy from expelling her back to the United States; she later married an Italian citizen and acquired Italian citizenship through him.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/winona-republican-herald/1951-12-15/page-5|title=Former Priest, Girl Plan Wedding|work=Winona Republican-Herald|date=December 15, 1951|accessdate=April 14, 2018}}</ref> [[Harmon Wilfred]] renounced U.S. citizenship in New Zealand in 2005 and made himself stateless after [[Immigration New Zealand]] (INZ) denied his application for a visa extension to remain in the country. In 2011 INZ ordered Wilfred deported, but the State Department refused to issue travel documents to allow Wilfred entry to the U.S., and in February 2018 INZ withdrew the deportation order against him.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.odt.co.nz/news/national/us-help-deport-wilfred-sought|first=David|last=Williams|title=US help to deport Wilfred sought|work=Otago Daily Times|date=October 27, 2016|accessdate=June 15, 2017}} {{cite news|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/102973303/legally-they-dont-exist-new-zealands-stateless-population-of-two|first=Oliver|last=Lewis|title='Legally they don't exist': New Zealand's stateless population of two|work=[[Stuff.co.nz]]|date=April 14, 2018|accessdate=April 16, 2018}}</ref>
===No relinquishment by parent or guardian===
In early U.S. legal history, the Supreme Court recognized the expatriation of a minor by his father's action in ''Inglis v. Trustees of Sailor's Snug Harbor'' (1830). In that case, the plaintiff had been born in New York City, but the success of his action to recover real estate turned on the [[question of law|legal question]] of his citizenship. It was not clear whether he was born before or after the [[United States Declaration of Independence]], but it was common ground that his loyalist father [[United Empire Loyalist|took him to Nova Scotia]] after the [[Evacuation Day (New York)|1783 British evacuation of New York]]. Justice [[Smith Thompson]], writing the majority opinion, held that the father's action constituted election to be a British subject under the [[Treaty of Paris (1783)|1783 Treaty of Paris]], and that decision extended to the plaintiff as well.<ref>{{cite book|first=I-Mien|last=Tsiang|title=The Question of Expatriation in America Prior to 1907|series=The Johns Hopkins University Studies in Historical and Political Science, Series LX|volume=3|year=1942|page=67|oclc=768266232|ref=harv}}</ref><ref group="Note">"The facts disclosed in this case, then, lead irresistibly to the conclusion that it was the fixed determination of Charles Inglis the father, at the declaration of independence, to adhere to his native allegiance. And John Inglis the son must be deemed to have followed the condition of his father, and the character of a British subject attached to and fastened on him also, which he has never attempted to throw off by any act disaffirming the choice made for him by his father." {{cite case|url=https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/28/99/case.html|litigants=Inglis v. Trustees of Sailor's Snug Harbor|vol=28|reporter=U.S.|opinion=99|year=1830}} For information about the harbor itself, see [[Sailors' Snug Harbor]].</ref>
In the early 20th century, the State Department and the Immigration and Naturalization Service clashed on the question of whether parental action could result in loss of citizenship of minor children. Though the Attorney-General favored the State Department's view that it could, in 1939 the Supreme Court held in ''[[Perkins v. Elg]]'' that a citizen born in the U.S. did not lose her own citizenship when her parents, both naturalized [[Swedish Americans|Americans of Swedish origin]], returned to Sweden and her father renounced his American citizenship.<ref>{{harvnb|Roche|1950|pp=30–31}}</ref> In the 2010s, the U.S. Consulate in Calgary ruled that Carol Tapanila, an [[American Canadians|American-born Canadian]] woman who had renounced her own U.S. citizenship, could not renounce on behalf of her developmentally disabled son; the son was also ruled unable to renounce on his own due to his inability to understand the concept of citizenship or renunciation, thus leaving him permanently subject to U.S. taxation on gains in his Canadian government-funded [[Registered Disability Savings Plan]].<ref name="Cain2014">{{cite news|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/1217871/how-to-get-rid-of-an-unwanted-u-s-citizenship/|first=Patrick|last=Cain|title=How to get rid of your U.S. citizenship|work=Global News|date=April 4, 2014|accessdate=June 17, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Hildebrant2014">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/u-s-fatca-tax-law-catches-unsuspecting-canadians-in-its-crosshairs-1.2493864|first=Amber|last=Hildebrant|title=U.S. FATCA tax law catches unsuspecting Canadians in its crosshairs|work=CBC News|date=January 13, 2014|accessdate=June 17, 2017}}</ref>
The statutory definition of some potentially expatriating acts, namely foreign naturalization, foreign oath of allegiance, and foreign government service, requires that the person performing them have been eighteen years or older at the time in order to relinquish citizenship through those acts.<ref>[[#7 FAM 1210|7 FAM 1214(b)(7)]] and {{cite book|chapterurl=https://fam.state.gov/fam/07fam/07fam1290.html|chapter=7 FAM 1290: Minors, Incompetents, Prisoners, Plea Bargains, Cults and Other Special Circumstances|title=Foreign Affairs Manual|publisher=Department of State|date=March 25, 2013|accessdate=June 15, 2017|ref=7 FAM 1290}}</ref> There is no statutory age restriction on renunciation before a U.S. diplomatic officer abroad; nevertheless, the State Department often refuses to accept renunciations by minors, and carefully scrutinizes cases involving even individuals who have recently attained the age of majority, on the theory that they may be subject to ongoing influence by their parents.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.emirates247.com/news/i-accidentally-became-a-us-citizen-and-cannot-get-rid-of-the-passport-2013-11-23-1.528931|first=Majorie|last=Van Leijen|title='I accidentally became a US citizen and cannot get rid of the passport': Minors who have involuntarily acquired US citizenship find it difficult to renounce it|work=Emirates 24/7|date=November 23, 2013|accessdate=February 11, 2018}} Cites language in [[#7 FAM 1290|7 FAM 1290]] and {{cite book|chapterurl=https://fam.state.gov/fam/07fam/07fam1230.html#M1236|chapter=7 FAM 1236: Reviewing the Record|title=Foreign Affairs Manual|publisher=Department of State|date=June 29, 2012|accessdate=February 11, 2018}}</ref>
==Reasons for relinquishing citizenship==
===Foreign prohibitions on multiple citizenship===
[[File:Valdas Adamkus.2007.jpg|thumb|right|[[Valdas Adamkus]] renounced U.S. citizenship to run for [[president of Lithuania]], and was elected to the position twice.]]
Although the U.S. government has removed most restrictions on [[multiple citizenship|dual or multiple citizenship]] from its nationality laws, some other countries retain such restrictions, and U.S. citizens in such countries may choose to give up U.S. citizenship to comply with those restrictions.
Some foreign countries do not permit their citizens to hold other citizenships at all. Bars on dual citizenship take a variety of forms, but two common provisions in such countries' laws are that a foreigner seeking to become a citizen of the country generally must obtain release from any other citizenships according to the laws of those other countries (a provision seen for example in South Korea and Austria), and that a person who was born with dual citizenship must choose whether to retain the local citizenship or the foreign citizenship upon reaching the age of majority (e.g. in Japan).<ref name="Seeker">{{cite news|url=https://www.seeker.com/which-countries-dont-allow-dual-citizenship-1933771298.html|title=Which Countries Don't Allow Dual Citizenship?|publisher=[[Seeker (media company)|Seeker]]|date=2016-07-20|accessdate=2017-12-07}}</ref> In the 1990s, many individuals relinquishing citizenship were naturalized citizens returning to their countries of birth; for example, the State Department indicated to the JCT that many of the 858 U.S. citizens who renounced in 1994 were former [[Korean Americans]] who returned to South Korea and resumed their citizenship there, which under [[South Korean nationality law]] required them to give up their U.S. citizenship.<ref>{{harvnb|JCT|1995|p=8}}</ref> By the late 1990s, the number of relinquishments had fallen to about 400 per year. The State Department speculated that the [[1997 Asian financial crisis]] resulted in "fewer people renounc[ing] their U.S. citizenship as a condition of employment in an Asian country".<ref>{{harvnb|Ashby|2000|p=4}}</ref>
Even countries which permit dual citizenship may bar dual citizens from government positions. Australia for example does not allow dual citizens to stand for election to Parliament, while Taiwan bars dual citizens from most public-sector positions.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-13/dual-nationality-crisis-claims-eighth-aussie-lawmaker-scalp|first=Jason|last=Scott|title=Australia’s Dual-Nationality Crisis Claims Eighth Victim|work=Bloomberg Politics|date=November 13, 2017|access-date=February 10, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Mt3LhhI3ZwwC&pg=PA213|first=Bernard|last=Wong|title=The Chinese in Silicon Valley: Globalization, Social Networks, and Ethnic Identity|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=2006|page=213|isbn=9780742539402}} {{cite web|url=http://law.moj.gov.tw/LawClass/LawAllIf.aspx?PCode=S0020001|title=公務人員任用法第 28 條|publisher=Ministry of Justice|location=Taiwan|date=June 17, 2015|access-date=February 10, 2018}}</ref> Diplomatic and consular positions present additional difficulties. The [[Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations]] and [[Vienna Convention on Consular Relations]] state that a country may refuse to receive a diplomat or consular officer who holds the citizenship of the receiving country. Based on this, the State Department does not receive U.S. citizens and non-citizen nationals as diplomats representing a foreign country to the United States. The State Department permits such individuals to represent a foreign country in its [[diplomatic mission]] at [[United Nations Headquarters]] in New York City, but while in such positions they enjoy only [[consular immunity|official acts immunity]] and not [[diplomatic immunity]]. Thus, an individual wishing to assume a diplomatic or consular position in the United States may choose to relinquish U.S. citizenship.<ref>{{cite book|chapterurl=https://fam.state.gov/FAM/07FAM/07FAM1280.html|chapter=7 FAM 1280: Loss of Nationality and Taking up a Position in a Foreign Government|title=Foreign Affairs Manual|publisher=Department of State|date=March 25, 2013|accessdate=June 15, 2017|ref=7 FAM 1280}}</ref> One early example of this, which was described at the time as the first such case in U.S. diplomatic history, was [[Oskar R. Lange]]'s decision to renounce citizenship in 1945 to become the Polish ambassador to the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chicagotribune.newspapers.com/image/370000738/|first=Walter|last=Trohan|title=Lange to yield citizenship to be Poles' envoy|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=August 20, 1945|accessdate=April 15, 2018|quote=For the first time in the diplomatic history of the United States, an American citizen is renouncing his allegiance to his adopted country in order to become the ambassador to Washington of the nation he disowned ...}}</ref>
===Tax compliance difficulties for U.S. citizens abroad===
[[File:Individual taxation systems.png|thumb|left|Systems of taxation on personal income{{legend|#00FF00|No income tax on individuals}}{{legend|#0080FF|Territorial}}{{legend|#000080|Residential}}{{legend|#FF00FF|Citizenship-based}}]]
The United States is the only country which taxes the foreign income of citizens residing abroad permanently.<ref>{{harvnb|Spiro|2017|p=168}}</ref><ref group="Note">Eritrea, which is frequently mentioned as another country practicing "citizenship-based taxation", requires citizens abroad to fill out a one-page form and pay a 2% reconstruction tax. Both proponents and detractors of the U.S. system agree that it is not analogous to the Eritrean system, e.g. {{harvnb|Kirsch|2014}} and {{harvnb|Spiro|2017}}. Reports that China practices citizenship-based taxation are incorrect; see {{cite journal|url=http://www.taxanalysts.org/content/experts-question-accuracy-new-york-times-story-chinese-taxation|first=Stephanie Soong|last=Johnston|title=Experts Question Accuracy of ''New York Times'' Story on Chinese Taxation|journal=Tax Analysts|date=January 22, 2015|accessdate=June 6, 2017|postscript=none}}.</ref> The United States first imposed taxes on overseas citizens during the [[United States Civil War|Civil War]], and has done so continuously since the [[Revenue Act of 1913]] up to the present.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://scholarship.law.nd.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1952&context=law_faculty_scholarship|first=Michael|last=Kirsch|title=Revisiting the Tax Treatment of Citizens Abroad: Reconciling Principle and Practice|journal=Florida Tax Review|volume=16|issue=3|date=2014|page=117, 119|accessdate=2017-10-31|ref=harv}}</ref> During that period, the small number of other countries with similar practices all repealed such laws and moved to taxing based on residence,<ref group="Note">Most recently Vietnam in 2007 and Myanmar in 2012. {{cite news|url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/vietnam-law-on-personal-income-tax/|title=Vietnam: Law on Personal Income Tax|work=Global Legal Monitor|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|date=April 2, 2008|accessdate=April 10, 2018}} {{cite news|url=http://www2.irrawaddy.com/article.php?art_id=22805|first=Simon|last=Roughneen|title=Burmese Abroad Welcome Tax Break, but More Reforms Needed|newspaper=[[The Irrawaddy]]|date=January 10, 2012|accessdate=April 10, 2018}}</ref> to the extent that residence-based taxation might now be regarded as a norm of [[customary international law]]; [[Allison Christians]] has stated that the U.S. might be regarded as a [[persistent objector]] to the emergence of this new norm, though she notes that the U.S.' sporadic efforts to enforce its system over the years in which this norm formed might not rise to the level of "persistent".<ref>{{harvnb|Christians|2017|p=224–228}}</ref>
The U.S. [[foreign tax credit]] and [[Foreign Earned Income Exclusion]] reduce [[double taxation]] but do not eliminate it even for people whose income is well below the exclusion threshold, particularly in the case of [[Federal Insurance Contributions Act tax#Self-employed people|self-employment tax]].<ref>{{cite journal|first=Bernard|last=Schneider|title=The End of Taxation without End: A New Tax Regime for U.S. Expatriates|journal=Virginia Law Review|volume=32|issue=1|year=2012|ssrn=2186076|ref=harv|page=30}}</ref> The treatment of foreign-currency loans can result in U.S. income tax owed even when there has been no income in real terms, which causes difficulties for those who obtained a [[mortgage]] to purchase a home in their country of residence.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/27/news/27iht-rmort_ed3_.html|first=Conrad|last=De Aenlle|title=Property losses and gains: Selling up? Prepare for a taxing time|newspaper=International Herald-Tribune|date=July 27, 2002|accessdate=April 12, 2018|archivedate=April 12, 2018}}</ref>{{refn|group=Note|Specifically, U.S. citizens, unlike businesses, are required to use the United States dollar as their [[functional currency]]. If the U.S. dollar has gone up in value, repayment of the foreign-currency loan creates [[Cancellation of Debt (COD) Income|income from cancellation of debt]], because in U.S. dollar terms the initial amount of indebtedness is greater than the value of the depreciated foreign currency used to pay back the loan. {{cite web|url=https://hodgen.com/when-buying-a-home-is-a-forex-transaction/|title=When buying a home is a forex transaction|publisher=Hodgen Law PC|date=May 29, 2015|access-date=April 12, 2018|postscript=none}}. Furthermore, U.S. citizens, unlike businesses, are not allowed to use {{USCSub|26|988|d|1}} to net gains on foreign-currency loans with capital losses on assets acquired with those loans. {{cite case|url=http://openjurist.org:80/93/f3d/26/quijano-v-united-states|litigants=Quijano v. United States|vol=93|reporter=F.3d|opinion=26|court=1st Cir.|year=1996}}}} Foreign government-sponsored savings plans or structures may face complicated reporting requirements under United States anti-offshoring laws; for example the Canadian [[Registered Disability Savings Plan]] may be a foreign trust for U.S. tax purposes,<ref name="Cain2014"/><ref name="Hildebrant2014"/> while non-US [[mutual fund]]s may be [[passive foreign investment company|Passive Foreign Investment Companies]].<ref name="Christians2015">{{cite news|url=http://www.taxanalysts.org/content/understanding-accidental-american-tinas-story|first=Allison|last=Christians|title=Understanding the Accidental American: Tina's Story|work=Tax Analysts|date=December 8, 2015|accessdate=June 15, 2017}}</ref> The forms for reporting such assets are time consuming to complete, often requiring expensive professional assistance, and penalties of $10,000 per form can be imposed for failure to file.<ref name="Christians2015"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thebalance.com/accidental-americans-tax-penalties-for-americans-overseas-3193099|first=William|last=Perez|title=Learn About Tax Penalties for Americans Overseas|date=December 18, 2017|accessdate=April 12, 2018}} {{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2015/03/10/pf/taxes/us-expat-kids-citizenship-tax/index.html?iid=EL|first=Sophia|last=Yan|title=Uncle Sam says my Swedish kid is American|work=CNN Money|date=March 11, 2015|accessdate=April 12, 2018}}</ref>{{refn|group=Note|For example, Form 3520, required for foreign savings plans classified as trusts by U.S. tax law as mentioned above, has a total time burden of 54 hours (including the time for recordkeeping, learning about the law or form, and preparing the form), according to estimates made by the IRS under the [[Paperwork Reduction Act]], and has a minimum penalty of $10,000 for incomplete or incorrect filing. {{cite web|url=https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/i3520.pdf|title=Instructions for Form 3520: Annual Return To Report Transactions With Foreign Trusts and Receipt of Certain Foreign Gifts|publisher=Internal Revenue Service|date=October 25, 2016|accessdate=April 12, 2018|pages=2, 14|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170430025608/https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/i3520.pdf|archivedate=April 30, 2017|postscript=none}}. For further details, see {{cite web|url=http://intltax.typepad.com/intltax_blog/2015/11/the-escalation-of-offshore-penalties-over-the-last-20-years.html|first=Andrew|last=Mitchel|title=The Escalation of Offshore Penalties Over the Last 20 Years|work=International Tax Blog|date=November 2, 2015|accessdate=April 12, 2018|postscript=none}}.}} Furthermore, the [[Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act]] (FATCA) imposed additional compliance burdens on non-U.S. banks, making them increasingly unwilling to extend anything beyond basic banking services to customers with U.S. citizenship.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/money/2014/sep/24/americans-chased-by-irs-give-up-citizenship-after-being-forced-out-of-bank-accounts|first=Siri|last=Srinivas|title='I was terrified we'd lose all our money': banks tell US customers they won't work with Americans|work=The Guardian|date=September 24, 2014|accessdate=April 12, 2018|quote=Scared of running afoul of US banking laws, foreign banks are taking extreme steps to limit US citizens to a narrow range of services. The result for expats has been a chaotic brew of closed bank accounts, mysterious excuses and a scramble to find local banks that would allow them to park their money.}}</ref> One scholar described the sum total of these requirements as "an attack on [[ordre public]]".<ref>{{harvnb|Grossman|2018|loc=§ 6}}</ref>
The rise in relinquishments in the 2010s appears to have been driven by increased awareness of the tax and reporting burdens on U.S. citizens in other countries; in particular, many relinquishers are believed to be [[accidental American]]s who only learned about their citizenship and these burdens due to enforcement of and publicity about FATCA.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.ctf.ca/ctfweb/Custom/CMDownload.aspx?ContentKey=4fa01c65-281b-437c-8099-bae25c4fbca6&ContentItemKey=11eb8ece-4a53-4f1a-a676-cb888fe67ed5|first=Kevyn|last=Nightingale|first2=David|last2=Turchen|title=Expatriation: The American's Tax Experience in Canada|journal=Canadian Tax Journal|volume=61|issue=1|year=2013|page=1, 12–13|accessdate=2017-10-31|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171031104012/https://www.ctf.ca/ctfweb/Custom/CMDownload.aspx?ContentKey=4fa01c65-281b-437c-8099-bae25c4fbca6&ContentItemKey=11eb8ece-4a53-4f1a-a676-cb888fe67ed5|archivedate=2017-10-31}}</ref> Some legal scholars interpret the number of U.S. citizenship relinquishers as indicating acceptance of the tax and reporting burdens by those who do not relinquish.<ref>{{harvnb|Kirsch|2014|p=125, 187–190}}</ref> Others believe that the number of people giving up citizenship remains small only because some ''de jure'' dual citizens, particularly those born abroad, remain unaware of their status or are able to hide from the U.S. government more effectively than those born in the United States.<ref>{{harvnb|Spiro|2017|p=191}} and {{harvnb|Grossman|2018|loc=§ 1}}</ref>
===U.S. military service===
In 1972, one commentator described Selective Service registration and military service as the "primary obligation" of U.S. citizen men living abroad, aside from taxation.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://scholarship.law.berkeley.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2608&context=californialawreview|first=Stephen S.|last=Bell|title=Expatriation: Constitutional and Non-Constitutional Citizenship|journal=California Law Review|volume=60|issue=6|page=1595}}</ref> In a 1995 report, the Joint Committee on Taxation attributed the high number of people who gave up U.S. citizenship in the 1960s and 1970s to the [[Vietnam War]].<ref>{{harvnb|JCT|1995|p=7}}</ref>
===Other reasons===
Other individual ex-citizens have expressed a variety of reasons for giving up U.S. citizenship.
